reviewText:
Overall, both acts of Broken Age left me disappointed. One might say, a double failed adventure.

The game has some things that work well, like the animation, the graphics and everything audio.
For those wondering where the multi million budgetdisappeared, I assume the famous voiceovers are partialy to blame. Is Jack Black's or Elijah Wood's voices essential to the enjoyment of this game? Not when it comes at the expense of the actual gameplay.

I've read on the forums some complaints about the difficulty of the puzzles. As a longtime adventure point and click aficionada, I thought they were of medium difficulty and if you really took the time to look for the solution, you would eventually find it (with one or two exceptions - like the wire puzzle). The main problem of the game is that it is tedious. The characters and the story are very unidimensional, there is no real substance, no nuances to them and the puzzles are there only so that you have something to do towards ending the game. There are so many loose ends, so many missed opportunities, you can only wonder how much thought they actually put in the game. In the end, you don't really care about any of the characters, you're glad it's over.

The cherry on top, after two years of waiting for a full game, you get an incomplete ending that seems to suggest there will be a third act. I see that as a slap in the face of everybody who ever payed for this game.

I left my original review at the bottom part of this comment.

First of all, cannot believe they still haven't released the second part yet.  They could have delivered a full game only on the money they got from Kickstarter. Yes, the graphics are nice but other developers deliver similar or even better animations on less than half of that budget.
Regarding the story: at first, I felt it had a lot of potential, but it turned out to be pretty dull. The characters are not interesting and the puzzles are uninspired. I cannot fully rate it, because I could only play half of it, but I definitely put a pin in this game creator.
There are other lesser known but better games out there like The Chronicles of Zerzura, the Chains of Satinav etc

reviewText: Broken Age exceeded all of my expectations. The artwork is beautiful and the world is wonderfully crafted with so much character and life. I've been a fan of adventure games since I was a kid but for about 10 years now it's been really hard to find quality adventure games that make you fall in love with the world and the characters. This is exactly the game that's been missing. The story is engaging and keeps you guessing until the end. The voice acting is excellent. There were numerous laugh out loud moments where my husband and I were in stitches. We chose to switch between the two stories regularly which kept us engaged in both worlds. Thank you Double Fine for delivering such an amazing game that pushes the boundaries for the genre with the stunning art and the depth of the story.
voteText: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game only took about 5 1/2 hours to beat and was frankly unsatisfying. The plot/game world made no sense and the comedy was weak. Art wise the game has been consistently bad, it looks like barely any effort was put in. There's a weeks worth of background art and a days worth of character design in there.
The puzzles were needlessly long, requiring a fair bit of running around through the same 6 or so screens. This only inflated the game length rather than add difficulty or enjoyment. If they put the objects for each puzzle within one or two rooms then this game would be even shorter. It's not the difficulty of the puzzles that takes so long, it's having to go back and forth and jot things down on a bit of paper. The only reason it took me as long as it did to complete this game is because I went into act 2 expecting not to need any paper. If you went in fully prepared you could probably beat the game in under 5 hours (not skipping dialogue).

The Book of Unwritten Tales series and Deponia are far superior. Wouldn't buy this game for more than £8 if I hadn't already paid as much as I did. Tis a shame I can not get a refund.

reviewText:
Broken Age is a game of two halves thanks to how development went and it really feels like it, as they completely changed how the game was from one act to another. Act 1 is all about setting up the story with a few puzzles here and there but nothing that will get in the way of enjoying the experience. Then you get to Act 2 and it feels like you're hitting a wall with puzzle after puzzle that will make you go back and forth, the game never makes it that apparent what you can or can't interact with either so sometimes you may need to pickle hunt. It can be frustrating and unintuitive as sometimes you will have to find something using one character to use with the other as if their minds are telepathically linked.

It is unfortunate as the game did have a lot of promise in Act 1 with interesting characters, a story set up to make you wonder what is going on with this world, decent voice acting and writing but by the end because of the frustration I felt, act 2's story didn't save it and felt almost trapped behind the puzzles, the ending wasn't very satisfying either so I left the game feeling dejected.

I cannot recommend this game, if you are all about the puzzles then you may well enjoy this but then you'd probably feel that act 1 was too easy and possibly boring for you. If you're more interesting in story, characters and the world then you could just end up feeling like I did.

reviewText: I saw so many negative reviews on this game, but I still gave it a chance because it looks beautiful and the voice cast is amazing! I have to say, this is one of my favorite games of all time. It is simple, but the art is stunningly beautiful and I adore the world, the characters, and the crazy storyline. I wish I could forget it all and play it through the first time again. Yes, the second act is a challenge and sometimes I had to look up outside help, but most of it I figured out myself with no outside help. I love this game and I won't be forgetting it any time soon.

reviewText:
It’s great to see that Double Fine’s Kickstarter wasn’t a complete flop.

There was a lot of anger towards this game for various reasons of which I do actually understand. The kickstarter was launched asking for $400,000 and they ended up with $3.45 million. Yet they blew their money too quickly and ended up having to release a first act to try and raise funds for the second. Which a lot of people deemed the second act to be lazy and rushed.

All of that aside, in my opinion Double Fine do great games. I’ve been following them for a while now and so far I haven’t been all that disappointed with anything that they’ve made that I have played. Despite their games always having a somewhat childlike feel to them, I always enjoy them.

Sometimes I do wonder if this would have gotten so much hate if the game was released as normal with people being pretty unaware of the recent drama and goings on of Double Fine. If you were to buy this game without knowing anything about it, I think more people would enjoy it.

This was kickstarted shortly after the “Amnesia Fortnight” events that Double Fine did, of which I loved. So I backed this since the beginning. From what feels like forever ago, I just never really bothered all that much actually watching or getting involved with it. It’s kind of been just a dusty book on the shelf until now. I finally got around to playing it and can say I think they did a really great job with it. I may actually go and watch the documentary now.

The story is definitely interesting. Luckily by the time I played it the second act was already out. I can’t imagine myself being all that happy about having to wait quite a while for the next act. But that’s down to pure impatience. I wanted to know what was going on straight away. I was expecting something a little different when it came to the story, but it surprised me in a good way. The story comes together in ways I couldn’t predict.

I think most people’s problem with the story is that a lot of act 1 is the set up. It asks all the questions, it gets you interested and it leaves you on a cliff hanger. After all that waiting, act 2 came out and honestly I can understand people’s disappointment. Most questions are straight up just answered. No real build up. The answers were somewhat brief, vague and honestly there are some holes in the story which made me wonder. I get the feeling most people yearned for more information or something much deeper then what it turned out to be. But I see this game again as almost child-like and light hearted. It honestly didn’t bother me all that much. I still enjoyed it and didn’t at all feel any sense of real disappointment concerning the plot.

The art in the game is really nice. It’s smooth and wonderfully drawn. The audio is well done both music and voice acting wise. I can only assume they blew most of that budget getting Elijah Wood in. The puzzles are straight forward most of the time, which again I think rustled some jimmies. But I honestly enjoyed a little bit more simplicity. It helped the game flow a bit better for me. I could progress and find out what the fudge was going on (I can be impatient when it comes to plotlines). The main kind of puzzle at the end I found a lot of fun. As to where to find the solution is annoying, but deciphering what everything means was quite fun for me.

Usually I end up getting frustrated with point and click games (I think many people do) as it can sometimes be pretty easy to get stuck.
Admittedly, I still got stuck on this a few times for a fair while but the puzzles and combinations are logical enough to not be stuck (and therefore annoyed) for very long. It’s also a nice feature to the game being able to switch between characters and take a break from what you were doing.

The annoying part is the achievements (if you are even into achievements, I suppose). I personally insisted on 100%ing the game.
It took me 18 hours and I have to say it was a little tedious. That may be just because I stayed up until 1am no-lifing and ended up quite tired and annoyed with it… but still. If you’re looking for an easy 100% it’s not all that easy. It’s do-able but you’ll need to be meticulous, complete it a few times over and be able to be quite fast about a complete play through to do it.

All in all, I enjoyed this game. I thought it was great. Was also nice to see Pendleton Ward doing some voice work for Double Fine after the last Amnesia Fortnight. I hope to see more of that.
Keep it up Double Fine!


TL;DR : Despite all the recent Double Fine drama, it’s a great story,  it had good audio, visuals and puzzles. It has achievements that actually do feel an achievement to get and it just generally is another great game by Double Fine. I’d think any point and click or Double Fine fan would like this game. If you’re neither or those things, try it anyway. I still think there’s a chance you might enjoy it despite Double Fine’s games always having a slight childlike feel to them.

reviewText: Tim Schafer is a game creator that I knew little about until I started to search for an adventure game to play. Tim Schafer is known for creating Grim Fandango (I never played it), which is loved by many and to be honest, I wish I was around to play it. He is also known for other things I bet, I am planning on doing research later. I love adventure games, and usually have it at the top of my list for things to play, and those with amazing stories please even more. When I first saw Broken Age on VGX, I was imediately hooked just by the art style and concept of the story. I got my hands on the game 5 months later than I hoped, wishing I bought it right at the start. This game is absolutely amazing, and Double Fine does it's well known job of amazing wrting, and I found myself laughing and crying at many points throughout this game. At the start of the game however, I started to feel a bit bored after a while, and after I had that feeling, I am thrown right into the point where I am on the edge of my seat. It is sad to say that the game is only one act currently, and I found myself annoyed that I dont have a release date for act 2 yet.. Then again, I waited for act 1, and I got exactly what I wanted. Waiting for Act 2 may in fact be a pain just because I am so desperately waiting to jump back into the story of Shay and Vella, but whenever it comes out, I know it will be just as good as this part, if not better. This review is not the best one I know, but it really does not have to be to tell you that this game is beautiful and very entertaining. I honestly say get the game if you want to have an amazing adventure that has probably one of the greatest scripts and stories I have ever seen. Broken Age is amazing and creative, and showed me exactly why adventure games are amazing, and threw me back into the times where I did not have a chance to experience adventures at their core. 9.75/10 I would reccomend this game to anyone.

reviewText:
(Note: I'm a backer for Broken Age and it's currently one of the only ways to actually play the game. My money supported Broken Age so I'm obviously biased. Nevertheless, this review is for non-backers who are interested in purchasing Broken Age.)

Broken Age is both a huge risk for Double Fine and a return to form for them. Broken Age's origin is a popular one of initially a small revival of the old school adventure game genre with a small asking price of 400k. This was back when Kickstarter wasn't the monolithic giant that it is now. The project raised much more than that and went as high as 3.4 million dollars. The development of Broken Age can be called rocky at best with expectations being much higher than the Broken Age team ever dreamed of. As a backer I've had the privilege of seeing behind the curtain of game development and have seen the best and worst from the dev team. I had high hopes for Broken Age and the documentary gave me a higher investment for the project than any video game that I've ever looked forward to. Hell, any thing that has your name in the credits is hopefully something that you're proud of being involved with. So call me a fan boy or anything like that, but I won't back down from my stance on Broken Age. After much anticipation I must say that I really enjoyed my time with Broken Age.

The best thing that can be said for Broken Age is how great it looks. Every single environment has the look of it being hand painted and treated with care. You can notice it from looking around by how many things have smiley faces or from how everything seems to fit together perfectly. It was a joy to walk around every new area to see how bizarre yet familiar every environment looks. It's accompanied by a wonderful score that fits each new area. My personal favorite came from Shay's part as it reflects the space ship theme. All of it can fall apart if the actual game play and story don't mesh together well. That isn't the case for Broken Age.

Broken Age's story is one of two characters that are each in different time periods and different situations that are worlds apart from each other. They both can seemingly never meet each other yet both have similar situations. Broken Age is a story of personal triumph from oppressive adults. Whether it be Shay's computer mother or Vella's grandmother both are set out to accomplish self-sacrifice for a goal that is of high importance. They both must decided if they should rebel against their elders in order to break tradition. You'll be able to aid both of them in any order you want to. I went with Shay's story first as I was more excited by space. Without spoiling anything I found the story and dialogue of Broken Age to be charming, funny, and nostalgic. This is the first adventure game that Tim Schafer has made in a long time. Grim Fandango was the last big adventure game that he's worked on as a writer. You could easily notice that he wrote Broken Age by how funny it is. The dialogue tree in particular made me laugh several times. It also has a lot of humor from using your inventory on any thing or one in the environment in order to get some kind of reaction. I haven't played a traditional adventure game since Tim Schafer left Lucas Arts so it was truly a nostalgic trip back to the days when adventure games were big on PC. That said, Broken Age isn't just a trip down memory lane. It's a story of breaking away from the past and paving a new future.

Double Fine promised a return to old school adventure games and it's a promise that was kept. Broken Age play like you typical adventure game with both a mouse cursor and an inventory. In Broken Age you'll have to solve many small puzzles in order to continue forward with the story. Some of these solutions make sense but others are as ridiculous as you'd expect from old adventure game logic. Luckily, it doesn't suffer from pixel hunting problems and brutally difficult puzzle logic. However, I wish that the game offered a button to let you know what kind of items are in the environment as most of the items that you'll put into your inventory don't stand out as well as I'd like.

I also found most of the situations to be fairly easy to solve. I would've liked some more complex puzzles to be in the game. There's also a arm grabbing mini-game in Shay's section that is harder than it should be for something that is necessary to solve in order to beat the game. It's at times far too easy and mostly overly difficult for such a simple mini-game that isn't all that fun. It's also a game that deserves the Beta moniker as the game crashed multiple times for me. It also had numerous bugs such as text being unreadable and characters getting stuck in the environment. These bugs and crashes are an unfortunate part of the early release for us backers but hopefully it shouldn't be a problem once the game is released to the public.

It was probably impossible to fulfill the high expectations that many felt after the huge success of the Double Fine Kickstarter. However, as a backer I'm glad to say that my expectations were met for Broken Age. It certainly isn't the greatest adventure game ever but it's still a well worth your time and money. Broken Age is a highly polished journey that has memorable voices from Jack Black, Jennifer Hale, and even Elijah Wood. These voices were treated right and aren't simply cameos. Everything surrounding Broken Age is filled with the love and care that you'd expect a Double Fine game to have. That's the same with Broken Age but it's also amplified higher than ever before. A lot if riding on Broken Age and I felt that they succeed in making a great adventure game that can hang with the best of the genre. This could all go to ♥♥♥♥ if the second Act in Broken Age sucks but I'm confident that it won't after playing the first Act. It isn't perfect of course. I still feel that the mechanics and puzzles in the game were far too easy to solve or simply obtuse enough for me to be confused for longer than I'd like. Hopefully the second act has better puzzles to solve. The story and everything is strong enough that it overshadows the puzzles but it still hurts the overall package. I can't wait to finish the story of Broken Age as a backer and a fan of old school adventure games.

reviewText:
This game is wonderful.

I grew up on Tim Schaffer's games. Day of the Tentacle, Full Throttle, Maniac Mansion, and other Lucas Arts titles like Monkey Island and Sam & Max. This game is a continuation of those games.

Some people complain that those old school graphic adventure titles had illogical puzzles that only made sense to the developers. And I'd say those are people with no imagination. Puzzle solving in these games are puns. There are clues that make them perfectly logical for the world that they're in and often require some degree of familiarity with tropes and cliché followed by subverting them.

Act 2 has some very obtuse puzzles, but if you take the time to look at your environment, you can solve them.

Players are so used to instant gratification. That is not what this game is about. Its a much slower game. That requires piecing together clues and exploring your options. Adventure games are not designed to be fast. They're designed to be clever.

This game is very clever. To get everything it has to offer you need to take it slow. You need time to reflect. There is so much narrative packed in to this game that's just hidden in plain sight. If you were able to plow through this game, you'd never notice the little details hidden in the background that helps tell you the story.

It's possible that people don't appreciate experiences like this anymore. But I for one do.

reviewText:
Well this is rather pleasant.

Broken Age isn’t a brash, jaw dropping, impossibly clever, superlative inducing spectacular. Instead it brings an old school charm.

It seems not too much has changed in the 20 years since Tim Schafer last shipped a point and click adventure. The main difference is with the complexity of the puzzles. Broken Age is more story focused than puzzle focused with a simple single click interface replacing the verb system found in the old SCUMM games. But at the heart of this is Tim Schafer’s story, with colourful characters, imaginative settings and witty dialog.

The story focuses across the two protagonists stuck in an absurdity that they are trying to escape from; one on a spaceship that controls their every action, the other in a fantasy land where they joyfully given as a sacrifice to a mysterious beast.
Both of the settings are relatively small, but beautifully realised. Each story is largely independent with nothing like the item passing mechanic of Day of the Tentacle, meaning you can complete each at your own pace, swapping between the two characters at will.

Everything comes together very nicely, from the writing, the excellent soundtrack and the beautiful story book art. There’s some excellent animation work as well and while a couple of lines fall flat, most of the voice work is very good.

There are a few minor issues, mainly with the interface. You can’t chose dialog options with the keyboard, the cursor is unnecessarily large and the inventory system is a bit awkward (I recombined rebinding right click to opening your inventory).

There’s a larger issue if you were hoping for brain teasing puzzles, but if you were looking for a captivating adventure game your only real complain will probably be that Act 1 comes to an end a bit too soon.

reviewText:
Broken Age, is a retro-looking point-and-click adventure game, recently released by Double Fine Productions, and funded by Kickstarter backers. It is an absolute feast of an incredibly unique art design, with amazing soundtracks, and a great, great story. Divided into 2 parts, which both are included in price, one is currently available to play, and other one is in progress right now.

(This review is written for people who are familiar with the genre, and have some brief background knowledge about it. I recommend you to pass if you are unfamiliar, since I'll be refering to some classics and relating Broken Age's quality to them.)

I want to talk about the sounds of the game first, since it actually impresses me the most. As expected, Peter McConnell (He was responsible for soundtracks of many LucasArts and Double Fine Productions classics. Creator of that famous Monkey Island loop, pretty nice, eh?) did an amazing job on soundtracks, perfectly reflecting the spirits of places like Meriloft, Shellmound, Bossa Nostra, making you feel like you are actually there. It's one of the best game OST I've recently heard, along with Bastion, Transistor, Braid, and Thomas was Alone OST's. As for dialogues, what you'll encounter is beyond belief, as it was a Kickstarter funded game. Names like Elijah Wood and Jack Black are the voice actors, and they all have done an amazing job, also as expected. You may wonder like, Where did they found all that money to pay them?"

reviewText:
The puzzles are probably a little too easy for point-and-click adventure game veterans - finished it in around 6 hours and I didn't attempt to rush through it. So if you're expecting a challenge, look elsewhere.

In all other ways, it lives up to expectations as a Tim Schafer game. The setting is adorable without being outright twee. The dual PC/split POV narrative has promise and some really fantastic bits (can't say more here without spoilers). The writing is never as outright hilarious as, say, a Monkey Island game, but it does stay consistently amusing throughout.

Also because of its pedigree, the gameplay is gratifyingly streamlined. As an example: in older games, getting from one side of the map to the other was a chore, consisting of watching your character amble along each screen. In this game, if you double click an in-room destination, the character will jog there. Double-click an exit and you warp to the next room immediately, bypassing the walk animation completely. This may be one reason the game is so much quicker to complete, but I'm a huge fan of the feature and others like it. Adventure games should be challenging, but never tedious.

Is it worth full price? I received the game as a gift, so it's hard for me to say whether you will get $20 worth of fun out of it. But now that I'm hooked on the setting and story, I'll be picking up the rest of the game without a doubt.

reviewText:
I love broken age. Everything about it brings memories of the games I used to play as a child. The voice acting is flawless, the graphics are very beautiful in a unique kind of way, and the story line is genious, not to mention the humour that anyone of all ages can enjoy. I loved every single moment of this brilliant point and click title.

However, there is only one flaw to this game, it only took me 3.4 hours to finish! I know that there will be another act coming out soon, which may be roughly another 4 hours; but 30$ for a 7.4 hours game is a bit much. For replay value, I could see my friends giving it a try, but it would be hard to enjoy the story knowing what happens at the end of the act and all the jokes in between.

Do I reccomend this game? On sale, it's a must buy. Not on sale, wait for the second act to come out.

reviewText: I finished this game today, and I must say playing thorugh Act 1 with the massive cliffhanger at the end wanted me to play Act 2 with the hope that it would be awesome. Instead Act 2 feels like a mess. Pretty much you are doing the same as in Act 1 but the opposite way. I was really bummed out by the ending and some feeling of the developers rushing to finish the game. Story- and puzzlewise I think its messy in Act 2. There are no hints in the gameworld some of the time as to what to do next, and you're almost doomed to read a walkthrough just to get to the next.  I can't in my right mind recommend this game because of this.

reviewText:
Broken Age started out extremely strong. Act One was phenomenal in almost every aspect, however, I feel like Act Two kind of dropped the ball.

Graphics:
The graphics throughout the entire game were amazingly colorful and bright. Everything was pleasant to look at and really helped to bring the game to life.

Audio:
The voice actors did a decent job with bringing out whatever emotion they could from the script. The music was complimentary to what ever was going on in the scene at the time and also helped to add to the excitement.

Storyline:
The storyline throughout Act One was extremely well done. It gave an in depth sense of what was going on and why, and you knew exactly why you were doing the things you were. However, once you got into Act Two, the storyline almost seemed non existent. The puzzles became increasingly hard, almost to the point of wanting to give up, with very little clues to go on. For a good portion of the final Act, I spent a lot of time looking through walkthroughs just to be able to move on.

Even though I enjoyed this game for the most part, I have a hard time recommending this game, based on the fact that Act Two left too much to be desired. I have more questions at the end of Act Two, then I did when I started it. There are still too many loose ends that have not been tied up. The game itself had so much potential, and I think that is why there was so much disappointment at the end.

reviewText:
Is this it? Really?

Mr. Schaefer, I don't mind a short game, but really? This is the best you could muster? A pathetically short story with mind-numbingly easy puzzles and uninteresting characters? I'd have to say I'm pretty disappointed.

As far as art style goes, its alright, but it feels....off. I don't even really know how to describe it. It feels really faux-something. It doesn't feel inspired and I know how pretentious this comes off as. But something about it bugged me through the whole thing.

Now all of you can defend this game saying But part 2 is coming!" That doesn't matter. This is a review for the product being sold as-is. And honestly I think it's a pretty lousy deal. If Act 2 is really so great then let it prove itself. Act 1 is simply mediocre."

reviewText:
Edit: Act 2 has been released a while now, but i can safely say I don't feel like going back to this game. It sounds as if I would have to play act 1 all over again just so I can understand stuff in act 2. And Act 2 doesn't sound worth it. So, yeah...

The awkward moment where steam tells you when you purchased the game, rather than when you last played... X(

I bought this game without any prior knowledge of the kickstarter origins of Broken Age, and I feel that this title supports my arguement for NEVER backing a game through kickstarter, unless you like throwing money at something which may never happen. There is always a risk when giving money to someone for something that doesn't exist, and I think a lot of people have unrealistic expectations, and unfortunately in this case, it was the people making the game that didn't plan and budget ahead.

I bought this game in a steam sale not long after it was offically realised, which was the best choice at the time, as I had heard a bit about the game and was excited to play it myself. I played through act 1 and expected a few months wait for act 2, as this is the norm with most multi-part titles. How wrong I was. Over a year later, I am still waiting for act 2. I can't imagine how annoyed people must be from backing this game from the start! However, the signs for problems ahead were there from the beginning.

Having only just bought the game, I started looking through sites to see if there was an expected release date for act 2, only to find an article which stated that the profits from act 1 meant they could go on and fund act 2. I was horrified! I had no idea that this game was not even funded for the second part. I had no idea that this game wasn't even supposed to be split into 2 acts in the first place. But I thought to myself, oh well, it might take a little bit longer but I can wait. Update after update, deadlines came and went for act 2 to be released. I think this is what really got to most people. The waiting wasn't the problem, it was the promises that were broken that made people upset and lose faith in Double Fine as a developer. How can you trust someone with your money if you don't believe they know what they are doing? If someone who has 30 years experience in the games industry can't budget for a full game, then we are all doomed! Unfortunately for us, its too late to take back our money or get back our trust. This is the true lesson to be learned from this experience: Research, research, research! If something looks too good to be true, then it probably is!

I feel that some of the fault in my buying this game has to fall at Valve's door. The steam page for Broken Age is very misleading, as it gave me no indication at the time that this game is kickstarter funded and may never have been finished. And, even now, it is impossible to tell from the steam page that this game is not finished! This is why I have written this review, to give people the knowledge of the situation surrounding this game, so that someone else can make an informed choice over whether to purchase this game, I choice I didn't have.

So, I guess you want to know a bit about the game, huh? Other reviews can tell you more, but the basics are: It's a point and click adventure that follows two very different main characters, with the option to switch between characters whenever you wish. Its a pretty looking game, with amazing voice-acting and simple puzzles.

Is it worth almost £20? No. Act 1 took me about 3 hours (I got stuck for about 30 minutes because I'm bad at video game logic :P), with act 2, if and when it appears, to take another 5 hours. I'm honestly not sure I will play act 2. It has been so long since I played act 1 that I will have to replay it all from scratch. And really, there are SO many other games I could be playing, I may never experience this game as it was supposed to be played. My advice: Wait until both acts are out and grab it in a sale. As the second act is currently not out, I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

A real shame.

reviewText:
It has taken me a day to mull everything over, but I think I'm ready to put an opinion out there, so here it goes.

I loved it. I will probably play it again as soon as I have time. The art was well done. The dialogue was genius (as expected). The voice acting was better than I could have hoped for. The story... the story was hands down the best adventure game story I have ever encountered. I spent a good chunk of time today just thinking and wondering about different parts of the story, what they mean, and what will happen in Act II. When a game's story gets me to actively engage it even when I'm not playing, it's a damn good story. I am sitting here wishing I had Act II in my hands already because I want to know what happens.

Now, the reason why it took me a little while to say this:

I don't consider myself a genius when it comes to adventure games. I expected to get at least 5 hours out of Act 1. When I finished it in under 3 hours, having exhausted every dialogue option available along the way, I felt as though the puzzle difficulty should have been higher or that there should have just been more puzzles. I was honestly a little irate that somebody like Tim Schafer would make the game so easy, considering what he has done in the past.

I currently still wish the difficulty had been a little higher, but I've started to understand why it wasn't.  Point & click adventures are known for their DEVIOUS puzzle design. When you're only playing a game puzzle to puzzle and getting stumped at every single one, it is more satisfying to solve them, but that satisfaction comes at the cost of the storytelling (which is and definitely should be the main focus any P&C adventure game). The purpose of the puzzles, however, is not just to make a story interactive. The best designed puzzles give you little nuggets of the story while presenting an interactive, stimulating challenge. Not every puzzle in Broken Age did this, but a lot of them did. If this quality makes for less contrived, more logical and consequently easier puzzles, then so be it. A great example of this is the use spoon with cereal" bit that

reviewText:
Huge Tim Schafer fan. Monkey Island is by far my fav. point and click adventure game and overall love all his work.
I got this game through the kickstarter which got me extremely excited when I heard he is making a new adventure game, especially since he has 100% full creative control, no publishers.. AWESOME!

That being said, this is a good game... It's slightly below my expectations, I don't consider it to be AMAZING, however I do think it's fairly good.

I've been following their documentary that covers the development of the game and since I also am a game developer I fully understand (and I was expecting) that they ran into financial and deadline problems. Especially for a point and click game where you have to basically build the engine yourself if you want anything decent, since it's an unpopular genre nowadays.

The game has small problems here and there like various depth issues when it comes to certain animations, and also the game was dropping frames for me when I was using an item to interact with something. (Keep in mind that I'm playing this before it's officially out on steam, so they will probably fix these problems by then)


All those problems don't affect the experience, however I don't feel like the experience comes anywhere close to Monkey Island or Grim Fandango. That's probably just me being nostalgic.. or playing too many games and being desensitized.

But if you are a Tim Schafer fan or just a point and click adventure genre fan, this is worth getting. It's an old genre game with beautiful graphics. I say in the end, it's worth it.

reviewText:
I will recommend this game, because I am a fan of point&click adventures, and because it has some funny moments,
But overall it is as average as they get.
I finished the Act and didn't feel much entertainement throughout. The puzzles are extremely easy, it is more about searching each scene thouroughly and pushing the story forward than solving anything, the story itself isnt particularly engaging, and this is quite problematic when it comes to adventures games since the story is the heart of the game and genre.

It can be an ok experience for most, but do not expect a memorable one, not by a longshot,
Voice acting is good, visuals are just ok. Passable game at best.
Im surprised that such a game can cost as much as it did, I struggled to find a justification for it.

Play it as a passtime, but there are much more epic adventures to embark on in the genre.

reviewText:
* Updated to contain Act 2 and represent the whole game *

Overall I'm glad that I backed the game, it did take more time than they thought and it did came out in two parts but as a whole I feel that it was money well spent.

Let's start with the good:
The art is great, they have used this style very well. The soundtrack is amazing and also the dubbing with several celebrities (Elijah Wood, Jack Black, Wil Wheaton and others). The story is pretty interesting and I enjoyed revealing it bit by bit, playing some time as Shay and then as Vella, it's useful when you get stuck on a puzzle to switch to the second charater.
As I hoped the second part took me longer to beat and overall Steam says that I played the game about 15 hours, I took my time, although the actual time should be a bit less it's still a nice amount, the average time to beat should be about 10.5 hours or so.

And for the bad:
I kinda hoped there would be a bit more to the story and somwhere in part 2 I could guess where it goes.
Most of the puzzles where fine but there were a couple of kinda hard to guess puzzles that really took me time to figure out, one of which was a really bad choice in my opinion and I'm sure that many players got stuck in that place, it was kinda annoying and I decided to use a guide just for that one puzzle (still not sure if I'de get that one without it! they needed to add some kind of hint there, I was just clueless on what I needed to do next and wandered around the screens looking for a hint).
Also some puzzles were a bit tiring (fetching things, going from one place to another and back again several times etc'), mostly on act 2.

To sum it up, as I said I enjoyed the game overall, I'm happy that we got the game but indeed it could have been a bit better, the first part was shorter and easier but more interesting and fun to play. Still if you like adventure point and click games you should give this game a try, I thought it was worth the 15$ I paid for it, but you can get it on sale for much less (lowest so far was 6.24$).
I hope Tim will be up to the task of creating another original P&C game in the future, we need more of those! :)

reviewText:
What can I say?  Tim Schafer has done it again.

Broken Age is an enjoyable point-and-click adventure with the right mix of character dialog, puzzles, and humor.  This all leads into decent character development throughout the game, and sets up the ending of this First Act perfectly.

The dynamic of shifting between the stories of two characters worked well throughout the game.  The two stories were balanced in terms of content, and I really didn't favor one over the other.  While it's important to play and appreciate both stories you aren't forced to switch throughout most of the game.  This allows the player to enjoy each story and character independently, and not be arbitrarily ripped out of the experience.  I enjoyed being able to switch between the stories when I wanted to, without consequences.

And the ending of this First Act?  I won't spoil it, but it's brilliantly executed and memorable.  It certainly makes me look forward to Act Two.  As far as which story to finish first, I will say that I finished Shay's story first and found the ending very profound.  It was truly an 'OMG' moment where the two stories merge, and suddenly everything makes sense and shocks you at the same time.  Please take your time and enjoy both stories before you get to the ending, as you'll appreciate the results.

I highly recommend Broken Age to both fans of point-and-click adventures and first-timers.  Tim Schafer and Double Fine have delivered a high-quality experience that is well worth the money.

reviewText:
This is a brilliant game.
A great throwback to 90s lucasarts adventure games. I avoided buying it for a while because I'd heard people moaning about it but I'm so glas I bought it as it's such a delight.

The first half's puzzles are great but a little easy and the second half if perfect. I really wasn't sure how to solve some of them and was stumped for a while but when I figured them out I was relieved to find they all had logical reasons to them.

That's just how an adventure should be. I know some people don't like the challenge but if you breeze through it without having to stop, go away and think outside the box then it's just an interactive cartoon.
Wonderful characters, witty dialogue, gorgeous music and a delightful art style.

I don't usually leave reviews but I really liked this and thought it an underrated delight.
Thank you Double Fine!

reviewText: This game is fantastic

reviewText:
Though Broken Age acts as a return to Double Fine’s earliest adventure game roots, it’s also their largest and most ambitious project in years. But if anything, the added scope and possibility that exploded out of their hugely successful Kickstarter has only amplified their talents as a developer, giving birth to what seems easily capable of becoming the game that defines them as a studio.

But playing Broken Age, there’s never the sense that Double Fine has grown beyond the quirky, commercially unviable studio that I’ve loved for years. Broken Age as a game, is exceptionally simple and humble in its construction. It’s unmistakably a product of its creator: esoteric, humorous, and at times even a bit profound, but without the often rough mechanics and invisible cage of possibilities that shackled most of the studio’s prior games. It’s Double Fine in their purest, most unrestrained form, and if you’ve played anything the studio’s made I doubt I have to tell you how exciting that is.

It’s somewhat precarious to attempt to discuss Broken Age’s plot, both for fear of spoilers and for the fact it’s only half finished, but its themes are so strong and its writing on point that it’s deserving of more than a minor conversation. It follows the dual stories of Vella and Shay, two people stuck in vastly different situations but united by their shared lack of freedom, forced to blindly conform to the traditions and expectations of those older than them, unable to even question “why?”.

Shay is the sole human aboard a ship intended as humanity’s last chance at finding a new planet they can call home. Trapped in an endless isolation, he lives out his days following his computer mom’s orders, still treated as a child ignorant to anything outside his daily routine and sheltered existence.

Vella in contrast is a member of a village whose traditions dictate the sacrifice of several young women to the towering Mog Chathra during their annual maiden feast, or otherwise doom them all to its wrath. Vella is the sole person brave enough to propose they fight the beast, but is shrugged off as a silly girl who doesn’t understand the gravity of the situation.

These two plotlines fold into each other to form Broken Age’s main themes of rejecting the systematic lives their characters are placed in, and being brave enough to discover the world for themselves. It’s rebellion without anarchy; breaking out to find who you are, not out of distaste of the world, but a desire to make it better if only you’d be given the ability to think and act for yourself.

You could label Broken Age a coming of age story (in fact it itself does), but it’s so much more sincere than I feel that commonly implies. Its characters are delightful and lively and often absurd, but also fully developed in how they fit within their world. They fully embody their roles and proclaim them so effectively that it felt like I knew the people I was talking to, as if they had somehow taken on a life outside of the game. Even characters you see in only a single scene or who are given but a few lines of dialogue have so much personality and heart in their interactions that they transcend their small part into the larger world of the game.

Double Fine has always been a developer recognized for brilliant writing and characterization, but I’ve never felt as immersed in the worlds they created or as invested in their characters as with Broken Age. As bizarre as their circumstances become, I connected with Shay and Vella’s plight for freedom of their parental and societal shackles, and was as curious as them upon entering a new area and meeting its peculiar inhabitants.

For all I know act two could be a complete disaster. It could cause Broken Age to go down as one of the most disappointing games in recent memory and probably cause even me to think twice before checking out anything Double Fine puts out in the future. But for now, it’s sublime, beautiful, expertly pinned, and not afraid to wear its heart on its sleeve. As a huge fan of all things Double Fine, I’m finding it hard not to readily declare this their best work yet, which I consider no small praise.

Act II Update & Conclusion
Perhaps I expected too much.

It’s been more than a year since the first part of Double Fine’s Kickstarted nest egg first release, and since then the anticipation, unease, and in some cases legitimate anger have been steadily increasing to levels that beg the question just what this game means to people. It was one of the first hugely successful examples of using Kickstarter to fund games, as well as a callback to Double Fine’s earliest work and easily their biggest and most ambitious game in a long time (despite hav ing began as something far smaller). It was hard not to want to continuously give them the benefit of the doubt; to let them give it their all and assume Broken Age would come out the better for it however long it took. But for all the hype and impossible dreams of what Broken Age might be, we might have taken it too far. Or maybe Broken Age took it too far, and in my naive enthusiasm I went along with it. [...]

Final Word
I said at the end of my act one write-up that I could see Broken Age being the game that defines Double Fine. I still think that to be true, but unfortunately it isn’t as glamorous an image as I had first imagined it to be. Broken Age isn’t a bad game, nor do I regret playing it or wish to advise others not to. It’s impossible to ignore though just how uneven and weird the first and second act are. Broken Age seems to reflect a lot on its extended development and the detriment its model of funding and community feedback may have had on it. It began with an eagerness you couldn’t escape and the feeling that this couldn’t be anything but an amazing, and yet by the end it has lost a lot of its drive. It’s tired and drained, seeking to provide closure for those who have been waiting so long, but being unable to do much more.

Sadly I've reached the character limit for Steam reviews. If you want to read my full thoughts on act II and Broken Age as a whole you can find them on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
This game deserves to be played by absolutely everyone. If you grew up playing and loving the classic LucasArts and Sierra adventure games, this will be right up your alley. And if you didn't? Well, then you're in for a treat! The humour throughout is spot on, and I found myself smiling or laughing at nearly every turn and every conversation. The extraordinary Double Fine feeling eminates from beginning to end,  and the story will most likely captivate you and leave you guessing where it's going to head next.

Broken age is yet enother example of the amazing and peerless work that Double Fine keeps producing, and it definitely gets close to the level of quality that they have produced in the past, including their own Psychonauts as well as games from their LucasArts days like Grim Fandango and Monkey Island. The puzzles in the game never reach the absurd levels that the old classics could achieve, but I did run into a handfull of headscratchers along the playthrough. The good part was the ability to switch between the two characters if I got stuck, or wanted a change of perspective in the story, very similar to the mechanic from Day of the Tentacle.

Overall, I can't recommend this game enough, it is a masterpiece in the genre, and it's only half-done! I for one can not wait untill part 2 is ready. Judging from the absolutely amazing work Double Fine did on part 1, there's no chance in hell that part 2 will dissapoint. Mark my word.
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you've ever played a point-and-click adventure before, you will immediately love Broken Age. If you haven't.. consider this a great opportunity to be introduced to the genre of clever puzzles and storytelling. The art style is gorgeous and comforting, the voice-work is all spot-on, and the humor... well it's Double-Fine!

Act 1 presents us with two seperate, highly imaginative worlds that seem to have no relation at all, apart from the two protagonists' desires to lead their own lives. When you figure out the shocking relation between the two segments of the game, which can be played in any order you like (even switching from one character's story to the other's at any point you wish), you WILL be hungry for the next installment. You may even play through Act 1 all over again just to see the story in a different light.

There's a good reason this game was such an immense success on kickstarter, and I'm happy to say all of the time and money did NOT go to waste.

A must have for people, who like games with stong stories and/or adventure fans.

9 out of 10 :)

reviewText: After a bit of turmoil over their release structure (with the 'solution' being the two-part release), we now have the first half of Broken Age, and I must say, it was worth the wait. If you're a fan of the point-and-click adventure games of old (LucasArts games coming to mind immediately, as well as The Longest Journey), Broken Age is worth playing. The game doesn't have the length that some of the old ones had (assuming Act 2 is roughly the same length as Act 1), though that may be largely due to the puzzles being a little more logical than those in the older games were, so you spend less time aimlessly clicking on the environment and trying to use random items with each other in hopes of finding a solution, and more time enjoying the stylized art, amusing dialog, and interesting world.\n\nIs it a good game? Yes, perhaps even if the adventure genre isn't normally your cup of tea. Is it worth $25? That really depends on whether playing half of the game now and half of it later this year" bothers you... chances are you'll have the opportunity to get it on sale before Act 2 is released
date: so that might be something to consider."

reviewText:
so i just beat broken age.
it took me roughly three hours to do so.

i think i liked the game?  the voice casting and acting was excellent, and the story itself was pretty interesting. I switched back and forth between shay and vella after they reached major points in their respective stories, so for sure saw the ending coming from preeeettttyyy far off. theres a lot of good points but i also have like, i guess, some issues.  lets discuss.

artistically this game is amazing. every area you go to is beautifully rendered and the characters actually have a nice highlight layer that respects lights located throughout the level, so even though its technically 2D they still feel like they navigate a 3D world in a way that is subtle and convincing.  all the characters had a great feel, and each area you went to had a clear artistic theme that worked well and created a good identity for the individual characters and the world itself.  Each village Vella visited had a great sense of fashion that reflected their purpose in the world, and in Shay’s case he just had a whole bunch of amazing everything friends to hang out with.  That being said there are a few places where i noticed the assets looks pixelated and improperly rezzed, but it was infrequent and it was never an object that was important to the story.

the sounds design was great.  the music was very well done, and the variety of voice actors was pretty impressive and full of wonderful and recognizable people who really did an awesome job of selling their characters.

The characters were also great. Shay’s friends were are hilarious and the way they interacted with him when on and off duty was entertaining.  The people in Vella’s world were also pretty interesting, although they all blindly love Mog Chothra which would get old if not for it being an integral part of the story, so i guess i don’t mind? It kinda bugged me that all the female characters in Shellmound were super ditzy and shallow though.  This could have been subverted by making one of the temple guards a dude, as their shallow nature ends up being a gag, but all the girls who were offered to mog chothra and the two temple guards kinda just blend together.

the gameplay was pretty standard point and click stuff, and the puzzles themselves were rarely very challenging. to be fair i’ve played point and click adventures for like, my entire life as a gamer, so these things are kinda second nature to me. there were some design choices that were a little strange - like the snake. why is the snake there? it is a dead end and misleading. there was no reason to get past the snake, and as far as i coudl tell, no way to get past the snake. why is there a snake?

the story itself was pretty interesting, and how the two stories come together is pretty obvious, but i cant fault the game for not surprising me with it’s plot twists.  Shay’s story is interesting because it all happens in a very small scale - he explores the ship to do a thing.  Vella, on the other hand, goes on this big winding adventure around her world (but really only like 3 locations).  Her story seems like a race against time, while shay’s seems far more casual and meandering.

overall though my biggest complaint is in the story.  it took me three hours to beat the game, and at the end of those three hours the story gets interesting.  the whole game is building up to this specific point (which again, is pretty easy to see coming if you like, you know, know how stories work) and when it finally happens the game ends. imagine, dear reader, that you are watching star wars, and just as luke gets on board the millenium falcon the credits roll.  Technically, yeah, you know luke is like off on an adventure, and leia needs to be rescued but NOPE. you’ll find out about it later.

I know that tim put out an apology for making the game too long and how he wanted to release SOMETHING because its been what, 2 years since the kickstarter? and so the game was split in two parts so we can play half now and half later.  but to me, this felt like maybe 1/3? speaking from my other P&C adventure experience: telltale games released a new season of sam and max every 2 years. each contain 5 episodes that take roughly 3 hours on the first play through - about the same size and substance as part 1 of broken age. they also cost the same amount of money. for 5 episodes released every month, instead of 2 released i guess like 6 months apart? they haven’t really been clear on when more is coming.

i know each studio has its own way of creating games and i’m not trying to say double fine should have made me more game, but i just feel like in 2 years and with 3 million dollars i was going to get something a little more substantial.

broken age is pretty good. it didn’t blow me away, but i enjoyed playing it. i look forward to part 2, whenever that gets finished  but like, if i am being honest, i enjoyed it more for the art and acting than i did for the game parts. the old lucas arts adventure games were challenging and engaging and really shaped my sense of humor and love for adventurous stories. the dig and monkey island will be with me the rest of my life because they impacted me in a big way.  act 1 of broken age is not memorable or impactful in the same way.  so i’m looking forward to episode 2. because episode 1 is great, but pretty forgettable.

reviewText:
It took me a lot of stopping and starting to finish the first act of Broken Age. An interesting world with some fun moments, but overall a bit of a mediocre adventure game; one of the stories had pacing problems, and the other had serious structural and character motivation problems. Finally I managed to push through and was pleasantly surprised by the excellent ending to Act 1.

It was on the strength of that ending (and a kind of masochistic pig-headedness) that I played through Act 2, which is a complete DISASTER. The puzzles are obtuse and nonsensical in the worst tradition of bad adventure games. The mechanism of switching back and forth between story lines to gain information is ridiculous in a story where the two characters cannot communicate (What, are they telepathic?). There's an entire elaborate multi-stage puzzle sequence where your progress can be completely reset by doing things in the wrong order.

This wouldn't be so bad if we had a goal, or some sort of logical progression of steps to be following, but for much of the second act I honestly couldn't have explained to you what the characters were trying to accomplish or why what I was doing would in any way help. This culminates in a series of actions that every piece of information you have indicates will lead to your horrible and gruesome death, without actually gaining anything meaningful.

A pointless, stupid, and frustrating experience. If you haven't bought this game already, for god's sake DON'T.

reviewText:
GET IT GET IT GET IT.
If you're a fan of old-school point and click adventures, get it.
If you're a fan of Double Fine and Tim Schafer, get it.
If you think it looks kinda kooky, get it.
If you've never played a point and click adventure, get it.
If you wanna see some of the power of crowd-sourcing, get it.
If you want to support the developers and NOT money-grabbing publishers like EA/Activision, get it.

Graphics: A lovely combination of hand painted models and a 2.5D engine.  It looks deceptively cartoony, but if you look closely you can see how well they've managed to mesh the dimensions.
Music: Creepy ambience and a fantastically subtle score.
Voice Acting:  Elijah Wood, Jack Black, Pendleton Ward, Wil Wheton, Jennifer Hale... need I say more?
Gameplay: Everything you'd expect from a point and click adventure; puzzles, dialogue quests, inventory management (that isn't done poorly), item combinations etc etc.
Writing:  I don't think I can properly comment on this yet, but it contains Schafer's typical comedic aspects with a hell of a lot of creepy undertones.

I've followed development of this game since it was announced on Kickstarter and I can happily say that with only a couple of hours play time, I already see it as money well spent.  Not only does it revive a 'dead' genre of gaming, it does it in a smooth manner that hopefully shouldn't be daunting to those that have never played a game like this.  Shay's opening sets up the story and teaches the player how to play these sorts of games flawlessly.  I find myself repeatedly clicking things just in case I missed something"
date: just like I used to do with Monkey Island.\n\nI'd love to have written a more concise review
recommended: but I am so full of feelings on this game right now that anything more will be unintelligible fangirling."

reviewText: I backed this game on Kickstarter, and I would have got my money's worth following its development even if the finished product wasn't particularly good. Fortunately that hasn't happened, and Act 1 of Broken Age is the most fun I've had playing a game designed by Tim Shafer since the last one I played! It's a beautiful game in every respect, the art and animation is wonderful, the music is of the highest standard, and the voice acting is excellent without exception. Really, as a demonstration of what a modern adventure game can be, there's no finer example. It's mildly amusing throughout, with a couple of laugh out loud moments. The puzzles aren't particularly challenging, although I did get modestly stumped a couple of times, having to come back the next day before the solution presented itself. Frankly, that's about my speed, but I still hope Act 2 is a little more challenging. Even if it isn't I would have had a great time. Overall a great success then, as far as I'm concerned. Like any good two-parter, the story ended on a suitable cliffhanger with some burning questions remaining unanswered, hopefully Double Fine don't take too long completing it.

reviewText:
Broken Age Act 1 is a beautiful adventure game where you follow two different people in storylines that feel quite different to each other. It's got an art style that feels quite unique, the voice acting is on the level of Shiny's Sacrifice - in other words high profile names doing their best quality voice acting giving their personas a very distinct character. The story is really well written and funny, and the world adds to that - there are also lots of hilarious things about both the environments and small side things happening.

Shay's story is like a teenager stuck in a spaceship where the computer treats him like he was still three years old, and the environments are full of props to that effect. Also, lots of things seems to be vowen, knitted of crocheted, like the yarn buddies, the arms of the computer, the warping effect when travelling in space, the present, the weaver etc. It's also quite heavily lampshaded. The story does a good work of giving the feeling that you as a character are bored and need to find a way to get out of the grudge while still not boring you as the player. It also gives you a great feeling of wanting to be doing something to help others.

Vella's story is the tale of a girl who is chosen as sacrifice to a monster to save the village, but who instead wants to fight the monster. The setting is such that nobody except her grandfather sees anything wrong with the sacrifice, instead seeing being sacrificed being a great honour, but you can see in it moments of despair about losing daughters or those daughters dying while still being an honourable sacrifice. The setting is more a renaissance faire with some fantastic elements to it, and a good lot of humourous dialogue.

What is the game missing? Well, in the LucasArts games of old, you generally had tasks like Monkey Island's sword fighting puzzle, where you first had to do an item quest, then you had to do a collection of lines, to eventually beat the Sword Master. It felt like you were actually achieving something by solving it. There were also moments in the game where you got stuck for a while and had to search for a solution, trying to figure the puzzle out. In here, the solutions are always really close by the problem, and there is no procedure to figure out you need to go through to solve it. There was not a single puzzle that made me stop and actually think about how to solve it, everything was obvious from the outset. The good thing about it though is that there is no pixel hunting, no missing items far away and having to backtrack, no banging your head on the table in frustration of not being able to get past a point and eventually dropping the game in frustration.

Despite those faults, the first act is storywise about as great as any point'n'click game has ever been, in looks, dialogue, humour and music it's spot on. The game throws a few screwballs at you, and I feel that depending on your game play order you will get a very different experience. If you play Shay's story first then Vella's story, you will suddenly get a shocking reveal that casts your actions in Shay's story in a very different light. If you play Vella's story first you will at the end of Shay's story get a different screwball where you at the end suddenly realise that an assumption you will probably make in her story's later part was dead on wrong, but not the shock of the reveal about your actions as Shay. If you switch characters at natural boundaries, and this is probably best done with playing Shay first, then switching when quest giver changes to Marek, and for Vella changing between Sugar Bunting and Merriloft, then Shay for the linear quests given by Marek, then Vella changing after escaping Merriloft, then play Shay to the end, then finally Vella to the end. The big picture of the story will be revealed way earlier, but it will not have any great reveals. It ends with a great cliffhanger that makes you really anticipate the second act.

If you wonder about the inspirations for the story, Tim Schafer has pointed to 1948 story The Lottery by Shirley Jackson, with a spoiler warning if you read it.


Over all, it's a very good and humorous story experience, if you're a lore fan you will probably really get into the game, but if you're looking for hard thinking nuts to consider, the puzzles of the first act will not give you full satisfaction, but I think you will have a hard time finding somebody that played the first act that is not eagerly anticipating the second act.



A warning though: Don't view any let's plays of this game, or you will spoil it utterly.

reviewText:
Having not played a point and click adventure since I was eight or so I found Broken Age to be quite enjoyable. The story is fairly entertaining and the puzzles fun.

There is a marked difference between Act 1 and Act 2. The game is quite easy in Act 1 while Act 2 is much more difficult. While a game getting harder as you play is to be expected (otherwise where would the challenge be?), it is not a gradual progression. The game goes to being fun for all ages to overtly complicated at a moments notice.

Though some of the puzzles can give you a migraine,; if you muscle your way though this is an enjoyable little game. It hasn’t rekindled my eight your old love of the genre but it was an enjoyable game that reminded me of why I loved and hated the genre.

While I wouldn’t advise purchasing this game at full price it is worth it in a bundle during a sale. My copy only cost $1.25 and at that price I certainly felt I received my money’s worth.

reviewText:
My review of Broken Age can be broken in two (pun!).

First, the bad: This is a very simple game that puts up only a ghost of a challenge. What's worse is that unsolicited hints come in like crazy, treating the player like a kid. I'd compare the gameplay to some of Telltale Games' easier fare (Wallace & Gromit, Back to the Future), but with the hint system on.

Secondly, the good; and there is a lot of that. This is a beautiful game. It's 2D, it animates like a flash game, but man is it the most gorgeous, eye-popping flash game out there. I've seen a lot of Lead Artist Bagel" Stapley's work for Broken Age in documentaries
date: but seeing it so crisp and clear in the game does his talent justice. The animations are also very fluid and charming
recommended: despite the limited technology.\n\nIn terms of story

reviewText:
I was one of the people who backed this game on Kickstarter years ago. I like point-and-click puzzle games for their stories, and Double Fine has done some other games that I've loved.

Broken Age was... disappointing. The review would have been rather glowing if I'd written it when we were still waiting for the second act to be released. But with the release of the conclusion of the game, it feels... lazy? The first act introduces two interesting storylines with colorful, interesting landscapes (Or, sort-of landscapes) to explore. True to P&C adventure games, you meet all manner of interesting, quirky people, and get to ask them all manner of interesting, quirky questions.

The second act offers... very little. For the most part you're revisiting the areas you saw before, but with the other character. Dialog options seem less varied and numerous, and puzzles begin to feel more like legwork than puzzles (Get X item that's on the opposite side of the game and bring it back to me).

The ending feels sort of lackluster, but it may simply be that it's a letdown after the outright grueling back-and-forth grind of setting things up required for completing the final puzzle.

reviewText:
Very brief comments because this game needs no more reviews:

The good is that it is beautiful, well acted, clever, unique, and solvable without hints.  It does not overfill your inventory, and it has Jack Black in it (briefly).

The bad is that the story gradually fell apart because you see so little about the real antagonists, and we all know the story was contrived to suit the split gameplay, not to mention the badly split development schedule.

The game is almost a 10 anyway, and probably would have been if they had developed it all at once and I had played it all at once. That also killed my opportunity to get many of the achievements on one run-through. They weren't in place when I played the first half of the game.

reviewText:
Broken Age is an old-school point-and-click adventure game funded through Kickstarter purely by nostalgia from fans that grew up with LucasArts games from the ‘90s along with Tim Schafer’s earlier works. For a very long time, Broken Age was Kickstarter’s poster-boy, all thanks to being the most funded project at the time. This meant that one small slip could potentially affect the way people perceive the risky-environment of Kickstarter projects in general. No wonder there was high pressure on Double Fine to deliver on their promises since they received almost $4 million in funding (which is almost nothing by today’s standards if it were funded by an actual publisher) in contrast to the $400,000 they were originally asking. The end result was split over two Acts, released approximately a year and half apart from each other.

With that said, what Double Fine delivered in the end is a wonderful adventure game with an interesting plot concept: a teenager by the name of Shay who is a prisoner in his own spaceship trying to escape from being babysit by computers he refers to “Mom” and “Dad”; and Vella, daughter of a family of bakers in a village who tries to oppose taking part in a traditional sacrifice to Mog Chathra, a creature known for devouring worlds. Two teenagers living in two different worlds, yet facing almost similar problems, eventually collide with one another. Although the story starts agonisingly slow, it eventually builds up momentum after two or so hours in and keeps you invested until the totally unexpected, nonetheless remarkable, plot twist near the end of the first act which makes up for any pacing issues encountered. I really dig the concept Broken Age is trying to follow here.

Additionally, compliments are to be given to the charming art-style. It is simply startling, albeit childish -- but that is its beauty, right? In fact, that is part of the story’s undertones. Sure, perhaps being an adult playing this might look silly, but from an artistic perspective it succeeds in capturing the aesthetics of a children’s storybook. It may not be what some people were expecting Broken Age to look like when the game was first pitched on Kickstarter, but I have no problems with it because Double Fine have done it very creatively. Likewise, while the humour might not be as memorable as in other comedy-oriented adventure games, Broken Age does not disappoint in this aspect either, all thanks to a couple of support characters such as the cutlery collective - the Spoon, the Fork and the Knife – whose dialogues and remarks never seize to be amusing. Throughout its duration, there are a handful of good chuckles to be had from time to time. Conceivably, I do not believe it was necessary for Double Fine to hire Hollywood actors as voice actors, but in the end they all did a solid job in most parts. Whilst there are minor moments where there might lack of emotion in the delivery of some of the lines, they do not break the immersion the game has to offer. And once again, Pete McConnell does a fantastic job on the soundtrack for this game, especially the three stellar tracks “The Lumberjack’s Cabin”, “Vella Wakes” and “Battle At Shellmound”.

If you read up to this point, then surely you may be wondering why I gave a negative review for something which, based on my comments above, sounds like an amazing point-and-click adventure game? Well, here is why, and it does actually break my heart to say it but:

Act 2 ruined it all.

Pretty much everything that is established in Act 1 is thrown out the window. The things we, as players, are to believe judging by how the story unravels in Act 1 simply do not materialise in the second half. In fact, the whole concept seems detached in places in Act 2. As far as the story is concerned, it becomes uninteresting and seems to go almost nowhere. Any new revelation either turns out predictable or unimpressive. And this may be due to a few major flaws which simply killed Act 2.

The most obvious crime committed here is the reuse of the same exact locations found in Act 1, with only Shay’s spaceship being “redecorated”. To me, one aspect of adventure games which sucks me in is the notion of exploration; finding new locations and meeting new interesting characters to advance the plot, aside from solving challenging puzzles. Desolately, that is not the case here. Simple as. In reality, what bothers me the most might not actually be the reuse of the same locations in the end, but rather all the fetching for items. In this part of the game, it did not click with me because it is a chore. But hold on a second, fetching for stuff has been in adventure games like this for decades? Yes, but the problem here is when you ultimately realise that most support characters are nothing more than “mechanical” characters. Paying close attention, almost none of them have any influence over nor take direct part in the story. They only exist there artificially for either Shay or Vella to retrieve a specific item from them to solve a certain puzzle. So this makes you stop investing time in caring for them, as characters. Also in regards to the puzzles, Act 1 is indeed a breeze for adventure veterans, so it is almost impossible to get stuck at any point – which in a way I do not think that is necessarily a bad thing at all. All puzzles, although pretty obvious, feel logical in Act 1. On the other hand, Act 2 bumps up the difficulty and takes some risks in being creative with some of the puzzles, but the end result is a mixed bag. Contrary to what other people say, I give Double Fine credit for the wiring puzzle in terms of creativity because it actually made you think (and no, it is not as hard as some people claim it to be – just time consuming). I only wish it was not as frequently used in the last quarter of the game and more intuitive, but stuff like the snake puzzle was badly implemented; waiting for a puzzle to solve itself? But yeah, most puzzles in Broken Age basically boil down to asking the right person for the right item and that is you more or less done. Sort of.

Comparing the two acts, it feels like Act 2 was either rushed or made up while they were going along (as in it was not planned out at the same time with Act 1), or both. The charm and humour are still intact in the second half, but everything in terms of plot, characters, concept and some puzzles took a major hit by some bad design choices. Plus, just when you think Act 2 would redeem itself by the end, Broken Age ends in an anticlimax which raises more questions than providing all the answers. Simply put, the writing is poor in Act 2, and it seems like poor management could have been another factor here.

In conclusion, Broken Age is a visually beautiful and well-crafted game where all the passion was clearly injected a lot more in the first act, but all its potential is completely ruined by its second act plagued by poor writing and some bad design choices which reduces it to no more than an adequate adventure game at best. Broken Age could have been the next big thing in this genre, and Act 1 is a valid gauge, but when modern adventure games like The Book of Unwritten Tales or even the more retro-y Blackwell series (as a whole) exist and provide a (subjectively) better and more fleshed out experience, then you know that something went wrong at some point in your game. Broken Age is still worth at least one shot thanks to its promising Act 1, so long as you lower your expectations in the next act. If so, then this still is a good starter for anyone new who wants to delve into point-and-click adventure games. Otherwise, for old adventure fanatics, I cannot really recommend it; easily skippable thanks to Act 2. To be honest, I could have also easily given this a neutral review if there were such a button on Steam.

I am still looking forward to Double Fine’s next project, but what a bummer coming from Tim Schafer.
