reviewText:
Lacking the charm, intelligence and writing of some of the better point-and-click games of the past decade, this seems to be a rather lackluster experience and one of the worse written games that came out of Tim Schafer’s production company.

The bad:
-A really lackluster story; and seeing how the story seems to be the game’s focus, this is saying a lot. A good setup for a story that starts out strong but turns out to be quite a mess in both character’s cases. Either lackluster or just completely stupid twists thrown in for good measure.
-Completely simple puzzle solution that most people probably won’t even want to think about. Use everything with everything wins the day here; and even then it is just way too easy to advance.
-Really bad, sometimes grotesque humor. Characters seem to try to be funny, but fail miserably most of the time. While some lines are worth a few chuckles, this does not come even close to some of the amazing writing and humor of other games of the genre like Sam and Max or the Monkey Island series.
-Short. Very short.
-Just really bland characters in general. Some of them can be entertaining, some of them even memorable, but most of the time you will just get thrown more and more characters onto your face without them having any sort of character development, interesting traits, stories, or anything else that would make them stand out.

The good:
-If you like how point-and-clicks work, this is a fairly clean UI that works well.
-Graphics are interesting, but obviously might not be for everyone’s taste. It has a unique art style though, and is visually interesting, so that should be noted.
-Voice acting is mostly really good.
-The atmosphere, especially at the beginning of the game, is really well presented. The game might make you feel uneasy, and even if it doesn’t, it presents its world very well at the start. Sadly, this somewhat falls off as the story progresses, and by the time you hit the end of Act 1, you will notice that the best part of the game was actually the beginning.

In general, it is a game that is hard to recommend to anyone. Horrifyingly short, quite silly mess of a story, uninteresting characters for the most part and just a lack of anything great besides the interesting art style and good voice acting make this a game that only die-hard fans of the genre or Tim Schafer’s games should check out. The rest might want to wait for a sale or just skip it completely.

reviewText:
++ Charming characters and amusing dialog, as expected from any Double Fine production
+ Competent voice acting
+ Not-bad story.  Not great, but good
- Tumblr nose.  In fact, the only likeable thing about this game's art style are the backgrounds
-- Extremely short;  Act 1 only took 4 hours to complete, and word has it there's only going to be an Act 2 after this.  Unless Double Fine really digs in and amps up the elements of what makes the adventure game genre great in the forthcoming Act 2, I wouldn't recommend this game.
--- The most significant negative:  No challenge at all;  this adventure game has the easiest puzzles" I've encountered in any point-and-click to date.  I'm not saying it should be Sierra-level difficult
date: but it's not unfair to expect a few good head-scratchers once in a while.  Alas
recommended:
there were none.

Verdict:  Not Schafer's best.  I know he can direct and produce a better game than this.  Play Psychonauts and Grim Fandango instead.

P.S.:  If Act 2's development makes a 180 degree turn and ends up being awesome by not repeating Act 1's more egregious mistakes

reviewText:
I might recommend this game, yes, but at this point, only if it's on sale.
The game is over fast. We're talking 5 hours gameplay at most, with little or no replayability.
It's well written, but there drama doesn't work as it's supposed to.
The talent is great.
It's a very, very pretty game.
The soundtrack and special effects are amazing.
The game is very very easy at times.
There's only one bit where you're completely stumped, but you can work it out with enough time.
It's an ok game, but there are parts where I think a movie would work better.
I was all excited for Shay's (the guy from the future) story, but honestly, it's so simple I think a movie would have worked out better. There's like, one puzzle with different parts in it, and it's not complicated or hard, it's just tedious.
This is not the best adventure game of it's time, at least, it isn't yet.
The price isn't worth it. for this amount of money, I could get Machanarium and still have enough money left over to get another cheap one, that would not only have more game time, but would also have more replayability.

The game feels like a letdown for me at this point.

reviewText:
There are certain animated children's movies that strike an emotional chord, which compel adults to keep watching them over and over again.  This game manages to capture that emotional chord.  I'm sure kids will love it, but there's something special about the story that will draw in adults and make you feel something.

The scenes are gorgeous, as is the music.  Controles are simple, and the puzzles are challenging enough without forcing you to figure out, say, how to connect your chicken to a pulley.  If you're a point and click puzzle adventure afficionato, this game will be easy.

Reading some of the negative reviews, I'm surprised how much dislike there is for part two.  Personally, I really enjoyed getting to revisit locations as they change and watching the two main characters get to know each other indirectly.  The puzzles got harder in part two, but given how easy they are in part one, that's not a bad thing.  You get to see all the characters you've met earlier change, develope, and grow.

In terms of plot, the one thing I wish would have been changed was part one.  I felt like there wasn't really time to establish Vella's character the way there was for Shay.  I had a very strong sense of who Shay was as a person in part one, but since Vella's story was so driven by her adversity to the obstacles around her, it wasn't really until part two that I began to get a sense of her personality beyond being willing to stand up for herself.  It would have been nice to have her do some small puzzle unconnected to the maiden's feast to define her personality to the player, before her adventure started.

I'll admit also I bought this on sale, so I didn't mind so much that it was short.  (I took my time and it lasted about 14 hours.)  Never the less, I will definitly be replaying this game, just like I rewatch Toy Story and the Iron Giant.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Being one the people who got this game gifted after the second act came out, I think I can give it a look that isn't sullied by backer's disctontent. So let's go and try to do it.

The game starts off great - you got 2 pretty different characters in rather different settings going on about their rather unusual daily lives. The world is bizzare, characters are colorful and voice acting is great, music score while nothing spectacular does compliment the tone of adventure very well, so it really drags you in for the first 1 or 2 hours. At that stage puzzles are almost trivial and you spend more time listening to dialog and exploring the world, rather than getting frustrated filling out charts and solving equasions, it feels like you playing a lighthearted interactive movie more than playing a game.

After about 4 or so hours in, with a bit of twist at the end, 1st act of the game ends and unfortunately what follows it up is one big mess. Act 2 is pretty much a dissapointment in a variety of ways - you meet next to none new characters, 95% of the locations you will visit are rehashes of the old ones, the plot unravels itself but leaves holes and doesn't really give a satisfying ending to the story. One important thing to notice about second act is the difficulty of puzzles - it racks up in a big way, so much, you would be excused to think devs have tried making second act feel longer by making you spend majority of the time scratching your head. Main strengths of the game so far: characters, dialog, bizzare setting, fade out at this stage in favour of trying to figure out what's the trick behind another wiring puzzle. It really kills the mood of the whole story and leaves a sour taste in a mouth.

At the end I feel troubled recommending this game, for even though I still managed to squeeze some fun out of it, I also didn't have to spend any money, which made me far less judgmental. Since it doesn't really doesn't have interesting satisfying puzzles, or at least a decent enough ending to the story, I urge you to purchase this product at your own discretion, for it can really get your hopes up only to crash them down and leave you feeling dissapointed.

reviewText:
You know you've got a great writing in front of you when the game has a boy and a girl as the main heroes, yet there's no attempt at a love story whatsoever.

The colourful characters, delightful and original art style that might need a little bit of getting used to, excellent voicing (Jack Black!) all lead to a memorable experience.

This is the only quest I can recall where even when I've figured out some solution, it's worthwhile just to walk around interacting items with other characters just to hear their often brilliant responses instead — and the difficulty was just right.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed this game.  Well, actually, story with puzzles.  I liked that most puzzles were not too difficult, but enough to make it fun. (Remember the wiring!  That will make sense the first time you play and realize you paid no attention.)

The story was deeper than I thought it would be and, happily, longer than I thought it would be.  Don't let the unusual art work deter you.  It is more sophisticated than it seems from the previews.  It fits well with the story and I enjoyed this.

As for playability, I've played through once so this is from a one-time play-through perspective.  Let me put it this way, if you enjoy reading a story, setting it aside for awhile and then reading it again, you could replay and enjoy it. If, however, you are a person who reads a book once and never reads it again, you may not enjoy playing it again.  But I bet you enjoy playing it at least once.

Though the story seems to be set, the fact that you are allowed to solve the problems in your own time, and some interaction is done differently, I think you could play it more than once.

I definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Supremely entertaining and gorgeous
Richly-imagined and lovely worldbuilding, characters and story. Great twists, hilarious dialogue with brilliant voice-acting, funny and clever puzzles, so much charm and attention to detail, and looks and sounds absolutely beautiful with its painted imagery and orchestral score.

In the game you get to switch freely between two likable young teenage protagonists in very different worlds, rebelling against a system imposed on them, and as the player advances their storylines they can begin to see the connections between them and use that to get them to help each other out.

Vella has the 'honour' of being offered as a sacrificial maiden to appease a monster attacking her village, but she decides to fight back instead. Shay has grown up on his own on a spaceship programmed to serve his every need and coddle him, and decides he needs to break free and try to make a real difference.

reviewText: The game was delivered in to parts - Act I and Act II. If you play the game fresh without knowing that it'll immeidately become obvious though because Act I is full of beautiful art and storytelling and puzzles thar are creative but overly simplistic. Unforatunately the designer took heed of the massive complaints on the ease of the puzzles in Act I and apparently vowed to fix that in Act II. He did.  Act II continues to use the same wonderful intuitive UI and fantastic art and music but the puzzles suddenly jump from a small part of the overall game to stupidily hard. As in - even if you have a walkthrough telling you exactly what you need to do it's still tricky to solve. To make matters worse most of the puzzles in Act II have no rhyme or reason to why you're doing them. Luckily you'll be rewarded with a mediocre story and ending.

reviewText:
Terrible ending = terrible.

This game had a lot of promise, act 1 set up the premise of two teenagers strugging with the situation thrown at them, one with an overbearing 'mother' isolated on a space ship while the other is rebellious of the paccifist nature of the sacrificing madiens ritual to the 'mog chothra.'   Then act 2 came along and slapped us across the face, not only by poorly completing the tale but giving us a really lame ending that makes you feel like you've accomplished nothing.

With all the money pooring in this game you'd think i'd be more than eye candy, but sadly that's not the case.  The puzzles themselves were, okay I guess, except the ending puzzle in act 2 the wiring the robots puzzle can go straight to hell.  It's even worse that if you dont memorize the pattern for them, and progress to a point of no return, you can softblock yourself and have to start over from your last save file because you can't remember the formula to solve the rewiring puzzle.  All in all this game is dissapointing, not a bad game, just dissapointing, you might want to skip this one.

reviewText:
My impressions at length, if you're not sure why I reached this conclusion: http://xander77.livejournal.com/27144.html

Also, your steam playtime counts the time the game spent paused while alt-tabbing. I have in fact played through the game once, and it took about 7 hours of actual playtime.

Part 1 was a nostalgic, traditional (charming) point and click adventure. Part 2 is very much not.

The puzzles in part 1 were very much typical, nostalgic point-and-click adventure puzzles that could be solved by talking to everyone and clicking on everything. They were mostly logical, congruent with their setting, and solvable by understanding how the locale in which they are found works. The puzzles in part 2 are puzzle game" puzzles for the sake of puzzles (does puzzle look like a word anymore?)

reviewText:
If you've ever heard of a game being Kickstarted, you can thank Broken Age for it. It was almost two years ago when Tim Schafer decided that he wanted to make another point-and-click adventure game, and he wanted the internet to fund it. Needless to say, it was a resounding success, and for a while all we wanted to talk about[thenexus.tv] was games on Kickstarter. The first half of Broken Age is out now, with the second half coming later this year.

The game is split into two different stories, with two different protagonists: Vella on the left, and Shay on the right. Once you choose one of them, you start their story, but you can switch between them at any time. I used this once when I got frustrated with a puzzle I was having trouble with.

Vella's story starts off in her village, which is made up entirely of bakers. Every generation they have the Maidens' Feast, where several young women are offered up to a big monster called Mog Chothra so it won't destroy the village. Needless to say, Vella is not thrilled about this and decides to fight back. Her adventure takes her to a couple of other villages, one that just had their Maidens' Feast, and another getting ready for its Maidens' Feast.

Shay on the other hand lives a pretty boring life: he's been living on a spaceship his whole life, and the simulation missions the ship throws at him have gotten pretty boring because they were designed for a toddler. Eventually he breaks out of this rut and discovers a whole new part of the ship that he has never seen before, and some real missions to embark on.

Visually the game is gorgeous. Everything looks hand painted, and in typical point-and-click fashion the camera is usually fixed, at most moving left or right as you move around the environment. There were a few places where I thought the textures looked low-resolution, but honestly it wouldn't have made much of a difference because of the art style.

Mechanically it plays almost exactly like a point-and-click from the 90's. Or at least that's what I assume because I wasn't doing much video gaming in the 90's. All of the puzzles" involved finding a specific item or combination of items to use in a particular way in a particular place to solve a problem. Most times it was pretty clear what needed to be done
date: and failing that just a little snooping around would uncover the solution. There was that one time though where the solution involved going back and forth through several areas to get different items
recommended: and I completely did not understand what I was supposed to do. Yeah
hoursPlayed: I looked up the solution to that one.\n\nOne of my favorite things about Broken Age is the voice cast. Having people like Elijah Wood
voteText: Jennifer Hale
helpfulPercent: and Jack Black in the same game is delightful to my nerd brain. And Wil Wheaton playing a hipster lumberjack hiding from the talking trees was the best moment of my week.\n\nIt took me just over four hours to complete Act 1

votesTotal: because Act 1 is a good length to finish in one or two sittings. This is one of the few games I have played that is appropriate for both adults and kids
votesFunny: so if you are a parent check it out. It's a little hard to name a good price because I have no idea how good Act 2 will be; if it keeps up the quality that Act 1 had
commentsCount: I would say that $20 is a good price."

reviewText:
The first half had a ton of potential... the setting was awesome and mysterious, and you followed interesting characters through interesting places and events.

The second half follows cardboard cutouts of those characters through... the same places and no events at all really, up to a climatic battle, all the while requiring you to break the fourth wall to solve inane puzzles.

Before act two, I would have pushed anyone I know to buy this game.  Now I'm wishing I didn't have it.

reviewText: I wish Steam had an option between positive and negative.  I didn't HATE this game...it had some things going for it like gorgeous animation, spot on voice acting, and a few times it genuinely made me laugh.  The ending of Part 1 was so fantastic and I utterly did not see coming.  But then in part two it wastes no time in bulldozing everything interesting about the first half and turning it into a very different much less interesting story. It almost felt like a betrayal. Nothing is really explained, there's plot holes big enough to fly a space ship through, and worst it doesn't even have much in the way of an ending rather then just stopping.  A good puzzle is the kind of thing that's challenging, but when you finally figure it out makes you go oooooooh!".  These puzzles were not like that.  Some of the solutions were unbelievably obscure
date: even for a point and click adventure game.\nSo while I can't say it's the worst thing I've ever played
recommended: based on all this it really just left me unsatisfied and wishing for it to have lived up to the potential the first half presented."

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game.

Act 1 is short, fun, and whimsical. Its puzzles are easy, which allows you to explore the beautiful environments and meet all of the interesting characters without too many barriers in your way.

Act 2, on the other hand, is just a frustrating mess. The entire act merely retreads the areas visted in Act 1, which removes the element of exploration that makes act 1 interesting. Worse yet, a lot of the puzzles are just ridiculous. Obvious solutions never work, and the actual solutions often make no sense in terms of why they would work or why the characters would try them. I've spent hours going through the levels clicking everything and trying to use my items on every object, and this is a common trend among players. For some puzzles, you have to go to the other character's perspective in order to find the solution, but the game never tells you when this is required, and it goes counter to everything you've done in act 1, so you might go through entire levels looking for answers that aren't there.

After Double Fine spent over a year developing act 2, it's such a disappointment to see recycled environments and puzzles that are just badly designed and badly thought out. Perhaps those problems might be more forgivable if the quality of the story made up for it, but it doesn't. Despite the brilliant setup in act 1, neither of the two main characters undergo much if any character development in act 2. Instead, we're treated to a bad science fiction plot which tries to explain the superficial elements of the world, and yet still leaves many questions unanswered in the cliffhanger ending. The villains expose themselves as something out of a children's cartoon, and some of the dramatic reveals only make sense if you don't think too deeply about act 1.

This game is a huge disappointment to me, and thinking about it still leaves a bitter taste in my mouth. If you want to see the interesting environments and the story that could have been, watch act 1 on youtube. If you must, watch act 2 on youtube as well. The game itself is absolutely not worth playing.

reviewText:
If you want to play half a game; by all means buy this game. I have been waiting forever for Act 2 of this game, and when it came I was disappointed beyond belief. This game was going so well, the storyline was perfect, there was good humor! Yet, when this final act of the game finally came out I wish it never did.

Storyline:
The storyline in Act 1 was perfect. It had the perfect setting with the perfect amount of humor. Act 2 completely obliterates all of what you know and love of the original setting and storyline (and not in a good way). To add to this; humor is less present and even when it is it is poor. The characters in Act 2 are so disconnected it isn't funny. I began to ask myself Why can't I meantion this to that person?" questions. There are so many things any logical person would tell another if they were in Shay's or Vella's position; but they aren't options. It feels like most of the dialog was thrown together without anying logical thinking in Act 2.

Puzzles:
Act 1 took me quite a while to finish but Act 2 took  forever . Act 2's puzzles are more of a chore than an enjoyment. I tried for  three hours  to finish Act 2 without cheating; but it was inevitable. I finally looked up a guide and had to use it basically the rest of the way. Even after I got past my struggle; the puzzles were still basically impossible. Act 1 required no transfer of knowledge between characters or to write anything down. I loved Act 1's puzzles because I didn't have to write anything down; I could actually figure out the puzzles without a paper in an enjoyable and slightly difficult way. Act 2 you suddenly need to write things down. Act 2 you also have to take your knowledge of one character's environment to anothers: this is horrible! While other games have done it
date:
Act 1 did not. This should not have been just thrown in like that for Act 2.

Overall:
I have lost all love for this game as a whole. I can never give this game a positive vote with the way Act 2 has been made. I loved this game so much when it was just Act 1; when it had a storyline

reviewText: I'm not sure that this game feels like a traditional point and click adventure to me. There is no really difficult puzzles, no pixel scanning with the cursor and no revisiting areas and dialog trees over and over again, causing that all familiar frustration that comes with most point and click adventures. I know from being a backer and watching the documentary that Tim Schafer wanted to avoid this type of frustration and he certainly has achieved it. At the expense of more difficult puzzles? Yes. But that's not a bad thing. I kind of do wish they were just slightly harder, but truly I am not that bothered at all.\n\nInstead, this game is smooth and fun to play". reviewText: I have completed the first act, and I have to say I am very pleased with what I have seen thus far of the game. The art style and animation are top notch. The game play is pretty limited, and the puzzles are relatively easy (which could be a good or bad point, depending on one's point of view). The story does have me engaged, and I am very much looking forward to its continuation. Without spoiling the game, I'll say that I thought I had the game figured out, only to have my pre-conceptions blown apart by the end of act 1. If you enjoy the adventure games of old, and were more into them for the story than the puzzles, I can't recoommend this game highly enough. If you are the sort that could care less about story and want gameplay however, I'd look elsewhere.

reviewText:
So I was slightly dismayed by the price point initially, especially with the reported length of ~4 hours, but I did not initially realize that this game is using an episodic structure. If you are at all familiar with Telltale's adventure game work over the past few years- Tales from Monkey Island, The Walking Dead, The Wolf Among Us, the Sam&Max games... so you're buying not only the game, but an unknown number of future acts in addition. Judging by history, you will probably get your money's worth by buying in on this.

As for the game itself... initially I was expecting pretty much what I got; something silly, cute, and DEEPLY ♥♥♥♥ed up on a psychological level (as I fully expected and hoped for from something from the mind of Tim Schafer!). However... once I got to the end of the act and the plotlines were finally tied together, the ♥♥♥♥ed upped ness" reached a whole new wonderful level.

If you have enjoyed ANYTHING in Tim Schafer's stable of products... Costume Quest

reviewText:
I have to say that playing Act I was fun and did remind me of the olde adventures of the past.

The artwork and music are both stunning and extremely well done, and the voice acting is pretty great with Elijah Wood, Jack Black and others making the game feel well put together.

Unfortunately, Act II is repetitive, boring and frankly feels like a cheap rip-off of Act I.  The scenery is almost identical.  The wiring puzzles are a pain in the proverbial (so much so I resorted to checking walkthroughs online) and the whole thing feels smashed together into a big pile of useless goo.

I, like many others dropped $35 or more on this as a backer. I am thoroughly disappointed with it.  The wait was way too long and I still would like to know how something this poor could blow away millions of investment from backers so easily.  I miss games like DOTT, and this certainly doesn't compare with those high standards at all.

A true shame, really.  It could have been so much better if they'd changed the scenery (secret rooms in Mog, other locations for Shay for example) and thought outside the box about the puzzles, but so many are too complex or obscure, or simply too easy, to enjoy.

reviewText:
This game as whole was a great experience, wonderful art direction, wonderful music, Alot of the puzzles were great, although some were difficult, but not impossible (plus every playthough changes a aspect of some specific puzzles in order to keep it difficult each time).

The concept of two stories going at the same time was very well done, at first it felt very seperate, but as time goes by you notice that what you see in one side can help you with a puzzle in the other side, and I believe that was very clever.

Story wise though, overall it could have been better, mostly for the ending, but it still was good, had a few good twists and it kept you thinking through out the game. Although from the looks of it alot of people did not seem to like the ending that much and thinks the game as a whole was horrible due to that. For me the journey is what matters and man that was a great journey. Plus it had a few cute ending credits pictures to get a good idea what happen after the game.

Overall it was great and I recommend anyone to play it. As long as they don't care about the ending bieng a bit short in delivery.

reviewText:
The saving grace of this game is it made me stop buying half baked games like this one in the future.

I used to trust Double Fine to prouduce content, after enjoying their first few games and after seeing this being the most well funded game in Kickstarter history I decided to give it a go.

The cost to live comfortably in San Francisco is around 5000$ a month, while in Ukraine it is only 300$ a month.

I'm not saying that Schafer should have made his team move out to Ukraine, just that it's something to be reminded of.

Besides that it's only about 4 hours of content, which I'd be okay with if the story's ending felt concise.

Anyway none of that really matters when the game isn't finished, for all intents and purposes it deserves an early access" tag."

reviewText:
[OLD REVIEW: When only the first part was out]

Now to the actual critisisms of the game. The game is incredibly short and since this is supposed to be about half of the game, I am very worried for the total length of this game when it's complete. The puzzles are very simplistic and straight forward which means that the story, characters and enviroments is what has to be good to carry this game.
And they are. The game oozes of atmosphere with great characters, great enviroments all realised with a beautiful artstyle. The story is also good so far but I can't put down a real opinion there as the game is not finished.

[UPDATE: May 02 2015]

The second part is now out and I have to say that the game all in all, is a disappointment. The first thing that is important to mention is that there are very few new assets or anything new to experience in the second part. All characters and enviroments are reused although re arranged and modified a bit to be the setting of the new story and the story in it self is not very good. It doesn't make much sense and the end doesn't manage to satisfy in any way.

The length of the game, as I was afraid of the last time I reviewed the game, is indeed very short and is mostly hold up by some puzzles that will take a long time to figure out. This is because the difficulty spike in the second part is enormous. While the first part was way too easy, the second one can be frustratingly hard. All in all there is one word I would describe Broken Age with and that is disappointment. It might be worth to play if you catch it on a sale for the art and atmosphere alone but otherwise, stay far away from it.

reviewText:
I liked this game. I think? It's complicated, okay!

Well, it isn't that I can't recommend this game. I would, to certain kinds of people and I know for sure that they are out there, it's just that I wouldn't to the majority out there. But let's get into this because as I said: It's complicated...

Let's talk about the mechanics first.
It's your standart Point'n'Click Adventure. Inventory system's a bit wonky but it does its job. Collect items, drag and drop, solve puzzles. That's about it.
The only new and interesting thing - and the one that drew me to it in the first place - is that you switch between the two main protagonists and experience the world from their points of view. They didn't really do anything with it mechanic-wise until Part 2 though, so up until then it was only a gimmick really. But a nice one. I enjoyed switching between charakters every other puzzle and it helped to paint a better picture of the world and its story, in my opinion.

Oh, story. In theory I should love this game. For me narrative is more key to a great experience than mechanics (a blend between the two being the perfect game") which is why I enjoy games that do focus on it more than I do "skill-based" ones. Adventure games typically one of the genres that shine in that regard.

And the story to Broken Age is interesting. Well
date: the ending of Part 1 that is and some of Part 2 up until its rather anticlimatic finish.\nAll in all it's a story of coming-of-age
recommended: paralells and juxtapositions between the protagonists drawn rather well. All characters are likeable

reviewText: Back in the day I played plenty of point and click adventure games, and I really enjoyed them. I'm not sure what I was expecting going into Broken Age, I guess I assumed it would be better than it turned out to be. This is just not my sort of game I guess, I just didn't find it at all entertaining or compelling. The story is incredibly weak in my opinion, and I was under the impression that was supposed to be the strong point. The artwork is really nice... But that does not make up for the lack luster story and uninteresting plot. Apparently millions of dollars went into this, but I fail to see where it all went. There are better games in this genre, made for far less money. But considering kickstarter made the game profitable before it was even released I'm not really surprised. Broken Age is not a bad game, its just not at all what I would expect from a title with such a massive budget and exponential waves of hype. I'm just not satisfied with it. And I can only recommend it if it goes on sale, $5, $10 if your interested. I just don't feel its worth $24.99.

reviewText:
I bought this game during the summer sale, and it was well worth the VERY LOW price I paid.  Unfortunately, I cannot recommend it for the full retail price.  So why do I recommend this game, anyway?  Read on...

First Impressions
The first thing you will notice are the well-scripted animations for each character.  The art style is quite appealing to the eyes, and fluidity between actions is definitely there.  The game is played by switching between the perspectives of a young man (Shay) and young girl (Vella); I started my playthrough as Vella and was instantly sold on the story.

Game Structure
The game is split into two acts, and for me the first act was more story-driven, while the second act was very puzzle-driven.  As I mentioned, the story is pretty good and I always wanted to uncover more, but the climax and ending fell short of my expectations.  The second issue I have with the game are the puzzles, which I will explain in more detail...

The Puzzles
Ah yes, the puzzles!  If you go and read discussions (SPOILERS IN THERE) you will find that many people are complaining that the puzzles for this game are way too hard to the point that they are moon logic" puzzles.  I somewhat disagree.  During my first (and only) playthrough I found that the solutions to two particular puzzles were very farfetched and even said aloud to myself in both instances
date: "who would ever think to do that?".  Near the very end of the game is a third puzzle that is actually very complex and difficult to solve
recommended: but I ended up enjoying it since I had some pen and paper ready for notes.  This third puzzle alone easily took me about an hour to complete and is the puzzle that many people complain about.  In my opinion
hoursPlayed: some of the other puzzles were more confusing and tedious.  All-in-all
voteText: I liked the mix of puzzle difficulty and adventure
helpfulPercent: but I have to admit that I used a walkthrough on more than one occasion when I felt stuck (which is hard to do if you don't want to spoil the rest of the game).  So
votesHelpful: if you are not super casual and have the patience to spend an hour or more on a single problem
votesTotal:
then you will most likely enjoy this game.

Recommendation
Now for the reason I cannot recommend it for the full retail price of $25: a very bad ending.  Everything up to the very end of the game answered enough questions to keep me thoroughly entertained.  However
votesFunny: once you complete the game you are left with a series of images on the credits screen that fill in the final bits of the story.  It helps explain what people ended up doing once the story has concluded
commentsCount: but it fails to answer many questions about the final scene of the game.  I had so many questions about the origins of Mog Chothra
column16: the Plague Dam
column17: Sugar Bunting's past (as Steel Bunting)
column18: and why the Volta's and Alex had to be tricked.  Also
column19: the concluding scene never explains how the attack is abruptly stopped
column20: why the whole operation had to play out for "as long as anyone remembers"
column21:
and what happened to Vella's grandmother or why she was in Sugar Bunting.

My Final Judgement
If you can buy this game on sale then it is probably worth it
column22: even if the ending is not that great.  The game had enough charm and other positive qualities for me to recommend it
column23: but I would not have bought it if I had to pay $25.\n\n/Review"

I am not that good at point and click adventures yet I love the heck out of them... I usually have to find the answers to the puzzles on the net after the first few... with that said I found this game to NEED ALMOST NO SKILL AT ALL... the puzzles are so simple they give away the answers. I kept waiting for the tutorial to be over... but it never got any harder... there was nothing that took me more than 5 min to figure out and 90% of the game I did without even having to think out the puzzle since it was so obvious...
The game IS beautiful and the story IS interesting but it’s so short it had me reading the Steam return policy to see if there was a time limit in which I could return the game because it was over that quick...
Steam shows I have 3 hours in the game total and about an hour of that was the game on pause to make dinner... I see NOTHING about this game that says 3 MILLION dollars was put into it... I am very disappointed and feel ripped off. Maybe if the game was finished or maybe if it didn't COST $25 dollars? This is a $9.99 game at best... I mean you get 2 to 3 hours TOPS with BOTH story modes and there wasn't much else for side quest or exploration... such a letdown. I will be finishing it when the update comes out only since it’s free... if I could return it and NOT finish it later I would... I knew I should have just watched a let’s play instead of buying it but with all the RAVE reviews I thought how could I possibly go wrong?" Well it did...

To sum it up this "game" is WAY TOO SHORT & WAY TOO EASY to be a $25 dollar game... and it has almost ZERO replayability... I still to this day break out Monkey Island and give it a run though on my tablet every now and then... I just don't see it with this game... unless they wow me with chapter two... I really got to ask WHERE DID THE MONEY GO?

reviewText:
Almost one and a half year ago I praised this game for how interesting the setting was in Act 1: a boy trapped in a spaceship that doesent want him to be in danger, and a girl who haves to be sacrificed to a monster to save her village, but she's the only one who wants to fight that monster.

In act one the story is so well driven, and the puzzles are fair and logical. Also most of the characters are very funny and interesting, but sadly very straight forward with little no backstory.

Still, with such good premise, great art style and amazing plot twist at the end of Act 1, you expect that Act 2 would be a thrilling conclusion to this throwback to a different Point and Click era?


Well, too ♥♥♥♥ing bad, because after one and a half year and 3.5 million dollars we got a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ending put togheter with spit and feces.

The whole mistery around the plot made no sense, Shay's campain is all about finding some objects, that can really take 30 minutes at best (let's be honest, is way more fun to play with that guy then the other uninteresting character) and let's not mention that to complete some puzzles there's no logic: you're gonna need one clue from one of the two character to complete the other, thing is, they literally have no ways to contact with each others, not even telepaticly, and this is never explained through the whole game.

The villian is just pathetic, same for his explanations, that have little no sense.

This is just one angry fan talking about one and a half year of waiting and promises, and mostly expectation since this haves the work of Tim Shafer written all over it, the same person who created Psychonauts, Grim Fandango and Brutal Legends. I really had big hopes for this, now, I don't think anyone will trust any of his projects.

reviewText:
You've likely already heard a lot about Broken Age as it's been covered in a lot of media... Long story short, it's the adventure game that was publicly funded using Kickstarter, the man behind it is Tim Schaefer (of Full Throttle / Grim Fandango / Psychonauts fame), and was touted to be a revival of the adventure game genre.

Whether they've succeeded seems to be open to personal opinion, with the majority that don't agree disliking either the art style (which you can see in the trailer and screenshots, and I think is gorgeous), or that the puzzles are too easy. I'll come back to that point in a moment.

The game itself is charming and always interesting. There are two protagonists, you pick one at the start and begin to play through their story. They are in completely different worlds (one science fiction, the other fantasy), and you can swap between the worlds to experience the other's story at any time. This gives you the opportunity to take a break and return with fresh eyes, or just mix up the pacing. These two separate story-threads do start to show hints of coming together towards the conclusion of the games first act (whilst act two will release later this year as a free update).

One thing the game doesn't have is particularly tricky puzzles. It is worth baring in mind that as only the first act of two so far, the second act has been promised to have more difficult puzzles when it launches. I don't think the puzzles are SO simple to be insulting, but you certainly won't be stuck on any puzzles for longer than a couple of minutes. Most solutions are readily apparant with a little thought, and there's usually enough clues through the environment or the character's comments that you soon realise what needs to be done.

I fully recommend it for anyone who enjoys a good story. As an adventure puzzle game it's a little on the easy side, but the story-telling, dialogue and superb voice acting, setting and music all make for an interesting experience regardless. If the second act has harder / more complex puzzles that's a bonus, but I personally feel there's enough to enjoy here.

(Full disclosure, I backed this game on Kickstarter for $30 / £19)

reviewText:
Having just finished this game I can say it was enjoyable, but I debate if this game is worth the 24 bucks they are currently selling it for. I find it frustrating that there is going to be a second act without an determined release date. I feel It would be worth it if both were released at the same time. But until then I would say wait. I know that the second act is going to be free, but it still feels odd, its like buying a season pass for a game but not knowing what you are going to be getting out of it, or when.

But there, that was my complaint about price, not substance. This game is a real gem, everything is hand painted,  and the way the animations work with that make the game instantly nostalgic. Its like a living cartoon. I showed this game to my 1 1/2 year old niece and she was instantly entranced. So the art is captivating and impressive. The voice acting in this game is great, it is splattered with famous actors. Like another review stated saying that the spoon in this game has more personality than most other characters in other games. I feel a lot of the big charm that hits you at the first of the game wears off a little bit after the first few minutes. It's not that it goes away, but the game becomes less captivating as I went along. But this is a great game to mess around with. View it like a film and then you won't be dissapointed in the time that it takes to complete it. plus add in the second act of the game and that should add 2 or 3 hours to the 2 hours it takes to beat the first act.

I do have to add that this game has complete support for tablets and that is really cool. I keep on trying to find games to play on my dell venue 8 pro, and this one works perfect. My only complaint about the interface is that I couldnt get the hint button to show up on my desktop, it would only show up on my tablet. So In a way this game is better played on a tablet.

Well, basically I would say hold off on this game for now, its not worth the full price just yet, when the 2nd act comes I would say that it would be worth it. I just don't completly understand why the people making this game can get away with selling this game for 10 bucks on the ios store, but sell it for 25 on pc. Its the same game, litterally, there are no differences or cut backs between the versions, except possible the 8 bit mode, but I have not looked into that since I don't own an apple product. This game would be completly worth it for 10 bucks and feels more of an appropriate price. But again I am getting into the price to much. As a game alone this game is great fun, it has such attidute that is easy to get sucked into. The world they establish just feels so strange, and when I say that I mean any one playing can sense something is up. It keeps on teasing that not everything is not as it seems, but it really lets you figure that out instead of just giving it to you. Might sound weird but it was worth it for the minute that I got to jack blacks character in the game. This game will make you laugh, and at the same time squirm trying to figure what its about.

reviewText: As soon as Tim Shafer revealed this on Kickstarter I backed immediately. The old Lucasarts games such as Monkey Island 1&2, Day Of The Tentacle and Grim Fandango are among my favourite games ever created and so I jumped at the chance to play a new adventure game from the same mind involved in those classics. I was not dissapointed. The writing takes on a different mood from his previous efforts in this genre and is less about side splitting humour and more about telling the story about the tragic lives of 2 seemingly unrelated teenagers with drastically different lives. That's not to say there are not funny moments, some of the humour is genuinly brilliant. The visual style is the thing that struck me most about this game though with it's amazing storybook visuals which look amazing when the characters are animated on screen.\nAt the time of this review only act 1 is available and comes in at around 4 hours long. I can already say my money was well spent and cannot wait for act 2. Tim Shafer and Double Fine have knocked it out of the park with this game.

reviewText:
You've likely already heard a lot about Broken Age as it's been covered in a lot of media... Long story short, it's the adventure game that was publicly funded using Kickstarter, the man behind it is Tim Schaefer (of Full Throttle / Grim Fandango / Psychonauts fame), and was touted to be a revival of the adventure game genre.

Whether they've succeeded seems to be open to personal opinion, with the majority that don't agree disliking either the art style (which you can see in the trailer and screenshots, and I think is gorgeous), or that the puzzles are too easy. I'll come back to that point in a moment.

The game itself is charming and always interesting. There are two protagonists, you pick one at the start and begin to play through their story. They are in completely different worlds (one science fiction, the other fantasy), and you can swap between the worlds to experience the other's story at any time. This gives you the opportunity to take a break and return with fresh eyes, or just mix up the pacing. These two separate story-threads do start to show hints of coming together towards the conclusion of the games first act (whilst act two will release later this year as a free update).

One thing the game doesn't have is particularly tricky puzzles. It is worth baring in mind that as only the first act of two so far, the second act has been promised to have more difficult puzzles when it launches. I don't think the puzzles are SO simple to be insulting, but you certainly won't be stuck on any puzzles for longer than a couple of minutes. Most solutions are readily apparant with a little thought, and there's usually enough clues through the environment or the character's comments that you soon realise what needs to be done.

I fully recommend it for anyone who enjoys a good story. As an adventure puzzle game it's a little on the easy side, but the story-telling, dialogue and superb voice acting, setting and music all make for an interesting experience regardless. If the second act has harder / more complex puzzles that's a bonus, but I personally feel there's enough to enjoy here.

(Full disclosure, I backed this game on Kickstarter for $30 / £19)

reviewText: Holy crap, where do I start on this marvelous game?! Ok, this masterpiece came from the brilliant mind of Tim Schafer, the King of point-and-clicks, who hasn't made a point-and-click adventure game in over 16 years. But he still has it! Broken Age tells the story of two vastly different, yet eerily similar, young people, Vella and Shay. You can play whoevers story first and alternate between them, in case you are stuck on a puzzle, which I believe is a brilliant mechanic. The visual art style is absolutely gorgeous and the characters are well developed. The gameplay is, well, point-and-click and if you aren't a fan of this, the game won't change your opinion on it. However, absolutely everyone should play this game, it puts multimillion dollar triple A" games to shame and I can't wait for the second part! (FYI the game is split into two parts
date: the first is out right now
recommended: but the second is coming out later this year as a free update)                                                              I'm giving this game a 9.7/10."

reviewText: Part 1 review: I liked this gentle scifi comedy. I've heard of complaints that the puzzles are too easy and I'd disagree, though unlike some games, if you use the spanner and then the bucket on an item to try to solve a puzzle, it will often give you a hint that you need to use the item on the bucket then spanner, rather than keeping you guessing at every possible combination for hours on end. I liked the riddle, mainly because I didn't have the item in question and only by working it out did I know where to go to solve it.\n\nPart 2: the problems definitely ramp up in difficulty and, though I liked the challenge, I have a beef with some aspects of this. MINOR SPOILER AHEAD Several problems rely on using information one of the characters you control discovers with the other, but, in some cases, there's no way the information could be passed on. Sort of like a game in which a person in England in the 1870s discovers a diary entry which gives the combination to a safe which is then used by a character you control in the revolutionary America. No internal logic to justify the transfer of information. They might at least have hinted at some sort of telepathic link between the two or something but if they do, I missed it... This irks me. Possibly unnecesssarily, and the rest of the game is great, it's just that this makes me go Hmmmm. A lack of care in game design.

reviewText:
I don't know quite how to feel about Broken Age. I want to scream and yell and claim it is a terrible experience, but I don't overtly hate the game. I had a partial bit of responsibility for bringing it to life (funding it way back when on Kickstater). As much as I want to say that I helped make this, I'm mostly ashamed that I got sucked into the marketing that Double Fine did.

When Tim Schafer had claimed he was going to make an adventure game in the vein of his classic titles, I didn't quite expect him to literally do that. I figured we would have years of advancement in technology and storytelling play a bigger role with the finished product. I expected this new adventure title to do away with some of the more frustrating aspects of the genre's origins.

Instead, Broken Age is a mess of a second half that fails to capitalize on the potential set forth in it's first act. The setup to this game is brilliant; two teenagers coming to terms with the way their lives are playing out. You have Shay, a boy who has only ever lived on a spaceship, breaking free and looking for adventure. You also have Vella, a young girl in a town that believes sacrificing maidens" to some monster is the only way to protect their village. Vella is obviously a maiden and has to deal with the fact that she will die.

This plays a lot like most people's adolescent years; the game deals with how one can make their stake in the world. Instead of accepting that nothing will get better and the world is all gloom and doom
date: these characters venture beyond their comfort zones and explore the world outside.\n\nThe puzzles may not have been the most mind-bending things around
recommended: but that was excusable for the beginning of a game. You never want to throw the hardest thing at a player right off the bat; using a gradual curve to teach the player how the game works and makes their mind adapt to your particular puzzle schemes is a great way to ensure the gamer is left satisfied.\n\nInstead
hoursPlayed: Act 2 brings about some creatively bankrupt scenarios. The game essentially goes on auto-pilot and solutions take no longer than 5 minutes to pop in your mind. Maybe this has more to do with me being a veteran of the genre
voteText: but Broken Age does away with a lot of needless items that used to plague the inventory of it's predecessors.\n\nIn doing that
helpfulPercent: though
votesHelpful: the game's puzzles focus purely on logic. With logic at your side
votesTotal: you simply need to look at the problem
votesFunny: check your limited supply and have at it. Eventually you get to the solution and your brain doesn't feel any smarter. At worse
commentsCount: you feel cheated out of a quality experience.\n\nThis also happens to the story. Each character
column16: before some insanely convoluted twist
column17: felt like a person with no understanding of their situation. They knew they wanted change
column18: but they weren't sure from what. Come Act 2
column19:
we're now supposed to accept that these characters know each other and have some emotional tie (thankfully not romantic).

Couple that with some other revelations about Shay's life and you're left with a portrait of a boy who looks selfish. That feeling of complacency he wanted to break from feels more like it was self-imposed instead of happening out of bad luck. Vella's family also deals exceptionally well with the knowledge of their old tradition being a farse.

The final puzzles of the game are also some of the worst I've ever had to play. You better like wiring robots and depending on omnipresent knowledge to get through; Broken Age features that in spades. Just quite how Shay should know a pattern that Vella is only able to see is beyond me.

I get that the idea was to have players make the characters interact with each other in an asymmetrical fashion
column20: but the execution feels haphazard. A better approach would be if Vella touched something on the ship and then Shay's world changed a bit. Other games have done this and it works great in making the player feel like their actions matter.\n\nFor that matter
column21: why do we only get a few limited areas? Vella goes through the area Shay explored in Act 1 and vice versa. I know this is supposed to make players get acquainted with their environment
column22: but it feels exceptionally cheap. It harkens back to the classic days of adventure gaming where memory was limited and hardware limitations needed to be worked around.\n\nI can only think of Monkey Island and how that game had 4 Acts that all took place in wholly unique environments. The sequels managed to make their worlds bigger
column23: too. Broken Age just feels like developers starting off with ambition and rushing to make their promises half-true.\n\nWhy not bring up the the voice acting? While the cast is assembled of some great actors and their performance in the first act is quite good
column24: the revelations we get in Act 2 should elicit more of an emotional response. Instead
column25: basically everyone reads their lines in a deadpan manner. I think I'd be screaming bloody murder if I got locked in a ship I previously thought was a monster.\n\nYou can tell most of the budget was spent on the visual style
column26: because the graphics are beautiful. Everything animates smoothly and transitions feel natural. I'm a bit torn on the slow camera
column27: but it does give you a great look into the detail of each scene. It's like looking at a living water color book; it's whimsical and jovial.\n\nBut for as much charm the visuals have
column28: the rest of the game just cannot hold up. I may be taking this especially hard as I had wanted this game for nearly 3 years
column29: but I just get the feeling that Tim Schafer and Double Fine got in way over their heads. Their initial budget was a mere $400k dollars. For them to gross around $3 million before the game even came out is obscene.\n\nThen again
column30: I guess we gamers are partially to blame for the lack of quality. We all funded this with nostalgia on our brains. We loved Schafer's previous work and just wanted him to return to a genre he had long left behind. Broken Age doesn't make me believe that adventure games are dead
column31:
just that Tim Schafer should probably turn his prospects on to something else.

We can never get back the past; this is a harsh truth we all learn in life. Broken Age could have been about just that. The premise starts off with a similar idea and then abandons it for familiar territory. If only Double Fine had listened to their own preaching and learned to grow over the course of this games development.

5/10"

reviewText:
When I bought a game written by the great Tim Schafer, creator of legendary game Psychonauts among other things, I really wasn't expecting to be let down by just about EVERYTHING the game had to offer. An pair of two intriguing stories running parallel to each other suddenly shift into a single story that loses all intrigue by the end of it. The plot, which seems to have so much potential at the start, becomes so incredibly uninteresting by the end that I only felt obliged to finish the game because I'd spent money on it.

The main characters are bland, unintelligent, and seem to have very little interest in anything happening around them, even when possibly faced with their own demise. The settings, while interesting, are small and will only hold your interest long enough for you to realize how little world-building Double Fine has done with the world they created, and will leave you wishing they put some actual effort into them. And the gameplay: It's a point and click adventure game, so what little gameplay it has can only be based on the puzzles. Almost all of them are too easy, being tasks that a 5-year-old could figure out, or they're so obscure that you'll either need a walkthrough or a bottem-less well of patience as you click on every interactable thing in the game in every possible order, searching in vain for the thread of logic the developers were operating on.

To top it all off, the game ends with our two protagonists finally meeting after an entire game being seperated. What happens then? Nothing. They see each other, say nothing to each other, and the credits roll. No real resolution is reached either, as the antagonists (who were introduced very late on, I might add) were neither truly defeated, nor were they even properly explained beyond some very forced exposition.

Do yourself a favor, do NOT buy Broken Age. Save your money, spend it on a better game like Psychonauts. That way you can see that Tim Schafer actually had some talent at one point in time before it suddenly faded and he started putting out garbage like this.

(PS: The only saving grace this game has a a few key side characters, the majority of which are SILVERWARE. Seriously.)

After pre-paying this game through a steam sale for $10 and waiting for the second half to complete the game, I can safely say that Broken Age is not worth buying.

Story: Act 1 presented a clear theme of defiance since the protagonists of the story yearning to break free from their own culture respectively and tackle a conflict in their own respective worlds. Act 2, on the other hand, tries its best to answer the players' speculations (or guesses about the lore of the game) from Act 1 but only to end up with more head scratching and confusion that makes you want to say How does this makes sense?" or just "What?". I'm not going to spoil the ending but the second half's story just feels like it's just wasting your time but the game is obligated to finish the writing.

reviewText: This game took me back. It's fortunate that I waited for both episodes to play, since the wait between them put so many people off. Now that it's one complete package I think it works fine.\n\nThis is a good example of why episodic games can either work or fail. If episodic means you tire everyone out, it hurts your game. If it means everyone is thrilled by a cliffhanger by the new episode, it helps your game. I am recommending this now, but I think breaking it up hurt this game, and I think that is unfortunate. It's still a gem, and Double Fine has an opportunity to learn from their mistakes.

reviewText:
ACT 1: Two teenagers trying to figure out life and trying to break from what's been imposed to them in order to be free to follow their own paths. Characters are likable and relatable. Inspiring, lovely, moving, brilliant!
ACT 2: Evil aliens and a lot of going back and forth (without a fast-travel-map) fetching items and puzzle-solving to save your lives. Not only did they fail to explore further the main theme of Act 1 but they also threw it in the trash. And spit on it! Boring, frustrating, uninspiring, irritating!

Visuals and voice acting are fantastic, and you can make analogies with issues related to oppression, racism, gender. One thing I liked is that the black female character is more important and relevant than the white male character (usually you'd expect the male-white-character-is-the-hero-and-saves-helpless-girl cliché).

Even so, I don't recommend the game. I could maybe recommend only Act 1 and the feeling of wondering what Act 2 could have been rather than actually experiencing it. But if you play Act 1 you won't believe they could actually ruin the game and you'll want to play Act 2. And it doesn't feel right to recommend something that can cause such frustration...

reviewText:
With charming art and animation, together with stellar voice-acting, Broken Age is an enjoyable adventure.

However, the combination of a somewhat lackluster story and puzzles that sometimes become quite head-scratching does deflate the experience a bit.

Occasionally the story gets a bit interesting with the two protagonists' experiences mirroring each other. Also, while the story itself isn't very deep, the characters that you meet along the way are well-written and often funny. While never causing me to wipe tears of laughter from my eyes, Broken Age often made me smile.

If you're looking to enjoy lovely visuals, well-written dialogue and excellent voice-acting, this is the point'n'click adventure for you. If you're looking for an engaging and thought-provoking story, I'm afraid this game simply doesn't offer that.

reviewText:
Anyone just hoping for a fun, light-hearted point-and-click adventure with Tim Schafer's characteristically quirky writing will probably really enjoy this game.

I backed this game and was very, very bitter about how long it took, its funding issues, etc. At the end of the day though, the game itself (now that there's no wait between acts) is pretty solid and delivers most of what it promised to. All the characters have such great, entertaining personalities, the voice acting and directing is SUPERB and usually pretty funny, and the gameplay is pretty much what you'd expect from a point-and-click game.

The only negatives I can really think of are that some of the late-game puzzles can be a bit frustrating, and there are some minor aspects of the plot that either don't ever get elaborated on at ALL, or the explanations for them don't end up being all that satisfying or logical.

Still, it was a pretty fun ride and provided many much-needed laughs. Your first full playthrough may only take you 10 to 11 hours, not counting loading or paused time.

reviewText:
I was one of the original Kickstarter backers for this game and as such my first time playing it was when only the first half of the game was available and it was in Beta. At the time I enjoyed the part of the story that I was shown, the writing, art and setting are all wonderful. However, I found it to be short, straightforward and all of the puzzles were overly simplistic.

Recently the second half of the game was released and the game had it's official release as a complete product. I played through the whole thing again and found that the first half of the game works so much better when seen as part of the whole rather than as a separate episode. All the puzzles from the first half of the game are the building blocks for puzzles later in the game and they gradually increase in complexity. The storyline as well really builds on everything from the first half in the second half and the whole thing comes together in a very worthwhile and impressive package.

Because of that, this game should never have been split into two parts. I understand that Double Fine did this so that they could create a larger game overall and generate funding, but at the same time, the experience of playing it as two separate acts took away from the overall experience for me.

That said I do highly recommend this game now that it is available as a complete product. Be warned the puzzles are very easy and overly simplistic in the beginning of the game, and the whole thing can likely be completed in 8 hours or less unless you run into any major snags. All the puzzles had fairly easy to understand solutions with only 2 or 3 instances where I really felt that the solution was too obtuse. In addition there was only one time that I had to look up the solution online (SPOILER the part where Shay has to simply let the snake attempt to strangle him until it falls off, how was I supposed to know I just had to stand there the whole time? SPOILER) and there was one instance where the solution is only shown by switching between the two characters which I found annoying.

I recommend this for fans of adventure games, and also those who can just appreciate the writing and art style that Double Fine brings to the table. If you don't like adventure games you might still find this accessible due to the simplicity of the puzzles and the engaging story. Otherwise, stay away.

reviewText:
I... Don't know exactly WHAT to say.
I just finished the game and while I sympathize with many on a few issues in it (namely the background pixalation at times and the overly challenging Act 2 puzzles), I must recommend.

The story is incredibly charming, in my opinion. I didn't mind the development in Act 2 as much as others seemed to in their reviews. Maybe I'm blinded by how much I love Elijah Wood's voice acting, but I respected the growth between parts. Shay and Vella's development run in parallel to each other well, and I liked how you could always switch between the two mid-play to further them together. The main problem in Act 2 for me is how you eventually need player knowledge for both protagonists to progress. Something you learned as Vella you need for Shay's side, and vice versa. It removes you a bit from the immersion you should have with this adventure game, ESPECIALLY near it's climax (where this is occurs).

All in all, I give it about an 8.5-9/10. Somewhere around there. Buy this on a sale if you fear you may be disappointed by anything. Read around for more reviews to get an understanding of what irks people.

reviewText:
Okay so here's the deal. The first half of this game? Amazing. Second half? NOT worth the wait and a complete drag to pull yourself through.

The first half of this game throws us into two completely seperate worlds. The fantasy realm of Vella and the sci-fi world of Shay. Both are works of art visually and plot wise, with mechanical creatures covered in kid-friendly yarn and controls made out of baby toys to sacrifices to ancient monsters and snakes who hate the sound of tubas.

The characters are interesting enough, with plenty to say and the protragonists willing to chatter on about almost anything you click on. Plus the mid game reveal? It will have you on the edge of your seat.

Sounds good right? Then you get to the second half...

WHICH immediately strips the game of most of its most charming qualities, re-uses almost all the stages from the last half (there is only one new stage you really explore) and ties everything together with a rather shoddy villain collaberations which I really feel was a last minute descision.

Especially the fact that they plucked a character who had minor screen time in the first act and settled her into the villain conglamorate where they REALLY stuck out with how different their character design was from EVERYONE ELSE and reused the same exact lines they used during their limited screen time before rather than have the voice actor come back and at least change the inflection of the voice to be more dramatic.

Also the puzzles in the scond half are an absolute chore, there is a difference between a good puzzle, and a tedius one. Many of the puzzles in this game are defintely the latter in the second half, and also pull you out of the storyline as they require info from one protragonist be used with the other protragonist with no communication between them they just magically know the answer" due to you (the players) intervention.

All in all
date: if its on sale I guess get it but know that only half of the game is really worth playing and the final resolution will feel cheap and unfullfilling despite the first halfs quaint charm. Definitely not worth full price."

reviewText:
The puzzles of the first act is pretty easy, perhaps too easy. In the second act some of the puzzles were of the try-and-experiment sort that was fun to solve, but most of them were rather obscure with rather hilarious solutions, similar to Monkey Island. I really liked the part where I got stuck on a puzzle for a while and the main character started drawing up a table as a hint.

The story wasn't in-depth or thought provoking, and in fact had some plot holes, or twists that were quickly brushed aside. The big bad felt rather signle dimensional, and you couldn't even visit the big-bad-evil's lair, only watch cutscenes from it, making chunks of the game feel like a missed opportunity. Some of the object interactions were pretty verbose but that's more of a relic from old-school games. Now, that said, the writing was filled with junevile fun with heaps of jokes that didn't feel particularly wooden. Voice acting was phonomenal too.

The visuals were pretty and hadn't noticed/encountered any graphical glitches since the second act update. Animations ran slick as butter and had graphics had a well drawn painterly style. Music was subtle and well made, which helped set the tone of the scenes and set up an enjoyable environment but were hardly memorable.

So, now, you're wondering why despite the critisms I'm giving it a positive review? That's because I went into the game expecting a light-hearted and cheerful game, and got what I wanted. To me the great bits of the game outweighed the bad bits.

Is it perfect? No. Is it good. Yes.

There aren't many games like this and the only one I can think of is the Deponia series, but that game relies on being mean and offensive all the time, which just leaves a bad taste the further you go. Broken Age is *the* game you should pick up if you are looking for a light-hearted, point and click adventure game.

reviewText:
The knife was my favorite character.

As most Double Fine games, Broken Age is short but sweet (lol that's what she said; sorry for the joke but I'm not deleting it since I don't think anyone will read this review). The graphics and animation are damn pretty. Voice acting is good; particurlarly Elijah Wood as Shay. The story is slow at first but it gets better; it's no Game of Thrones or Breaking Bad though. Tim Schafer again writes some bomb-♥♥♥ dialogue; he's damn good at that (which reminds me that I should finish Psychonauts). Music wasn't anything special.

$25 for the full release is a bit much. I feel that the value of the game is more like $15, mainly due to how short it's going to be and how replayability won't be high. I kickstarted it with a $30 pledge, so I shouldn't be complaining about pricing. I should note that I am satisfied with my pledge and don't feel bad about backing this project.

I don't have much experience with point and click adventure games but the puzzles are not that difficult; I do realize that younger players might play this game too.

Overall, it was a nice experience with beautiful artwork, sympathetic characters, and not-too-difficult puzzles; (MINOR SPOILER WARNING) and I totally called the ending of the first act. (/SPOILER)

And since everyone likes number ratings: it's a 4 cupcakes out of 5.

reviewText:
Broken Age is a point-and-click adventure game that is the result of Double Fine's massively popular, record-breaking Kickstarter campaign. You alternate between controlling Shay, who is overly coddled by his spaceship's computer, and Vella, who is just about the only person who takes issue with human sacrifice in her civilization, and figure out how to help them battle injustice in their own way.

A lot of money went into this game, and it's easy to tell. The voice cast is star studded, with Elijah Wood doing an amazing job as Shay, and all-around great voice acting otherwise. The art has a beautiful, painted style. The orchestral music is definitely enjoyable.

As for the gameplay, well, it's a point-and-click adventure game. Some of the puzzles are tricky, but I never got completely stuck. The interface is pretty easy to use. All in all, it's a standard adventure game with modern design sensibilities.

The story is pretty interesting, and the game did a pretty good job of holding my interest. Act I is short, however, and at the moment, Act I is the whole game. It took me about five hours to beat. I really loved the humor, and Broken Age is full of it.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend Broken Age to just about anyone, and I'm definitely glad I backed it. The only real issue is the price, especially since this game is short. If this game looks interesting to you, then Broken Age will probably be worth the price.

reviewText:
I cut my teeth on adventure games as a kid—that and RPGs—so the puzzles were very simple for me and there wasn’t much playtime as a result.

But!

I’d rather have a very tight game (and only the first half at that) than a lot of padded content for no reason. The amount of detail that’s gone into that game is fantastic and I’d expect nothing less from that creative team. I hope a lot of people fall in love with adventure games because of this title, because it’s full of moments that I remember kind of delighting me as a kid with Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle. Like, trying to combine two objects you don’t expect to do anything—but getting some kind of very specific dialogue for that action when it fails all the same.

Try to combine fruit + ladder =

No
date:
I don’t need a fruit-scented ladder right now."

Why on earth would they need to record that instead of just making an error sound! Because everything is fun in that game even when you’re getting things wrong. It really puts an emphasis back into EXPLORATION. Which was always the appeal of those games and really makes me feel like a kid again.

Because the emphasis isn’t on FINISHING the game or getting achievements or anything like that. It’s inhabiting that world and clicking on everything gleefully and exhausting every dialogue tree.


I really hope that people get this game.
"

reviewText:
Act 1.  Masterpiece.

Act 2. Pile of Steaming Dog Poo.

Act 1, had the perfect mix of comedy, acting, puzzle solving, heartfelt emotion and pure gold.

Act 2, had story contrivances ... one character knowing that the other character needed something in a specific way for them to progress... when said character had NO CLUE WHATSOEVER what the other character needed.  Oh but the player did.

And the puzzles, annoying to solve and it takes a lot of switcing between characters and, to me, breaking up narrative flow.

At the end of Act 2, my hair was pulled from it's resting place, my game also BSOD my computer at least once and I had screamed to high holy heaven in aggravation.

It's like Tim Shafer created a masterpiece... then went on to make a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ sequel that takes all the previous wonder, comedy, fun ... and RIPPED IT RIGHT OUT.

Act 1 - Laughed 9-10 times.

Act 2 - Two giggles... lots of hair pulling.

5/10 ... and it's only that high because of Act 1.

A waste of money at its current price however... and I feel sorry for the 1500+ people who donated millions to Tim Shafer for this piece of awesome game and crap game at the same time.  I could just feel their wonderment after playing Act 1 ... quickly turn into WHY THE F DID I GIVE TIM SHAFER MY MONEY?!" when they got to Act 2.

Tim... for the love of god ... where did all the money go? Into paying the actors right? Did you waste it all on the actors and have nothing left for Act 2? Is the reason it took so long because you were out of money to make a decent end to your game?"

reviewText:
This game has great visuals, genuine humor, and stellar voice acting, but puzzles can be unintuitive and dialogue regrettably stitched together.

Watching the trailer, you can see and hear the pros I listed. A great cast and imaginative art make this game worth playing.

What you can't see from the trailer are the cons I've pointed out.
As others have pointed out, the second act of this game has a sharp difficulty spike. A good portion of my play through was simply being stuck in the second act, not actually playing the game. All in all, I had to look at hints 3 times to progress in the second act (not at all in the first). If you don't mind using a guide, this game will likely be great for you. If having to toggle between two characters to get answers to puzzles bothers you (immersion breaking because characters use knowledge they otherwise wouldn't have) then this game is definitely NOT for you.
Other than the difficulty in the second act, I wasn't entirely pleased with how the dialogue flowed together. The lines by themselves were not the problem, but following one line of thought and then having to jarringly switch over to another to get a hint or key to a puzzle really bothered me.

For me, I liked the game, but I would have preferred to watch someone else play it (stitching together the dialogue best they could) or for this to be a short movie.
