reviewText:
For those of you expecting a return to the old-school point 'n click adventure games, you won't find it here. It's the genre reimagined for these modern times. This means the UI is optimised for tablets. No menu's, only one interaction prompt and drag & drop inventory. The level of interactivity is very poor as well, only essential objects can be highlighted. All really unintuïtive, so it'll take some time getting used to.
Once and if you get over these modernisations the game will present itself as a charming adventure game. The artstyle is amazing, voice-acting superb and the music hits all the right notes. Though very enjoyable there's no crude humor like you'd expect from Tim Shafer, the whole thing seems rather harmless compared to the old days.
Part 1 will only take about 3-4 hours to complete, because the puzzles aren't hard. You'll breeze through it, but at least that keeps the pacing going. It sets up part 2 to have some intruiging plot development and I'm excited to see where they take it.
Pick it up if you havn't yet, this is one adventure you don't want to miss out on.

reviewText:
Dear Tim,

I'm sorry to say the game I gleefully backed isn't any good.

Yes the puzzles are simple, but main problem for me is it's just so boring and laboured. I never came close to laughing out loud like the Monkey Island games; instead it's all heavy handed metaphors and forced quirkiness. It's like expecting a meaningful but deranged and hilarious act by Louis CK, and getting a Wes Anderson movie. I'm not sure I'll even bother with the 2nd half when you eventually push it out.

And now I mention the delays and how frought the project is; you've lost me as a backer for future projects. Again, sorry Tim.

reviewText:
I'm sorry, please forgive me.  I'm co-responsible for this dullness: I was among those who kickstarted this (so I got early access and already have it).

We gave Double Fine over 8 times more money than they had asked for.  Yet somehow it turned out it still wasn't enough for them: they went over schedule, needed some extra funding, made some cuts and are releasing it in parts.  But the worst is...

...it is just as insignificant, inconsistent  and boring as Monkey Island and Grim Fandango were fabulous, great and funny.  What happened?

By far it doesn't look like the same Schafer we knew and loved.  Pity, pity, pity: mine and everyone else's hopes were so high.  We really believed he coud give us another gem, but it seems time has had it's toll and he's spent.  So sad.

Please Tim, making things strange and weird does not make them interesting.  Oddness that has no motive and ends nowhere can titillate curiosity for a short time, but ends up being only boring and irritating.

We still love you and many of us are longing for great adventure games.  We would love to get more of those from you.
I'm sure you can still be a great team-leader and motivator, but maybe you should pass the creative leadership to some other artist who still has something innovative and interesting to say.   PLEASE!    Thank you.

reviewText:
I missed the boat on the Kickstarter though I did end up preordering the game on the site, it was clearly the right decision.

Broken Age is already an amazing game, not only is it Double Fine's best game I think its one of the best adventure games ever and its only the first half. The sheer amount of creativity is astounding and it really goes to show how shallow and lifeless AAA games are right now. The atmosphere is great and so is the writing, which is darkly humorous in its own unique way. The voice-acting is pretty great too. The puzzles are logical and not convulted, I never had to use a FAQ once, which is pretty damn good for an adventure game and I love the genre.

One could easily criticize Double Fine for blowing their budget, and I even did, but its pretty clear that the money was put to great use and this is a truly a labor of love. I really do recommend this game and its a great thing that it is so good because it proves that despite the inherent risks crowd-funding like Kickstarter can really work to make great games that would otherwise never exist if the money is given to the teams that can make it happen.

reviewText:
This review is in regards to Act 1, since Act 2 is not available yet.

Personally, I gladly recommend Broken Age, but I'm going to say right now that it's DEFINITELY not something that will fit everyone's gaming tastes. It's a point-and-click adventure, of course, but a very simple one; sometimes the only difficulty that arose was from temporarily looking over an item that needs to be used. I'm not sure if it's even possible to truly fail this game, to be honest. The game is short, simple enough if you pay attention, and doesn't particularly fall prey to the Sierra Logic issues that sometimes come with point-and-click games (Sierra games were infamous in particular for occasionally having puzzles with solutions that were so absurd, they didn't make sense). If you're looking for a complex puzzle game or something involving some combat, then you should look elsewhere.

I recommend this game mostly on the merit of the story, music, and art style. If you've ever played Double Fine games before (Psychonauts comes to mind), then you'll have an idea of what sort of tone this game's story has. I enjoyed the characters and settings, short as everything was, and I'm glad I played it. I wish there had been more to do at least in some of the interactions, but considering this is part 1 of a 2-part game, I'm not going to hold it against the game.

What this review basically comes down to is if you can like a game mostly for the story and style, then this may be good to look into. If you want a challenging sort of gameplay experience, though? It's probably not worth your time.

reviewText:
---Part 1 review originally written Jan 2014---

I may be a victim of my own overblown expectations on this one, but I came away from Broken Age (part 1) fairly disappointed.  The one thing that I expect from Tim Schafer is great characters and humor.  Small doses of the latter are still present, but the characters, I found I could care less about them.  Neither of the main characters has a standout personality.  The girl, Vella, is much better in this respect than the boy, and her section of the game is better too; but ultimately the game  never comes close to approaching the excellence of Full Throttle or Grim Fandango.

The puzzles stay away from the sometimes ridiculous leaps of logic of 90s adventure games - but almost too far.  The game is much too easy, with options being limited and solutions being almost insultingly obvious.  The game is about as close to click button for more story" as an adventure game can get.  So the gameplay is certainly not it's own reward
date: which is ok in an adventure game because ultimately the point *is* the story
recommended:
but in this case the narrative and characters aren't much of a reward either.

---Part 2 review---

Some of the leaps of logic required make 90s adventure games look sensible in comparision and when combined with incessant back and forth travel between several recycled backgrounds from part 1

reviewText:
I can't say how much I recommend this game. This game is literally the reason I got into gaming (I saw the NPR piece about it and I knew I had to get my hands on something that lovely).

Story:
The first half is fantastic story. In the documentary they pointed out that things really kick up once Merrick shows up and that's definitely true. You don't really know what is going on or who to trust. Then you have the end of the first half and the beginning of the second half.

The big mysteries in the first half are pretty quickly filled in within the second half but personally I loved the ways they were revealed (for one my husband was watching over my shoulder and exclaimed in surprise) and that the focus of the game was then executing specific tasks, rather than hunting for clues.

I also really liked the ending; it reminded me strongly of the ending of Transistor with it's understated approach and use of the credits.

Overall the story was just suspenseful/unnerving enough without being something I wouldn't recommend to younger players and fantastically winsome and memorable.

Character Balance/Development:
In the first half Vella's world is more flat than Shay's. She's less clearly motivated and the objects she carries don't result in really any clever dialogue at all (as far as clicking on them in inventory, offering them to everyone, etc). Shay's world on the other hand was amazingly rich. The spoon and knife I didn't really discover until my second play through and they alone make his entire world more charming.

In the second half that's much more balanced. While Shay still has more interesting tasks since he isn't trapped as much in one locale, Vella picks up the knife and a fork and some new characters show up in her locale (along with an old one I was really hoping we hadn't seen the end of!) that give her more engagement. Shay has more of the I don't think we can use that that way" lines in the second half.

Shay is in my opinion more rounded and makes more sense than Vella. We don't get a good sense of Vella without really digging into one or two lines; otherwise she comes off as needlessly and oddly intense. But they are both very winning and you feel a vested interest in them.

One thing character wise that bugged me in the second half was the fact that one character stands around on a beach and you can't really talk to him. His big issue is pretty easily solved and then he's just there for most of the game. If you try to talk to him you get the auto "Never mind!" line and have to walk away. That seemed really pointless.

Puzzles:
They are definitely uneven but not unduly so. The first half of the game they are realizing things are not as they seem. The second half they are trying to cope with certain big revelations and new realities. It makes sense that other things are suddenly harder as well.

I have NO idea why people hate the second half so much. The puzzles are clever but not so obscure that you would never get them (I found the knot puzzle easy while I would miss certain more obvious items
date: like how to get the shell). Most of the time if one side got old I would switch and play the other and suddenly things would make sense to me. So I felt like it played very smoothly. You need to diagram some things out but please
recommended:
that's point and click standard. If you don't see that as the sign of a good game then don't play point and click.

I also didn't understand the claims some have made about not having a hint system. When your character tells you "Maybe I should look for X" how is that NOT a hint? Same with your character asking another repeatedly if thing X will cause reaction Y.

I like all others would have liked more new territory
hoursPlayed: but again
voteText: that's point and click standard to have one environment you really scrub over again and again. If it had all been released at once it would have been less striking.\n\nI know there's more I could say here but these were the reasons I got into the game and these are the only things that really matter to me. It's a gorgeous game that is incredibly addicting and charming. If this appeals to you at all
helpfulPercent: buy it! It's well worth every cent!"

reviewText:
To start, I just want to give a brief overview: Part 1 was brilliant, charming, and in my opinion, alone worth playing through for the purchase of this game, albeit not at full price. Part 2 did not deliver in regards to puzzles, and has had mixed reactions to the story (which I'm personally neutral on, I can't bring myself to dislike it, but the ending is by no means satisfying either).

I think I speak for the majority of players when it comes to one thing, at least:
Part 2 was not fun. It is as simple as that. After over a year of waiting upon completing part 1, I'll damit, the story could have been fleshed out more, but ultimately that is a minor complaint when it comes to repetitive and convoluted puzzle design that gets in the way of the more logical, more straightforward, but simultaneously still-difficult puzzles that really provided a sense of achievement when you completed them instead of giving you a sigh of relief to finally be done - just to move on to that same laborious struggle.

That said, I believe this story is meritable if not for its puzzles, then for its artstyle and, in some part, story. This game is gorgeous from start to finish, in an artstyle that truly matches up to the very nature of the game and is pleasing simply to be walking through. That said, that is the only point that gets by without flaws, in my opinion. The music, whilst excellent, I found to be far too repetitive, although this likely comes from the fact that the puzzles in part 2 forced me to associate them with the unpleasant experience, which is really a pity.

On to the story. I will avoid any spoilers but I will say that I have seen complaints that the story does not continue with part 1's themes of teenage struggle. This, at least, I disagree with. Part 1 heavily showed through Shay's story the struggle of dealing with overprotective and overbearing parents, and Vella's shows dealing with living and dealing with life outside of parental influence (and to a more minor degree, dealing with parents' beliefs  and their contrast to her view of the world). Part 2, on the other hand, shows the point of view of their respective families, moreso, and allows for a less one-sided view on the issues. I feel like if not for this, the story may have had the opportunity to flesh out more interestingly, but thematically was essential to take players out of their comfort zone when it comes to understanding both sides of an issue that directly affects what I believe to be the majority of players. Some plot points were not fleshed out, but I personally feel that that would have pulled attention away from the themes of teenage struggle we otherwise have.

Broken Age, for me, has sated my hunger for adventure games and kept me engaged in a story that remains focused and rooted in its themes. Whilst as a story, it is weak, and for the second half the puzzles are tedious and disappointing, a beautiful artstyle paired with a thematically focused narrative means Broken Age, for me, reamins worth playing.
It's no masterpiece, like I hoped that it could be, but it does just enough to make it worth playing through.

reviewText:
Broken Age is a beautiful game, and it's first Act is a wonderful introduction to the old-school adventure genre for a new generation. The story is intriguing, and the puzzles intuitive and fun ... in Act 1.

Unfortunatley, everything seems to start falling apart in Act 2. Massive plot holes are introduced to the story, and the puzzles become convoluted and frustrating. I can't imagine ever solving the final puzzle without consulting a guide - something I never had to do in Act 1, or for any other part of Act 2. But the puzzles in Act 2 are everything that was wrong with adventure games in the 1990s. Double-fine paid too much attention to the hardcore player's feedback about Act 1's puzzles being easy and ramped up difficulty (i.e. moon logic) enough to kill the enjoyment for all the other players in Act 2.

The characters and world are still engaging, but everything else in Act 2 is a massive let down compared to the first Act of the game.

I tenatively recommend the game if you can catch it on sale, just because Act 1 is so flawless and enjoyable, but Double-Fine dropped so many balls with Act 2 that it is a tragedy.

reviewText:
It's pretty if you like the art style, not a massive fan of it myself but you can see how people would find it beautiful. Everything is a bit sparse, very few things to interact with.

Puzzles are absurdly simple, there's a couple of odd leaps of logic as per standard but since you have such a tiny inventory and so few things to interact with it's hard to get stuck.  Given this was backed on the love of oldschool adventure gamers, this should've been way more of a focus.  Also for people who are used to exploring rooms you'll find a lot of dialog is out of place - your character is suddenly asking around about things they've not yet heard of.

The two stories are charming but shallow, old adventure games were marketed at kids but the complexity of them was what made them stick.  This has none.

It's hard to picture how DoTT had a budget of 600k, while they only managed half a game with a tiny fraction of the depth, with 3.3million

In Act 2: Puzzles go from barely existing to frustratingly vague, random and even glitched to impossibility.  They don't even make sense, the two characters need to share knowledge on several occasions through the player, there is no possible way each could get the solutions the other needs to find out for them.  For one of them there is NO way to find out the answer, you have to just rely on the fact it's not the other 3 options and the game has given you a fourth out of the blue.

A lot of the fail states are mind numbingly boring to reset - do it enough times and the game will actually step in and cut out some of the steps so it's not like they weren't aware the puzzles kinda sucked.

I'm sort of imagining this is the backlash from everyone complaining act 1 was too easy, but there's a thing called balance and this is both of the worst ends of the spectrum.

Story wraps up in record time - but still makes no sense - and then the finale is forced and anticlimactic, dialogue is much shorter, much less witty, character development is nil.  Revelations that should be earth-shattering and psyche-breaking are shrugged off in seconds. The ending not only doesn't make sense, it doesn't even solve anything.

All in all if this were a quirky bargain bin game then sure pick it up, play for a bit and then forget. As a story it's a mess that clearly wasn't planned in advance. As a promised hark back to the old school games of yore, it's a nail in their coffin.

This is not the game we backed.

reviewText:
Very short. A few hours. Only has first act. May not be worth the purchase, yet. The story is shaping up to be interesting once complete. The cliffhanger of Act I certainly has me chomping at the bit for Act II.

Decent voice acting and writing. Has the whimsy, but not the wit of certain old school adventure games such as Monkey Islands. Though the lack of wit is a result of the story and characters being somewhat serious. (at least in comparison to the slapstick antics of Guybrush Threepwood Mighty Pirate) Contains a good bit of dramatic irony as well.

The art style may be the best part. It's wonderful to look at. With the fanciful interesting character design we can expect from Doublefine.

There are big names lending their voices, but it never felt like anyone but the character's themselves where talking.


Due to not being the complete story. I would not recommend this game. Know what you are purchasing so you don't regret the purchase. I'm happy with my purchase but I have a soft spot for adventure games.

reviewText: At the games current state, apparently only being half complete, it is totally and absolutely not worth the money. I don't care how much money they got to work on it (in reference to the Kickstarter), as I gave none to that cause, so it's not quite my business, but I did buy this game for about $11 and 4 hours of gameplay is nowhere near worth that. They say there's a part 2 coming and most importatnly it IS free. But if you don't want to play half of the game and wait however many months it takes to be completed, which I don't know anyone who would (other than me because I have many other games to move on to) sort of like an episodic game except full-priced from the beginning, with only ONE free act announced, or like a season pass where you pay now and get dlc later, this is not for you. It seems like there is only one other act announced and if it's the same length as Act 1 and the only other act that gets released for free, this game is WAY overpriced, even the price for it on sale.\nTL;DR: In the modern age, 8 hours (assuming act two is the same length) of gameplay is not worth $11 not to mention $25. If they don't add more acts to make it an acceptable amount of gameplay/time (dependent on your opinion, but I think most agree that the time is not enough right now to justify the price), then the price is completely unfair, no matter what voice-actors they hired.\nMaybe, I'm spoiled by Steam sales and being able to buy very long and/or content-filled games for incredibly low prices (almost never buying a new, full-priced game) but you have to go with the flow of other developers.

reviewText:
It's pretty if you like the art style, not a massive fan of it myself but you can see how people would find it beautiful. Everything is a bit sparse, very few things to interact with.

Puzzles are absurdly simple, there's a couple of odd leaps of logic as per standard but since you have such a tiny inventory and so few things to interact with it's hard to get stuck.  Given this was backed on the love of oldschool adventure gamers, this should've been way more of a focus.  Also for people who are used to exploring rooms you'll find a lot of dialog is out of place - your character is suddenly asking around about things they've not yet heard of.

The two stories are charming but shallow, old adventure games were marketed at kids but the complexity of them was what made them stick.  This has none.

It's hard to picture how DoTT had a budget of 600k, while they only managed half a game with a tiny fraction of the depth, with 3.3million

In Act 2: Puzzles go from barely existing to frustratingly vague, random and even glitched to impossibility.  They don't even make sense, the two characters need to share knowledge on several occasions through the player, there is no possible way each could get the solutions the other needs to find out for them.  For one of them there is NO way to find out the answer, you have to just rely on the fact it's not the other 3 options and the game has given you a fourth out of the blue.

A lot of the fail states are mind numbingly boring to reset - do it enough times and the game will actually step in and cut out some of the steps so it's not like they weren't aware the puzzles kinda sucked.

I'm sort of imagining this is the backlash from everyone complaining act 1 was too easy, but there's a thing called balance and this is both of the worst ends of the spectrum.

Story wraps up in record time - but still makes no sense - and then the finale is forced and anticlimactic, dialogue is much shorter, much less witty, character development is nil.  Revelations that should be earth-shattering and psyche-breaking are shrugged off in seconds. The ending not only doesn't make sense, it doesn't even solve anything.

All in all if this were a quirky bargain bin game then sure pick it up, play for a bit and then forget. As a story it's a mess that clearly wasn't planned in advance. As a promised hark back to the old school games of yore, it's a nail in their coffin.

This is not the game we backed.

reviewText:
While I enjoyed Act 1, the story in Act 2 was atrocious and the puzzles were about as much fun as performing cosmetic surgery on myself with a claw hammer.

Act 2 creates plot holes, resolves absolutely nothing, requires the player to break the fourth wall (solutions to Shay's problems must be found by Vella and vice versa with no communication between the two of them). It also seems to undermine much of the plot from Act 1.

The ending makes no sense; I cannot fathom why Vella or Shay would feel compelled to do what they have to do, especially since they cannot come up with a plan or tell each other what they need to do. It resolves absolutely nothing, and is in general so half-done it seems like this was meant to be a bridge for a third Act. But it's not, this was the end.

Terrible. Not worth the wait, and definitely not recommended.

reviewText: After having played this game through twice, I think I can safely say that it, for the most part, does justice to classic adventure games. Though the puzzles (with some exceptions, but I will get to those in a second) are really very easy, the game itself is extremely enjoyable; this is mostly due to the fully realized characters, the fantastic setting (which does start to dry out with the second part), and great humor and conversation.\n\nThat said, the second part saw a pretty large detour from the first. It starts off on a relatively weak note, with astonishingly stupid plot twists (such as that of Shay's family) and long lists of tasks that the player has to do. Though a dedicated player will get past this section without pause, it provides very little motivation to keep going. reviewText:
I thought that Broken Age was a fun adventure game. Was it a masterpiece? No. Did it live up to the amount of hype and money put into development? I think not. But putting all the preconceptions about Tim Schafer and the delay of the 2nd part aside, and approaching it simply as a game, I enjoyed it and thought it was worth the sticker price that I backed it for.

I didn't have any issues with the amount of backtracking in Act 2, although the some of the puzzles in Act 2 can be frustrating at times and poorly designed. Mainly a certain knot puzzle that is very difficult, or at least annoying, to parse, and the final puzzle resets itself when you leave a room, which can be hair-pulling.

The plot does have some plot holes, and ridiculous aspects, especially in Act 2. While they do stretch the limits of the imagination, they are not impossible to believe, especially since the universe the game is set in is a little bonkers and cartoonish.

Overall, the game was fun, and saying otherwise is really a stretch. It wasn't a classic or a masterpiece, but it was good enough to pull its own weight. The question of whether it lived up to the amount of money put into it is another story. I don't really think it did, since there have been some very competent and funny adventure games made by indies on a shoestring budget. Most of the money from the Kickstarter really went into keeping the studio afloat and paying for star power rather than towards making an impressive game. That isn't to say that the game doesn't look nice - it definitely does. And even if the game didn't live up to the hype, it's definitely something that is worth playing"."

reviewText:
I'm having a really hard time deciding whether or not to recommend Broken Age.

On the one hand, I absolutely loved the art style, the soundtrack, the characters and the world. All top notch. The hand-painted art is consistently amazing, even breathtaking at times. The game runs and flows very smoothly with slick cuts between scenes. The ending of Act I left me in awe of what had just happened and hungry for more. Definitely a page-turner of a game.

Yet the game is unfortunately a victim of annoying, unintuitive and, at times, very frustrating adventure game logic." The puzzles were mostly OK

The game itself has that broken age meaning , is it a full blown old adventure game ? no
is it like one of those heavy graphics modern adventure games ? no
Tim has decided to take the game in between making it the best of both eras , old and new.

reviewText:
A point and click adventure game that came in two acts and the division is clear.

Act 1:
I'm not really a big adventure fan, mostly because those I played long ago were full of puzzles that just didn't make any sense and would devolve into just using everything on everything until you found the solution, or by getting a walkthrough. So, for me, the first act was really great, the puzzles made sense and I only got really stuck once (but when I looked up the solution I was like 'damn, I'm an idiot'.
The story is really great, full of cool characters with good voice acting. The visuals are (with one subjective exception, see later) amazing, both backgrounds and characters and their animations. At the end of Act 1 I was like whaaaaaaaat :-O".

What I did not like: Most of the characters have a very prominent red noses that to me looked either as chronic alcoholics or a chimp attack victims with big gaping holes in their faces. I wanted to take a cool screenshot many times but I decided against it because I could not get over those noses.

Act 2:
The story and audiovisuals are still good

reviewText:
I thought that Broken Age was a fun adventure game. Was it a masterpiece? No. Did it live up to the amount of hype and money put into development? I think not. But putting all the preconceptions about Tim Schafer and the delay of the 2nd part aside, and approaching it simply as a game, I enjoyed it and thought it was worth the sticker price that I backed it for.

I didn't have any issues with the amount of backtracking in Act 2, although the some of the puzzles in Act 2 can be frustrating at times and poorly designed. Mainly a certain knot puzzle that is very difficult, or at least annoying, to parse, and the final puzzle resets itself when you leave a room, which can be hair-pulling.

The plot does have some plot holes, and ridiculous aspects, especially in Act 2. While they do stretch the limits of the imagination, they are not impossible to believe, especially since the universe the game is set in is a little bonkers and cartoonish.

Overall, the game was fun, and saying otherwise is really a stretch. It wasn't a classic or a masterpiece, but it was good enough to pull its own weight. The question of whether it lived up to the amount of money put into it is another story. I don't really think it did, since there have been some very competent and funny adventure games made by indies on a shoestring budget. Most of the money from the Kickstarter really went into keeping the studio afloat and paying for star power rather than towards making an impressive game. That isn't to say that the game doesn't look nice - it definitely does. And even if the game didn't live up to the hype, it's definitely something that is worth playing"."

reviewText:
A point and click adventure game that came in two acts and the division is clear.

Act 1:
I'm not really a big adventure fan, mostly because those I played long ago were full of puzzles that just didn't make any sense and would devolve into just using everything on everything until you found the solution, or by getting a walkthrough. So, for me, the first act was really great, the puzzles made sense and I only got really stuck once (but when I looked up the solution I was like 'damn, I'm an idiot'.
The story is really great, full of cool characters with good voice acting. The visuals are (with one subjective exception, see later) amazing, both backgrounds and characters and their animations. At the end of Act 1 I was like whaaaaaaaat :-O".

What I did not like: Most of the characters have a very prominent red noses that to me looked either as chronic alcoholics or a chimp attack victims with big gaping holes in their faces. I wanted to take a cool screenshot many times but I decided against it because I could not get over those noses.

Act 2:
The story and audiovisuals are still good
date: although the story didn't feel as good as the first act's
recommended: but I felt the puzzles were now made a lot harder for some reason. And the worst of them (the wiring) had a randomized solution so you could not quickly be done with it by looking up the solution. I admit I had one guide open in the overlay most of the second act. Really

reviewText:
The game itself has that broken age meaning , is it a full blown old adventure game ? no
is it like one of those heavy graphics modern adventure games ? no
Tim has decided to take the game in between making it the best of both eras , old and new.

reviewText:
Totally lived up to my hopes from its Kickstarter three years ago! I loved most of the puzzles, the writing was as great as ever, the art completely stunning, and the reveals and story much more satisfying than I could have hoped. All of the voice actors were top notch too.

There were a couple of points I had to use a walkthrough to figure out some esoteric details, but honestly? That's just part of adventure games for me and always has been.

The puzzles which actually required creative thinking instead of finding a hidden combination of items? Didn't need a walkthrough for those, just some good problem solving.

reviewText:
Overall I recommend everyone pick this up if you are fan of puzzle games. It contains a high amount of polish and should give you a good 10 hours or so of gameplay. There are some flaws, but I found it to a challenging and fun experience. I think it works well to play it in small periods and take breaks so you do not get too frustrated.

Pros:
Graphics: Beautiful hand painted game. Each area and character looks distinct. Since they are all painted, the game will probably still look good years from now.

Sound: Fully orchestrated score and high quality voice acting. The personality of the charcters come alive through their dialogue. The investments and time they spent on the music and voice acting really pays off, especially with the main characters.

Gameplay: Game is point and click and functions with a vareity of controller options including touch screen. The standard game play is to travel to different areas and solve puzzles to further the game's plot. The puzzles start off fairly easy and progress in difficulty towards the end of the game. Most are fairly fun and can be solved by following established mechanics or using information from items/characters. A few near the end can frustate you, but even then the game tries to give you hints for these. So if you get annoyed, take a break and clear your head. There are some fun chemistry puzzles and ones that use SAT question like logic and even one that involve tree jokes. Near the end, I needed to take pictures of some of the clues, so have your phone or paper handy.

Story: The story is fairly straightfoward and a bit flawed, but the characters and dialogue really shine. Vella is one of the best female protagonist I have seen in a game for a long time. Shay shows some nice growth throughout the game and brings a nice opposing view to the world compared to Vella. All the side characters are are fun to talk to and will make you laugh. In fact every side character feels unique and memorable. Some highlights for me include the tree , the space weaver, and vella's family.

Cons:
Gameplay: The puzzles are interesting, and the game tries to give you hints, but it can be inconsistent about it. One of the aspects I did not like is that its not always obvious when you cannot yet complete a task/puzzle. Some puzzles require other ones to be completed first before you can solve them. The game is not great in explaining this always, so you can feel like stuck and frustrated when trying to solve a puzzle when you simply need some item from another puzzle first. So dont focus too much on anyone puzzle, try switching characters and tasks from time to time. Some puzzles are great at giving you hints and even teleporting you where you need to go if you mess up, but others seem to only clue you in once. Stacking had a nice hint system that might be helpful in this game. I think several big site reviews are frustrated by the boot, knot, and wire puzzles. The wire one is probably the most challenging though the game does try to give you some hints.

Graphics: There not many new areas in Act 2. Most of the places you visited in Act 1 you will see again in Act 2, but through a differing perspective. There are a few new places, but do not expect a lot of new art. All of the characters have new dialogue at least.

Story: The story does not feel entirely complete. On the surface it works and is satisfying enough, but the game definitely leaves a lot of questions about the world and its history. The characters go through their arcs and complete their goals, but there is a lot left for the player to fill in.  It definitely feels like changes were made or story was cut for the sake of time/money. The final puzzle is fun to solve, but from a story perspective, it feels like the motivations could have been better explained.

reviewText:
(this review isn't completely done yet, buuut it still might help you)

Since the release of Act 2, some reviewers have written about Broken Age being a point&click heaven, while others seem to hate almost everything about it. I don't think it's perfect, but neither do I see a sharp decline in quality if compared to Act 1. Let me tell you why I think so (spoiler-free, of course):

Act 1 has absolutely funny dialogue, bizarre characters and a twist at the end that once left me hungry for more, but it lacked clever puzzles. True, Act 2 doesn't have as many surprises when it comes to the story and yes, most areas you'll visit have already been established before, but its dialogue and its characters is still absurdly funny, and its puzzle design is absolutely great and much more challenging. Of course, the solutions to some puzzles are so creative that you might silently shout How the hell should I have known that?" but COME ON

reviewText:
I'm having a really hard time deciding whether or not to recommend Broken Age.

On the one hand, I absolutely loved the art style, the soundtrack, the characters and the world. All top notch. The hand-painted art is consistently amazing, even breathtaking at times. The game runs and flows very smoothly with slick cuts between scenes. The ending of Act I left me in awe of what had just happened and hungry for more. Definitely a page-turner of a game.

Yet the game is unfortunately a victim of annoying, unintuitive and, at times, very frustrating adventure game logic." The puzzles were mostly OK

reviewText: How could you go wrong with a game comming from Double Fine studio?  It's amazing in every aspect! Where should i start? The virusals.. the musical score.. the voice acting.. Just the very first scene of Vella waking up under a tree sets the tone for the rest of the adventure. It's enchanting. It's like watching your very first cartoons with children's eyes. There are quite enough puzzle, mostly very easy, but the adventure focusses more on the dialogues which you souldn't miss a single line as they are so well written and acted. Elijah Wood, Jack Black, Will Wheaton, ... even Pendleton Ward is in it :)  For the french speaking person i am not very much used to recognize english actors by their voice, i was surprised and pleased to recognize them in the game! The subtitles are very well translated, by the way. Really, it praises quality ... over quantity, which is the game's only downside. The game is very short (typical for point'n'click adventure games) and Act2 isn't even released yet, but it will be soon and for free. I just can't wait for it. Thanks Tim Schafer and Double Fine production. I knew from the start my money was on the right horse.

reviewText:
I had been sitting on Broken Age since it was released, however I didn't want to play it until all the episodes had been released (two). Finally earlier this year the second episode finally came out.

Broken Age is a point-and-click game. The game features two characters, each located in different worlds. You can switch between the two characters at any time you want at the click of a button, other than this; the characters don’t have any real interaction. It has all the usual adventurey type things such as an inventory and very good dialog options.

The game looks absolutely gorgeous, animations are all done brilliantly too. Music and voice acting is all top notch.

As with most point and click games, you have to have some nicely put together puzzles, and Broken Age certainly delivers, they aren't so hard that you are stuck for hours trying to work it out, but they aren't so easy that you can do it without thinking. I won't spoil anything with regards to the story, but it is beautifully written, and the characters are some of the most likable I have ever encountered in a video game.

This is one of those games you just have to have in your library, its fun and worth the time and adventure. Don't let other reviews discourage you from a good time!

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

reviewText:
This game is very good, but not as good as Grim Fandango.

Broken Age is a point and click adventure game by Tim Schafer, about two teenagers who live two seemingly different lives.  First there is a girl who has been chosen to be sacrificed to a monster but decides to fight back.  Second, is a boy who has been raised on a spaceship by an overprotective super computer, but now he wants more excitement in his life.

The art style and environments are gorgeous and Imaginative, the characters you interact with are colorful and memorable, and the humor is well written.  The story, while not as good as some of Tim’s past work, is a pretty decent story with some interesting twists and turns along the way. And while I do believe the game’s ending does leave some questions unanswered, I personally found it satisfying.

My personal problem with the game was that some of the puzzles felt a bit too cryptic. I felt like I was forced to find the solutions online, and after finding the solutions, it made me wonder how any normal person would figure them out without having to resort to a walkthrough.  It would have been helpful if the game had a hint button like they had in the Monkey Island special edition.  Despite this, it didn’t really ruin the experience for me.

If you in the mood for a nice, charming, adventure game then I would recommend checking it out.  It may not be perfect, but is still an experience worth having.
I give this game a 7.7/10.

reviewText:
Great first act, not quite as good second act, terrible ending (imo).

Really becomes apparent that they ran out of money.

First act is gorgeous and well written, a lot of fun to play.  The art style is amazing and the high quality voiceovers contribute greatly to the game.  The second act starts to fall apart as they reuse nearly all assets and locations from the first act, and resort to simple item swapping puzzles (fetch quests, effectively) across multiple characters and NPCs to stretch the length (seemingly).  The end of the second act, if you can even call it that, is about 5 minutes long and consists of several scenes of exposition and a fairly poorly explained 'ending', where you get little to no actual information about what is going on, just a brief explanation and then credits.

The villain provides little to no motivation outside from one sentence as to why he is doing what he is doing, and even then, never explains at all why he has chosen the specific path he took to complete his action.  He exists almost solely as diabolus ex machina for the plot.  His motivation is unclear until the very end, and even then it seems completely weakly written.

Save your $ unless this becomes extremely cheap.  There is no real pay-off at the end, you spend a lot of time getting excited about a few things that you never end up seeing and that never get explained, only to get a really short throwaway ending that exists solely to tie up one or two plot threads while leaving many, many others dangling.

reviewText:
Experience on Linux so far:

+ Solid

The game:
As a huge fan of point-and-click adventures this game tickled my old school nerves in the most pleasant of ways possible. The artwork is wonderful, I wish they would have a replay button just to replay certain scenes for their artistic attributes alone. You play as two main characters (a boy and a girl) and you can switch storyline between them as you please.
This is a nice way of getting away from the monotamy of the old-school point-and-clickers.
Voice acting is a big part in PAC games these days and this game nails it. I recognize a few names, most notably would be Jack Black, but overall the dialogs and characters come to live both through the beautiful animations and the excellent voice acting.
The game comes in two parts, the first part (out now) was outstanding, albeit short compared to even the mid 90's games in the genre. For the price I paid, yeah, maybe another two hours of gameplay, but I still think it was well worth it for maybe one of the best games in the genre ever.

Score:
5/5

reviewText:
Overhyped from the beginning, this game had a lot to live up to.

Unfortunately, while it's charming in some aspects I also found it rather dull in many others. The characters don't have a lot of personality and the game just fails to create a strong emotional connection with the player. Also, as expected, the gameplay is very simple and not challenging.

Inititally scheduled to be released as one game it was split into two parts when the developers ran out of money. That was very damaging to this game and it ends just when it starts to become a bit more interesting.

Despite what was claimed in the original kickstarter video, adventure games are not dead, they never were. It's a genre that is thriving with many innovative titles. Compared to those Broken Age is not the worst but it's also far from the best.

Overall an ok game but I recommend waiting until part 2 is released as hopefully that might fix some of the game's problems.

reviewText:
I backed the game in the initial Kickstarter and I completed Part One a while ago, but I just replayed it in order to refresh my memory for Part Two, which I've played for a couple hours. After a slight letdown at the release of Part One due to the easiness of the game, I'm really happy to see the difficulty ramp up in Part Two, and I also discovered that I really enjoyed playing through Part One again to find some of the jokes and details I had missed the first time around.

I find the art absolutely beautiful, the dialogue witty and well-written (first time in a while I've laughed out loud at a game), and it's all accompanied by an excellent soundtrack (I'm definitely a sucker for games with good music). The story is interesting and compelling, especially once you start delving into Part Two, and I'm having lots of fun trying to guess where it's going to end up.

Overall, I'm happy with the product Tim and the Double Fine team came out with - it's a very high quality point and click adventure and I'm having a blast playing through it!

One thing I wish was included in the game is an in-game hint system for the more frustrating puzzles though.

reviewText:
What a gem of a game. It exudes charm, humor, and lightness in only the way Tim Schafer and crew know how to do it. And it's so wonderful to see a point and click adventure game like this, in this day and age, harkening back to Schafer's older, most respected works. On top of that the art is brilliant, the voice acting top notch, the script clever and hilarious, and so many fun little easter eggs all over the place. I spent a good portion of the game just talking to everyone and combining every kind of item just to hear the knee-jerk responses. Double Fine are some of the best comic writers in the entertainment biz, games or otherwise.

The only downsides are those typical of point and click games. Some objects really do blend in with the background too well, you'll do lots of backtracking, various puzzles need to be solved in very specific order, etc. I must admit I did have to use a guide later in the game as some of the puzzle solutions were just not obvious enough after lots of back and forth trying out many different things. I can't really fault the developers for this, as I think these sorts of games do need to have some tougher puzzles, not everything can be elementary. Certainly nowhere near as perplexing and complicated as some of Machinarium's puzzles.

I can't recommend it enough!!

reviewText:
I loved every minute of this game. However, it's far too short and pretty much incomplete. I won't go ballistic about the injustice of how the community invested a ♥♥♥♥ ton of money into a kickstarter and only got a small part of what was promised to them; I didn't participate in that kickstarter and I only recently bought it, about a month before the release of Act II, so I can't really comment on that.

If I had to grade it as a standalone game, I certainly wouldn't recommend it; it being an incomplete experience. But considering how the second installation is right around the corner, and how intensely I enjoyed the two meager hours of gameplay this first miniature installation had to offer, I will recommend it heartily anyway.

As a caveat though, I have to say it's probably not for everyone. It's not incredibly thought-provoking, nor is it a particularly thrilling gameplay experience. It's just a charming adventure game that some might write off as childish and lackluster. And while I'd disagree with such a negative judgement, I can understand why some would think of it as such.

I loved it. Will you? I honestly don't know, but one can hope.

reviewText: If you are the type of person that loves games for their story, then this game will be worth the price tag. Some people have given this game negative reviews not because the game is bad, but because the price wasn't right for them. Yes, the game can be completed over a single weekend and yes, the price is steep, but it's been nearly a year now and I still think about the storyline of this game. It has more charm and personality than Deponia (which is saying a lot) and gives an immense amount of feels despite the small package it comes in.\n\nAt the very least, keep in mind that Part 2 of this game is coming out very soon and will be patched in for free. Maybe you'll want to wait until then to buy it, but if you wait, please keep away from any forums, videos, or comments talking about it. You may get spoiled on one of the game's most incredible moments.

reviewText:
I've only played a few hours into Broken Age, but I'm not sure I'll ever fire it up again.

Although the art style is respectable, the dialog is stilted, silly, and repetative. It's quite childish, but not in a way I think children would enjoy. The girl's story was somewhat engaging, but the boys side just failed to capture my imagination. Perhaps it was having to repeat the same 'quest' and dialog options multiple times. I get it, I'm supposed to feel like the boy who is bored out of his mind by endless repetition. Mission accomplished. Even when things started to pick up, the boy's lack of concern (or even moment of pause) that something has changed was too much for me to handle.

Again, I didn't really get too deep into the game, so maybe it picks up a little later, but I also found the gameplay completely lacking. The objects you need to find are basically handed to you, and what you need to do with them is painfully obvious for an adventure game. They really only serve as a means of advancing the plot.

In a word, I found Broken Age to be: boring.

reviewText:
Broken Age is an adventure game by Double Fine that was initially funded via Kickstarter in 2012. Now in 2015, the game is finally fully released! But the question is: does it deliver?

The story describes the coming of age of a boy (Shay) and girl (Vella). You get to play with both characters by alternating their storylines, which are interwoven in a clever way. After a certain point, alternating between characters becomes essential for progressing in the game. I found the story compelling and it motivated me to keep playing the game.

The puzzles in the game use the classic object manipulation and character interaction staples from the adventure game genre, which are executed in a appropriate and traditional way. Unfortunately, some puzzles do suffer from being too easy or having an unclear context. A bit more polish here and there would have definitely made all puzzles great. Overall, I enjoyed solving the puzzles.

From a visual perspective, Broken age has a unique and nice art style, which is definitely a selling point. Animations are crisp and the world feels very much alive thanks to a quirky cast of characters with great voice actors. The ambience the game breathes is great and it is an enjoyable environment to walk around in.

The soundtrack is also very enjoyable and it always suited the mood for the story.

In conclusion, from the perspective of an adventure game player, Broken Age might feel underwhelming, since it never tries to go beyond the classic adventure game mold. What remains is a charming game that any gamer with an open mind can appreciate, given its sense of adventure and positive spirit.

reviewText:
So, there it is. Broken Age is finally out. I haven't touched it before tonight (bought it sometime last year during a sale) and waited patiently for it to be ready for a full-on, one-session playthrough. The question is: Was it worth the wait?

The (spoiler-free) answer to that is: Yes it was, if you have been patient and didn't raise your expectations too high.


Now, something to say right away - Broken Age is not the adventure to end all adventures. It has its strengths and weaknesses. But what makes assessing them hard is that they switch around. In Act 1, the story was very strong and somewhat mysterious while the puzzles were mostly fairly easy. In Act 2, the story lost a lot of its pull (in my opinion) but the puzzles became more complex and challenging, some of them just the right amount to be satisfying, some pushing it a little (or well) into the realm of the frustrating.

But I will not blame Double Fine for experimenting with some of the concepts behind puzzles. The fewer developers keep recycling the same concept, content and game over and over, the better, so I can admit I was satisfied with that part of the game even though I eventually had to look up a hint or two.

The story left a somewhat bitter aftertaste, though. It's not that it's bad overall - The presentation is brilliant, the setup stellar (particularly Shay's Act 1 was great) and the cast of experienced and skilled (voice) actors add to it, as do the beatiful soundtrack and catching visuals. And the writing also doesn't leave a lot to be desired: It's witty, but not too over-the-top and just the right amount of educational to be played by all ages.
It does, however, suffer from what I would call the Mass Effect 3" effect: By the end
date: it seems like nobody really knew what to do with it
recommended: so it was just wrapped up in whatever way they could. It's not as bad as Mass Effect 3 but I found the conclusion unsatisfying and the last few scenes made me wonder where the good writing with its surprises and twists had gone and why I was now watching a B movie.\n\nI know that doesn't sound like a hearty recommendation but that doesn't mean you shouldn't pick it up. Broken Age is still a great adventure; it just isn't without faults
hoursPlayed: just like the story of its development.\n\nBe aware
voteText: though
helpfulPercent: that you are probably only going to get one playthrough of 8-10 hours out of it (maybe another some years later). But during a sale
votesHelpful: this is a good pick."

Broken Age is a game that focuses on two protagonists, Shay and Vella. They're very different but it turns out they're important to one another's story. Broken Age is their story and about how the two of them change things.

reviewText:
Broken Age represents the return of the classic “point-and-click” adventure game; it promised to feature the same wit, humor, and odd-ball puzzles that made games like The Secret of Monkey Island and Day of the Tentacle such timeless classics. I grew up during the hey-day of the point-and-click computer games and still have a box filled with floppy discs for games such as Monkey Island, Monkey Island 2 and Day of the Tentacle. My sense of humor was shaped by the comedy that Tim Schafer and Ron Gilbert wrote into their games.

Now, after a controversial development, Broken Age arrives in full on the PlayStation Vita making one thing absurdly clear: it makes good on everything it promised. It is an adventure game that is as deep and rich as any I’ve ever played.

2015-04-27-043646

Broken Age tells the story of two young adults with one thing in common; they’re unhappy with their lot in life. Shay is a young man who has spent his life aboard a spaceship and has had his every need catered to by an overly mothering computer. The only excitement in his day is when he embarks on scripted expeditions to “rescue” creatures in peril. Day after day his life trudges on the same, and day after day he goes through the same charade – wishing each time there was something more.

Vella is a young woman who lives in a village of bakers. Every 14 years the village offers up the best maidens in town as an offering to a horrible monster that ravages their land. Despite having such an honor bestowed upon her, Vella wonders why the people of her village cower in fear rather than fight the beast. She has chosen not to be a sacrifice; she has chosen for something better in life.

2015-04-21-161855

Shay and Vella are both unhappy with where their lives are going, but they also question what is real in the world around them. More than anything, what they really want, is to peer behind the curtain and discover the truth.

The story in Broken Age is a deep and philosophical one that ironically doesn’t take itself too seriously. Shay lives on a spaceship where his companions are all knitted out of yarn, while Vella comes from a place where young women compete to be eaten by a monster. It’s the juxtaposition of these conflicting ideas that brings an elevated sense of humor to the story…

Wow, that was deep. What I’m trying to say is that despite the underlying story, the surface is full of wild and wacky elements that are not only fun but hilariously funny. Often times this humor is derived from our two naïve heroes entering strange, new situations. Shay is a bit of a bumbling hero, much in the vain of Guybrush Threepwood from Monkey Island, while Vella is a headstrong go-getter with only one thing on her mind. Their dry comments in the oddest of situations would frequently make me laugh out loud, sometimes uncontrollably.

And it’s good to have a sense of humor when playing a puzzle game like this. The puzzles presented in Broken Age feel very familiar and fresh at the same time. They’re the same twisted puzzles I grew up with where clues hide in plain sight and the answer is often more absurd than you’d think. Sometimes these puzzles get solved in a matter of minutes while other times you may have to think about them for a few hours.

2015-04-23-080526
2015-04-21-194850
The game is broken up into two acts. Act I introduces us to our two protagonists and allows us to guide them on a new adventure. You can play as either Shay or Vella and switch between them at any time. The puzzles are challenging with a number of “A-ha!” moments, but it goes by rather quickly.

Act II starts with you having to deal with the consequences of your earlier actions. Shay and Vella want to peer behind the curtain, but what do they do once they have? The second act is much longer than the first and the puzzles get more intense. In total it took me around 13 hours to complete the entire game.

The interface for the game was designed with a PC in mind, and while it does make the transition to a controller fairly well, it still feels a bit awkward at times since you use the thumb sticks to move an on-screen cursor and interact with the environment. A nice feature is that the right stick will automatically snap to “clickable” objects so you don’t have to scan the entire room for something to click. It works decent enough, but it’s still not very precise. However, the PS Vita does have an advantage over the PS4 version – you can use the touchscreen to select items in the game. It works amazingly well and really speeds things up.

2015-04-25-083347

Visually, the game is absolutely stunning. The 2-D art style retains the feeling of the pixilated adventure games of old but adds a brilliant layer that creates a hand-drawn look to the game. The characters have a bold and unique style to them and the environmental art is all top notch. Everything runs smoothly with the performance never being a problem.

Likewise, the voice acting is superb. With notable talents such as Elijah Wood, Jack Black, and Wil Wheaton (whom I didn’t even recognize until the credits rolled), the characters are all given a great sense of depth and humor. And as good as the acting is, the musical score is even better. It’s composition is grand in ambition at times befitting the heroes’ journey, but it can also be tender and intimate. It’s by far one of my favorite game scores to come out in a long time.

2015-04-23-074403

As great as Broken Age is, it’s not perfect. I often had trouble with the audio late in the game where the characters would speak but audio would be delayed for several seconds (or get drowned out by other noises). It’s a problem that happened in isolated areas but it was persistent. It also appears to be a Vita issue as the same problem would not occur on the PS4. I also had problems with the game crashing occasionally which seemed to go hand-in-hand with the Vita losing a connection to PSN.

Any other issues I could point to would be nit-picking. It would be nice if there were more areas to explore, and it would be cool if the world felt a little bigger. Some characters get criminally underused while others get a bit too much screen time. In the end, I found it clever how the story would weave back into itself and reuse a lot of the same locations.

Broken Age is a masterpiece. It manages to capture everything that made point-and-click adventure games great in the first place. It is the perfect blend of interesting characters, wacky humor, and head-scratching puzzles that constantly have you wanting more, and represents everything that made these games so wonderful to play.

REVIEW OVERVIEW
Presentation	5/5
Gameplay	5/5
Lasting Appeal	4.5/5
Execution	5/5

SUMMARY
Broken Age promised to be a return to the classic point-and-click adventure games from yesteryear and manages to succeed on that promise in every way. It's a game filled with brilliantly absurd puzzles wrapped around a beautiful story that's told with wit and humor. It is both laugh out loud funny and head banging frustration. Broken Age manages to blend all these elements into a wonderfully charming game that should not be missed.

4.9/5

reviewText:
OK! Tim Schafer's Double Fine Adventure game, Broken Age (act 1) has finally landed! After being successfully funded on Mar 13, 2012. It landed today. And I have to say... holy crap that was bad.
That was three hours of semi humorous adventure point-and-click game play. It was not particularly exciting or hilarious or anything I expected from it considering who was making it and how much money they had to make it with (asked for $400k, received $3.33 million).

The art, and sound, and voice acting, and just about everything that individually make up a great game were pretty much all amazing.  That said... The pinnacle of the game was a hipster lumberjack woodworker making a comment after he makes a stool for you that you can have it because he likes to spread his samples around.

I'm not kidding. The height of the game was a poop joke.

Every individual piece was put together nicely, but they combined to make a rather lackluster and incredibly short game.  I understand this is only act 1, and act 2 will come out, oh, sometime, eventually, but even knowing there's going to be a sequel, the ending to this game is a giant middle finger to everyone who's been waiting for two years to play it.

As it took me maybe three hours of actual gameplay to finish this without looking anything up (it says I've had it open for 4.1 total at time of writing), I cannot recommend this in its current state. Wait until act 2 is available and play it straight through (assuming act 2 actually ends up with a decent ending).

reviewText:
I don't not-recommend this as a hard No. I might very likely recommend it to someone I thought would enjoy it, albeit with reservations.



*SPOILERS*

Weeellllll, I just finished playing Broken Age. Hmm. First off, it's so beautiful. SO beautiful. I can see why I paid full-price for it after knowing hardly anything and watching the trailer. The game is just as beautiful as the trailer looks, with a whole lot of tiresome monotony thrown in.

Broken Age is split into two acts. Act One has fairly simple puzzles which follow the fun story. Vella and Shay, the two main characters, each inhabit their own world with no knowledge of the other (but you know that's gonna change). Playing either character is possible at any time. In Act Two, Vella and Shay switch worlds, and while each world is expanded on and new characters introduced, the puzzles became so tedious and not-obvoius, I found myself walking around the same places over and over.

The puzzles were tough in a way that didn't feel very stimulating, or creative, or challenging. Just sort of a shiny cute laborious thing to sludge through, with the help of walkthroughs that I very quickly turned to. I really want to make this sound more positive than I am, but I think the best part of the game for me was finishing, haha. Being done brought a feeling of satisfaction and relief that the game itself mostly hadn't.

I did find Vella and Shay both to be interesting characters, largely because they're their own people and don't align so much with gender stereotypes. That said, a lot of other characters are pretty cliche and boring. Like, there are some married parents in Act Two, and the mom's main activity seems to be worrying about her kid, while the dad is gettin' all scientific with the PH balance of a mud puddle and patching holes in a spaceship.

I recommend buying Broken Age on sale, taking lots of screenshots, enjoying Elijah Wood's voice (as Shay), turning to walkthroughs as wanted, and maybe having the snacks you like best nearby. Because this game, like any, is a whole lot better with some nice ridged chips and a towel to wipe the grease.

reviewText:
Tim Schafer is known for his quirky brand of the Monkey Island adventure game. For those new to the genre of point and click adventure games, you explore and solve puzzles within a highly stylized environment as action and narrative gradually unfolds. Understandably, there are both strong and weak points to this style. Since the genre has been around for three decades, the weaknesses have integrated themselves into the appeal of the game. There is an audience who enjoys having ten unique items in a sack and endlessly manipulating them to unravel the story. Other games, such as Telltale's Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us, estimate the majority of the greater potential audience dislikes this style of Trial and Error, and streamlines the experience.

Thus, I will cut right to the chase, Broken Age is consciously archaec. If you have played Monkey Island, The Longest Journey, or Grim Fandago, you know exactly what to expect, since you have played this game before. The story unfolds along an intriguing ark, you obtain and interact with ten items in a sack, appealing humor and characters are involved, and the overall experience is entertaining, moving, and of high quality. If you are new to the genre, and are open minded toward it. Broken Age is one of the Top Grade titles of its class. Tim Schafer himself is a product of the Steven Speilberg, Disney-Pixar, Nintendo craze of the 80's and 90's, and his work is a luminous reflection of his influences. Schafer does have a few off-beat conventions in his style, which you would not expect from a Disney or Nintendo show, but his games deviate only a couple of steps from first base.

Did I enjoy Broken Age? Yes, I was entertained and moved. Is it a classic of the overall genre? As much as Grim Fandago or Monkey Island is in my mind. Would I recommend it to someone else? If you like Tim Schafer's product, then yes, if you have not enjoyed his Adventure Games in the past, there will be nothing here to dissuade you from your prior bias. If you haven't played an adventure game before and you like the Speilberg-Disney-Pixar-Nintendo product, Broken Age is a good place to start and you will have a great time. There's no shame in following a walkthrough.

reviewText:
Broken Age was the very first project I backed on Kickstarter. As such, it will always have a special place in my heart. It also revived my interest in adventure games, which I didn't think possible in my old, jaded age, but it's a consequence of the game that will stay with me long after the game itself is finished, which is an impressive feat.

The first act is a love song to 2D adventure games. There are tropes that play out like you'd expect and others turned totally upside down. It's fun and light-hearted and whimsical. You won't find another voice cast including the likes of Jack Black and Wil Wheaton in an adventure game any time soon. It's funny, and at times, poignant.

Sadly, the second half doesn't follow nearly as strongly. The puzzles are more obtuse. The writing is more matter-of-fact, and a lot of the situations, artwork, and even puzzles get heavily re-used. In some cases this allows for a creative twist on things, but in others it stinks of laziness. Personally I think the issue is that the success of the Kickstarter and Act I gave Double Fine some room to maneuver, so they got distracted: they made several new games such as Massive Chalice and remastered some old adventure titles in between the releases of the acts. The second act feels like it's a necessary conclusion to the story, but one that they rushed through creating rather than taking the time and care needed to make it something truely memorable.

My other complaint is with the achievements. Most of the time I feel that achievements are neutral - you would've done the requirement for it anyway - or positive because they force you to play the game in a new or interesting or challenging way. But here the achievements are almost all neutral or negative - actively detracting from the experience. First, they were only included for Act I after Act II was released, which forces another run through just to get credit for things already completed. Furthermore, some of the achievements require you to get something right on the first try. For me, this is the worst kind of achievement because it discourages experimentation and encourages relying on guides. It's exacerbated by the fact that there is no chapter select, despite the natural break point in the middle and the forums shouting for some kind of way to jump into Act II when it came out.

Finally, there is a speed run achievement. Simply put: it has no place here. An adventure game is the not the kind of game where you want to skip all the cutscenes and dialogue and use a guide for all the puzzles. That's like purposefully ignoring all the best parts. It's stupid. Some people have theorized it's only there because Xbox Live requires games to have leaderboards. It's just speculation, but if it's true it's awful reasoning and it's fustrating that they kept it included in the desktop version, where there are no leaderboards. And to top it off, because of the included manual save feature the speed run is not even challenging, since you can just save when you only complete a section in the optimal time. So it's an achievement that is a worthless chore requiring no skill that forces you to skip past the best parts of the game. I can't imagine what they were thinking.

Broken Age has some beautiful moments and engrossing puzzles set in a unique world. It can't carry the magic all the way through, but it doesn't have to for it to be a game worth playing.

reviewText:
I loved it!  I've enjoyed several other classic point-and-clicks: Monkey Island I and II, Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis, Day of the Tentacle, and Full Throttle, and I think this one makes a fresh and interesting contribution to that library.  The art and music direction is fantastic, the voice acting is great, and the humor is done well.  Minor things bothered me in the final puzzle sequence (mostly the music), but overall I liked the game a great deal.  The puzzles in Act I are fairly easy, so most of my enjoyment came from watching the story unfold and interacting with the characters.  In Act II the difficulty increases a bit, which I appreciated.  Online walkthroughs are easy to find, but of course I recommend playing without them as much as possible if you actually want to enjoy hitting those Aha!" moments when you solve particularly challenging puzzles.


The "Double Fine Adventure" documentary series online is also fun to watch if you're interested in the blood
hoursPlayed: and laughter that goes into video game production.\n\n9/10"

reviewText:
This is a delightful point-and-click adventure. Its strengths are story, superb art and animation, top-notch voice acting, and lush original music. The puzzles are more of a mixed bag: some really great ones, but also a few that don't make much sense and may prove frustrating with a lot of going back and forth.

But, if you like point-and-click adventures, you are sure to enjoy this one. I recommend it. The tone is family-friendly (with a few sly jokes) and endearing. It may remind you in this respect of Machinarium and Botanicula, though voice acting and plenty of dialog really beef up the production.

So, what's up with all these bizarrely negative reviews? This game had a lot of hype, and was poorly managed along the way (it was originally released in two acts" and took a total of three years to make)
date: which led to some inflated expectations about and misdirected anger towards the final product. Some people seemed to expect this to be the greatest point-and-click adventure of all time
recommended: and when it didn't turn out that way
hoursPlayed: slammed the game.\n\nJut ignore all that noise: it's not the best point-and-click adventure of all time
voteText: but definitely worth your time and money. The game absolutely deserves a "thumbs up
helpfulPercent:
even if it has frustrating moments.

I also suspect that some of the negative reviews come from people who just don't appreciate the genre: point-and-click adventuring has always been based on 1) thinking logically, and when that fails 2) trying to use every object on every other object, and finally 3) going: d'oh, why didn't I think of that! If you don't enjoy this kind of gameplay, this is not the game that will convert you. It adheres to all the conventions of the genre, just with exceptionally high production values.

Finally, I'd like to thank the developers for supporting Linux!

reviewText:
Broken Age was originally hailed as a great comeback to Double Fine's origins, the adventure point and clicks of LucasArts.

While Broken Age certainly has good audio and visual design, the gameplay is incredibly lacking. No puzzle is really difficult, you don't really have to do anything too advanced, and I don't think you even have more than 6 items in your inventory at a time.

The locations also match this lacking gameplay. Very few locations that therefore limits the game to less characters and less depth. The locations also bother me, because although it fits the style, the art is very plain and the backgrounds are way less detailed than that of other modern point and clicks, such as the remake of Monkey Island or The Whispered World.

I know I shouldn't be whining when the game has a 2nd part in the works, but judging by how most of the $3.3+ million budget was put into this first part and how Tim Schaefer wanted to get some Early Access money to fund the second part, I can only predict that the second part will be just as disappointing.

Double Fine is capable of much better things than this. Maybe they should stick to publishers and make sure that someone that isn't a complete fanboy believes that they have a good idea.

reviewText: Only act 1 has been released so far, with 2 to follow sometime very soon. I came in with moderate expectations, and came away with an insanely good Double Fine experience. The game is really funny with the quirky humour you've come to expect from Tim, with a lovely art style that remains consistantly cozy and amazing to look at throughout, no matter the route. Both protags are great for their own merits, and add a lot throughout the two wildly different experiences.\n\nOnly thing I can say is the length might not be up to par for some people, although at the time of this review take in to account that only one of the acts has been released, so the second part could be wildly longer in length. I took my time throughout, talking to everyone and clicking on different combos to hear what everyone had to say, and I finished Act 1 in 4 hours, which seems to be the general consensus on how long it'll take a typical person to finish it, so keep that in mind.

reviewText:
At this point, I might as well proclaim my undying love to Tim Schafer. It seems every title I've touched with him behind the director's chair reminds me why I love video games.

Apparently 16 years since his last point-and-click adventure game, Grim Fandango, and the man still knows how to work it. I mean it's not like he wasn't doing anything, with Psychonauts and Brutal Legends druid-plowing themselves into my favorite's list, but point-and-clicks are very different from your normal genre. Practically visual novels; if the story or context doesn't hook you, there's nothing to go back for it aside from meager puzzles.

Luckly Broken Age hooks you from the start with both, and beautiful artwork to boot. Shay and Vella's story is nothing new, something we've seen or read plently times before, but Tim Schafer's spin leaves it refreshing. For example, Shay's situation is entirely understandable, where he puts a mental barrier between him and the Computer" who is taking care of him. Although never brought up by Shay or the game itself
date: it's likely only programmed to take care of him - it isn't true love and concern. Yet all it takes is some lovely voice-work provided by the ever awesome Jennifer Hale and a small story toward Shay
recommended: and I can't help but feel sad for "Computer". Damn you
hoursPlayed: Shay
voteText: just call her "Mom" for once.\n\nContrary to what I'm saying above
helpfulPercent: the game is light-hearted. Vella's story about sacrificing maidens is not as grim as you'd imagine it to be. No blood or gore
votesHelpful: just a small glimpse of a body as it's devoured by a giant species of monster called a Mog. Yet that's part of its charm. Combined with its watercolor artwork and peaceful soundtrack
votesTotal: it's as if I'm reading a children's storybook. Then you eventually come across someone whose name is shortened to Ch't.... heh-heh.\n\nAll and all
votesFunny: I am very looking forward to Act 2. Having started Shay's story first
commentsCount: I thought I had an idea of where his story ended when I was nearing the end of Vella's. The end of Act 1 practically told me "Nope
column16: punched me in the face, and jumped off a cliff. I'd pay again in order for it to come sooner, but like everyone else, I'll have to wait for the free update... whenever that is.\n\nC'mon, Tim. Don't do this to me, man. I needs it. I needs it now~
