reviewText:
A simple point and click with a lot of heart.

The characters are charming, the voice acting is superb, and while the puzzles may seem simple, I enjoyed them and found them rather clever without being too non-sequiter, like some other point-and-click adventures.

A tad short, but this is only part one. Part two will add to the charm and make this game really great. Double Fine is very good at making games that feel like homages to their genre, and Broken Age is no exception. It's an excellent point and click adventure.

reviewText: Broken Age has the same charm that I've come to expect from Schafer's games, like Psychonauts, Costume Quest and Stacking.  The characters are interesting though admittedly one-dimensional (just like most point and click adventure games) and the conversations are mostly quite entertaining.  I think the voice acting is superb as well, especially with the two main characters and the Computer (Mom").  The animation and visuals prove that a game does not need super high def SSAO bloom TressFX etc etc to set the atmosphere of a game in the right direction.  The overall aesthetic (visuals
recommended: ambience) elicit zero complaints from me.\n\nUnfortunately
hoursPlayed: the same cannot be said of the gameplay.  I'm not sure what I was expecting
voteText: but I found the item hunting a bit tiring at times.  I wish there was a way to speed up conversations
helpfulPercent: as I generally read much faster than people speak (pressing space will skip the entire conversation
votesHelpful: not just the current dialogue with subtitles) and though there are some areas where your character can run
votesTotal: most of the time you walk at a very slow clip.  I'm glad that there isn't much hand holding
votesFunny: but when certain areas open up
commentsCount: it can be a bit annoying to walk back and forth between screens looking for an item I missed.\n\nStill
column16: it's not like I did not enjoy the gameplay at all.  I think the clever dialogue (and even off hand remarks as I look at items or walk past characters) cracked me up
column17: and that makes a ton of difference in adventure games.  I had an idea of where the story was heading at first
column18: but now I'm not so sure.  All I know is that Act 2 cannot come soon enough."

reviewText:
I thankfullly got this game while on sale so this will not be a butthurt review of this wonderfully done game. Aside for the fact that the developers failed to live up to their backer's expectations, I find this game hauntingly gorgeus. Even if I did back this up with my own money, and they failed to deliver on time, I'd probably forget I ever funded it and when it finally reached my doorstep I have sweet litte surprise for me.

Broken Age was done with taste. That's what I think of it. It might not appeal to 'gamers' in general or even hardcore ones puzzle-wise, length-wise, heck story-wise even; but I regard this game as a piece of art that was created with impeccable taste. The art, the music (original orchestra music? C'mon, gotta give them credit for at least that), inspired voice acting (I mean the cast is splendid), and innocent but captivating story all blend in to make a fun little game. I say little because with a story this simple and slow gameplay, it'd be painful if it lasts 12 or 13 hours.

All in all I'll give this an 8.5/10.

reviewText: Double Fine really dropped the ball on the second half of this game. Most puzzles in the second half of the game are just really tedious and repetitive, The solutions to these puzzles also do not feel nearly as logical as the solutions to puzzles in the first half of the game. I guess you could say it brings the good and bad of classic point-and-click adventure games to a modern one, but even the story and writing I liked quite a bit in the first half felt inconsistent and off-base in the second half.\n\nGiven how much the second half of the game soured my impressions of the first half of the game, I simply can't reccomend picking it up. I would check out the documentary though. Some fascinating insight there and it's free on youtube.

reviewText: I'll rate the full game (both Act 1 and 2) for what it is given the $15 price point I backed it for. This disregards things such as release time and anything about the developers.\n\nI enjoyed it very much. The artstyle is very cute, the dialog is funny, and the puzzles are just the right difficulty. The length of the game is roughly around 15 hours depending on how thorough you play the game (interacting with every object with every object, trying to extract every bit of dialog). The story keeps you engaged, with you wanting to play more to find out the mysteries surrounding the game's events. For the price of $15, it's definitely worth a playthrough when you want to relax and play some point-and-click adventure games.

reviewText:
Broken Age is a beautifuly crafted point & click adventure that challenges you to use a long lost tool vital to all human beings; logic. The absolutely stunning hand painted art style accompanied by whimsical and inspiring orchestrated music easily sets this game apart from many other adventure games within it's genre. Without a doubt, I would recommend this game to anyone who has the ability to think for themselves, and are yearning for a challenging game that won't hold your hand throughout the play-though.

I also feel that I have to address the negative reviews that are slowly encroaching upon this wonderful game's reputation.

A: I would have to agree that the second act is slightly lacking in the overwhelming epiphany department, in terms of the awe struck feeling it leaves you with at the end of act one, however, that shouldn't warrant people throwing the entire project under the proverbial bus as a result.

B: As I previously stated in the introduction to my review, this game heavily relies on the players ability to utilize their personal logic and problem solving skills throughout the duration of the game. If you read the negative reviews, you will encounter a plethora of individuals complaining about the difficulty of particular puzzles, with which they defeated the purpose of the game by selling their own intelect short and merely looked up the answers. Once again, this game will not hold your hand, and assumes that YOU the player, actually has the ability to think for yourself via deduction and analysis of your surroundings.

C: Many gamers within the playerbase of this project constantly complain about plot holes and unexplained" circumstances of intuition between Vella and Shay
date: as well as their overall importance to the Thrush. Within the second act
recommended: it's my personal opinion that players were too busy looking for things to hate about it
hoursPlayed: rather than actually paying any bit of noteable attention to conversational clues; albeit rather vague

reviewText:
no spoilers

act 1 was great as ♥♥♥♥. it was adorable, charming, funny and just all around amazing and fun to play.

act 2 is a different story, however. somehow double fine managed to make it seem rushed, careless, boring and impossible all in one ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little package. i'd rather have stayed with the cliffhanger at the end of act 1 than played act 2, and i recommend that even if you do ever spend your money on it, you just DO NOT play act 2. it'll likely ruin any liking you have for the game, as it did for me.

that being said, i'm going to put a recommendation here because act 1 was amazing enough that you should definitely try it if you're into point-and-clicks that aren't that hard. i'm simply warning you: you're going to be disappointed by act 2. very disappointed.

and they got, like, eight or nine times as much money as they needed from the kickstarter, didn't they? p sure they spent it all on the famous actors rather than the quality control by the time they were working on act 2.

TL;DR buy it for act 1 because act 2 sucks balls

reviewText:
A very unique style of game, with very deep storytelling. The game is a story and puzzle game. Think of games like myst where you go from area to area gathering tools and items to unlock the next part of the puzzle/story, The game levels are technically linear but they have a very open feel to them. There are many achievements to be had, giving some limited replayability. Some achievements you only get one shot at and if you didn't have a manual save, you would need to start the game over. Most puzzles are well designed, but a few are near impossible to figure out without a guide.  The visuals are amazing works of art. The voice acting and environmental audio is top notch. Overall this game is a great break from traditional styles of games. If you like adventure genre video games with good story telling, you will not be disappointed.

Negatives:
Once chance to attain some achievements without a manual save
Poor guidance for some puzzles
Limited replayability for achievements only

Postives:
The few puzzles encountered are well designed
Excellent graphics and environmental detail
In depth storytelling
Top notch voice acting and environmental audio

Graphics: 10/10
Sound: 10/10
Story: 9/10 (some story elements do not make sense)
Gameplay: 7/10 (lack of puzzle guidance and replayability)
Overall:9/10

reviewText:
I don't recommend this game at all and really it's not worth buying this game. Now don't get me wrong Broken Age is a refreshing point and click adventure game from Tim Schafer but what absolutely ruined this game was Act II of the story. Act I on the other hand was very enjoyable, the story was intriguing and I genuinly connected with the characters. The puzzles in Act I varied from simple to difficult but overall fun and exciting to solve which I thoroughly enjoyed. But DEAR GOD TIM SCHAFER, HAVE YOU NO SOUL FOR CREATING THE ♥♥♥♥ YOU CALL A STORY IN ACT II! The game was in my eyes a masterpiece until act II started. Just a reminder that act II took 1.5 years to release and in those 1.5 years we got the following:
1.) No new characters
2.) No new Environments
3.) Plot hole filled story
and last but not least:
4.) A piece of ♥♥♥♥ ending
If you wanted to even call it ending! the game ends with you having more unanswered questions then when you started!

My Personal rating for this game 6/10

reviewText:
Broken Age is an Adventure, which is mostly thought for kids, but it makes a lot of fun for older ones too.
The Game is build up simple, funny and sometimes kind of tricky.
You Play the two charakters, one in a kind of an space ship, the boy shay, the other in a little village, the girl vella.
Its very exciting to watch their own world and their own problems, which sometimes have some great supprises for you.
Vella, whos always in dangour and mets allong her way many very stupid People. She seems to has a lot more intellect, than the other and thats often difficult to handle for her, while Shay is allone on this Big Space Ship with the KI playing his Father and his mother. He´s always searching for an real Adventure, without having any real knowledge, about what hes really doing.
To come to a conclusion I think Broken Age is a very funny and Great Adveture, just for the first part, which is really nice to play and makes a good difference to the games you normally play instead. It´s really worth it

reviewText:
This game has had my attention the minute my eyes landed on it and then I saw it on early access, I just had to get my hands on it. It seemed to bring something quaint and unique to the table.. Turns out, that guess was right.

The sceneries being 2D hand-painted is an art in itself. Honestly, I found myself just staring at how beautiful the game was quite a few times, I mean, even the menu was quaint, as much of a redundant thing that may be to mention. Topped with a lovely and perfectly fitting soundtrack from Peter McConnel (Who also put together the soundtracks for; Brütal Legend and Grim Fandango). it's all the little things that just make the entirety of it so appealing.

The story-line giving you two different lives with different things to do on each side is already a concept I quite enjoy, it doesn't overwhelm you with too much to do or a need to switch between the two, it just melds in a whole, brilliantly.

The only thing that may throw it off for some is the movement system and no kind of hints for some puzzles can make for a bit of back and forthing looking for required pieces. That aside making a point and click so enjoyable is quite the achievement.

I'm glad they have gotten far more than their goal funding so there will be a chapter 2 soon released as I cannot wait to play the next adventure. Although I have seen a lot of complaints that it is far too short and too expensive for 3-4 hours of play time just in chapter 1, it is an early access game, you buy it to be part of the process of it growing and bettering itself through good and bad. It's always a given in early access. Now they have more than enough funding for a chapter 2 and most likely quite a few more chapters, I personally think it will end up being quite worth it even though for me it already is, just for the amount of work and detail poured into it, I mean, just the surroundings being hand-painted seems to be such a rare and beautiful thing to see.

Final summation, lovely game, awesome story-line, characters, voice-acting and all around charming game. Will be worth it to see it develop into a full game.


****REVIEW UPDATE!****

As chapter two has finally come out, I feel this is due for an update.

Now mind you, I still love this game, I however feel that the execution for most of the puzzles in this chapter were even more obtuse and just downright annoying. Now, I'll be dropping a few tiny spoilers to anyone who hasn't played this yet, just a forewarning.

The fact that the game has gone through hoops just to make these incredibly and punishingly difficult really bothered me. I mean, one example is where you need to figure out how to rewire Shay's robot.. After at least an hour of raging, going back and forth, trying every combination I could think of, I still turned out empty handed. It was only when I went and looked up a walkthrough to see what I was doing wrong, that I felt like putting my head through a wall even more. The answer to the rewire was in a picture that was found in Vella's side. This is using information you never would have known been on the other characters side and something I think barely anyone would ever pick up.

Being able to switch to find out information is an okay way to do things, but the characters would have no way to actually find this out from an in-game perspective.

That aside, the entire chapter was put together really nicely with a range of different mini events happening within the game as you unlock and solve puzzles.

All in all, it's still a more than worthwhile play. Offering a total of about 10 hours of play, give or take however much you rage. Word of advice, have a game guide handy for when you get stuck and close to rage quitting, you may already have all the pieces of what you need to continue.

reviewText: In a world where most games involve an hour of intense highly focused gameplay, Broken Age broke the mold.  Be prepared to be transported into a pastel world, where you are lead screen to screen in a fun and light-hearted manner.  The knock on this game is that the puzzles are a bit easy, but the world is so transcendent and beautiful it's guaranteed to carve into your memory.\n\nReally an excellent game that deserves all of it's accolades, this one is worth every penny.

reviewText:
This game is unfinished as it is, leaving you with a bit of a cliffhanger, but (I believe), part 2 is included in the price when it is finally released.  It has two seemingly very different characters with their own environment, story and puzzles.  You can switch between them at any point, though I never really saw a need for this and played each one straight through.  Truly imaginative worlds with great art, interesting plot, AWESOME voice acting (Elijah Wood, Wil Wheaton)... I have high hopes for part 2!

Update for Part 2: Once again, you play as two separate characters in different worlds, but what you do in one world actually matters, which was a departure from Part 1. You find out key details you need in one world by interacting with the other. The puzzles were much more complicated an finicky for the second part than the first, causing some annoyance.

Pros:
+Voice acting
+Awesome art
+Interesting worlds
+Good puzzles
+Good story

Cons:
-Second half of the game was MUCH more frustrating puzzle-wise.
-First half of the game has little to no crossover between the two characters you play, making the dual storylines seem useless until the second half

Overall:
9/10. A great adventure game.

reviewText:
Broken Age - Act 1 is a nice and short point-and-click adventure with an interesting out-of-this-world story, beautiful artwork, professional voice-acting and lovable details.

+ Interesting story-lines
+ Very nice graphics
+ Very good voice-acting
+ Forwarding of dialogue and animation
+ Pauseable cut-scenes
+ Dialogue choice by number keys
+ Reasoning: NPC feeling hunted by trees boards up window
+ Star Trek reference
+ Extend-A-Ladder
- Rather short
- Inventory items need to be dragged in order to use them
- Reasoning: NPC in predicament, PC refuses to help
- Reasoning: Wants to get fruit, finds a way up the tree, simply jumps down again
- Reasoning: Boarded up fireplace with fire
- Achievements are not yet activated it seems

The game has some nice and some bad design decisions. I disliked the fact that you have to drag items from the inventory, I prefer clicking the item and then the target. I really liked forwarding of animation and text passages. For some reason initial configuration has you press spacebar for forwarding. I recommend changing that to the middle mouse button and I'd much rather have this as a secondary function for left-click or right-click since both don't serve any purpose in those cases where forwarding can be employed.
I also like that you can pause cut-scenes and that dialogue options can be chosen by pressing number keys.

Initially the game showed me a black screen when starting the game with the menu music playing. This was finally resolved by updating my Catalyst Control Center. By then I had already followed some other advice to turn off the Steam overlay for the game and I had to restart Steam to get that back into the game(s).
The game has already defined achievements but they are not yet activated. From the global stats you can see that no one has any achievements and that they cover some actions in Act 1 and mostly actions outside it.

The game includes some strange reasoning, one instance I found funny but the rest was irritating.
* There is the morbid notion of a lumberjack boarding up his place in order to keep out trees.
* The lumberjack also boarded up his fireplace which has a fire burning inside at the time.
* The player character shows some false sense of modesty when refusing to help a stranger in need of assistance because that would include touching.
* At some point you have to get fruit from a tree and find a way up the tree.. from where the PC simply jumps down again.

There are a number of nice details in the game. I particularly like the two Star Trek TNG references and the Extend-A-Ladder". The latter reminded me of the Grim Fandango scythe and triggered a warm bout of nostalgia.

I'm looking forward to playing Act 2 of Broken Age and recommend the first one."

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic game! Where to begin?

1. First and foremost, this game is an awesome deconstruction of unrecognized privilege. I've never come across a game more directly attempting to reach gamers and improve them as human beings. All games published henceforth ought to take a page out of this game's socio/political playbook. I could go on about the instances of this, but there's an outstanding article that pretty much blows it out of the water here: http://www.geekquality.com/broken-age/

2. The art. Ho boy the art in this game. It has the unique Tim Schafer magic of Day of the Tentacle and Full Throttle, but with an elegance that is totally unparralleled in any game I've played to date. Some of the scenes in this game beg you to stop advancing in the game for a while and just ENJOY the beauty. 5/5 stars here.

3. The voiceover and script for the game is phenomenal. All the corny, cherished humor of adventure games from Ye Olden Tymes with A-listers reading.

Amazing work, Double Fine. Please keep turning out more titles like this one!

reviewText:
Act 2 update posted April 28, 2015
I replayed Act 1 and went on to beat Act 2. Everything I already said about Act 1 stays true in Act 2. Act 2 is about another 8 hours if you take the time to talk to everyone and try to do every combo of item with person/thing you can. The puzzles are a little more difficult which is good, but at the end of the game figuring out exactly what to do can be a little annoying what with the multiple possibilities of the wire puzzle".

The answers to what is going on are basically answered
date: but not to the depth I (and I'm sure many others) would have preferred
recommended: especially given the implications of what it meant. If you're worried about a cliffhanger
hoursPlayed:
there isn't one; it just feels like there could (and hopefully will) be more to the story when you beat it. Sequel perhaps? There easily could be one.

Overall I did enjoy this Act 2 and I feel it was very well done. One of the more memorable point n' click adventure games in a long time.

reviewText:
I didn't back this game during the kickstarter and I didn't play it until it was fully released. I intentionally kept myself in the dark to not create expectations and not to spoil myself fun of discovering the game on my own.

Wow this game looks good. The art style is gorgeous, music is great. It is obvious that a lot of work went into presentation. Animation for each conversation seems to be hand-crafted, so if you have an eye for details you will find many things to enjoy.

Sadly the other parts of the game aren't that interesting. Puzzles are occasionally fun but nothing groundbreaking. In the later stages of the game, when it attempts to provide more challenging puzzles BA falls into a trap of being quite abstract. You will do some things, which really don't make sense within the context of the story.

Story itself is enjoyable but disjointed and not particularly convincing. Still it was good enough to keep me interested for the duration of the game. There are some intriguing ideas but overall it is a very silly tale.

I think it is good game but not a brilliant one. If you are looking for something on the level of the Longest Journey, Siberia or Grim Fandango... well, play those. Broken Age is a weaker kind of p&c - the puzzles stop you from progressing the story, rather than being a way of developing plot and characters.

I don't think Broken Age will reopen doors to point&click adventures. It runs into too many problems the old games did and beside presentation it doesn't bring anything new. But if you crave for a new point&click, it is a fun adventure!

reviewText:
While I loved games like Grim Fandango and Monkey Island,  I have to say this game combines great story telling, heartwarming animation, user-experience and puzzle design in way that simply surpasses the former greats.

I seem to have a different opinion than many, and that is likely due to the fact that I played Act 1&2 together.  Waiting several months and then playing in mostly the same settings I suppose could be disappointing, but if played together actually makes the game feel seamless and natural, and in fact the story is as well thought-out as it is whimsical.

I think the same is true with puzzle difficulty: the puzzles progressively get harder over the course of Act 1&2, which makes sense.  Yes, there are times when I got stuck, but that just made figuring them out satisfying. I think one or two puzzles required a pencil and paper (or memorization) in Act 2, which crossed the line for some people.  I would say: 1. the puzzles make sense (enough for an adventure game), and 2. the game is liberal with clues, and 3. no puzzles require" help online.

Kudos to the developers and all involved.  I think there are many stories left to be told in this universe
date: and I hope we get to see them someday."

reviewText:
What a lovely game. Again, what Tim Schafer's games may lack in challenge they make up for in strong characterization, imaginative world building and engaging story telling. I was worried like many others at the completion of Act 1, that there would be no showing of a challening puzzle, but I was pleasantly surprised in the end. The whimsy, the art, the sound and the odd suggestive adult joke made it the game an enjoyable experience.

+Memorable world and characters
+Fun art

-Some weak puzzles

reviewText:
While I loved games like Grim Fandango and Monkey Island,  I have to say this game combines great story telling, heartwarming animation, user-experience and puzzle design in way that simply surpasses the former greats.

I seem to have a different opinion than many, and that is likely due to the fact that I played Act 1&2 together.  Waiting several months and then playing in mostly the same settings I suppose could be disappointing, but if played together actually makes the game feel seamless and natural, and in fact the story is as well thought-out as it is whimsical.

I think the same is true with puzzle difficulty: the puzzles progressively get harder over the course of Act 1&2, which makes sense.  Yes, there are times when I got stuck, but that just made figuring them out satisfying. I think one or two puzzles required a pencil and paper (or memorization) in Act 2, which crossed the line for some people.  I would say: 1. the puzzles make sense (enough for an adventure game), and 2. the game is liberal with clues, and 3. no puzzles require" help online.

Kudos to the developers and all involved.  I think there are many stories left to be told in this universe
date: and I hope we get to see them someday."

reviewText:
This game is unfinished as it is, leaving you with a bit of a cliffhanger, but (I believe), part 2 is included in the price when it is finally released.  It has two seemingly very different characters with their own environment, story and puzzles.  You can switch between them at any point, though I never really saw a need for this and played each one straight through.  Truly imaginative worlds with great art, interesting plot, AWESOME voice acting (Elijah Wood, Wil Wheaton)... I have high hopes for part 2!

Update for Part 2: Once again, you play as two separate characters in different worlds, but what you do in one world actually matters, which was a departure from Part 1. You find out key details you need in one world by interacting with the other. The puzzles were much more complicated an finicky for the second part than the first, causing some annoyance.

Pros:
+Voice acting
+Awesome art
+Interesting worlds
+Good puzzles
+Good story

Cons:
-Second half of the game was MUCH more frustrating puzzle-wise.
-First half of the game has little to no crossover between the two characters you play, making the dual storylines seem useless until the second half

Overall:
9/10. A great adventure game.

reviewText:
This game is set in 2 parts. The first one is so easy that is almost insulting, and since that was a big complain from backers and reviewers, the have the second part being extremely dificult for no reason, with tons of puzzles that come out of nowehere and requiere both characters to solve despite them being in total diferent scenarios.

I disliked the game and finishing it turn into a chore, but after that it gets worst for achievement hunters, with tons of achievements about solving puzzles on the first try despite being try and error, related to pure luck or just dumb and confusing for the sake of it.

You can watch my game library and you´ll see I´m an adventure game enthusiast, from the narrative shows of TellTale, till the pixel art of Wadjet Eye and passing through the classic Lucas Arts games and, yes, the good Double Fine properties that Schafer got back a few years ago. And I enjoy every single one of those games, this one however was painful and the only thing possitive I have to say is that I liked the art and the voice acting, but if you don´t like or you´re indiferent to the art style, and if voice acting isn´t somethign that makes games worth buying for you, then I wouldn´t recommend this game even to an adventure gamer, hell, I wouldn´t even recommended to my enemies.

reviewText:
This game is a REALLY mixed bag. A real pity- it starts with a great deal of promise, but the writers just didn't seem to know where to take the story, and the whole game suffers for it.
I rate it 5  out of 10.

Pros:
Beautiful Artwork and Animation
Pretty good humor
Excellent voiceover work for the most part (Jack Black in particular really nails his part, though it's small)
Mostly solid puzzles
An interesting story premise

Cons:
A few ridiculously obscure puzzles that require bizarre leaps of logic
Jarring shifts in tone in the storytelling
Plot holes big enough to drive a starship through
Giant TWIST in the story midway through that never gets explained AT ALL
Unsatisfying and trite conclusion to the story

reviewText:
I was in the middle of a 10 pages review when I accidentally kicked the power cord and the computer turned off. So I'll make this brief.

Yes, I recommend it. Buy the game.

Strong point: story. Very clever and surprising.

Broken Age ditched all those verbs from the first adventure games. I think that's actually an advance, these things always felt hacky, sometimes there were redundant verbs and you never knew exactly what to do, do I USE a door or OPEN it? Eventually the verbs shrunk to less actions, like full throttle's intuitive wheel. But it was still questionable, what does HAND means I'll do? punch? pick it up? OK, I am glad we got over that but the fact is that more options than simply clicking gives more dimensions to the puzzles and Broken Age feels easy and linear in the puzzle department. Maybe there's a sweet spot between plain click and verbs that makes sense.

I may be swimming against the stream here but I don't like the voice acting. It's not bad acting though, I think they don't know how to deliver Tim Shafer's very dry humor writing, everything sounds like a children's cartoon and it's not as funny as it could be.

UPDATE FOR EPISODE 2:

Everything I said before still holds but I want to make an extra comment on the voice acting. I HATE VELLA'S VOICE. Most of the voices are pretty bad, missing the jokes and all, but serviceable, except hers goes the extra mile and makes me hate the parts of the game I have to play as her. It's like they wrote all of Vella's lines in a book and had someone read it to children as bedtime story, recorded it, and called it voice acting. It's bad. Really, really bad.

I still like the story. It got a little messy and confusing near the end though (still better than several classic adventure games). There were some clever puzzles. I laughed on occasion. Besides my dislike for the voice acting (and hatred for Vella's voice in particular) it's a good adventure game.

reviewText:
I was one of the intial Kickstarter backers who helped it reach that magical 3.3 million funding bux.

I had high hopes for this game after remembering Grim Fandango and recently replaying a lot of adventure games myself, as well as new the new ones.

First I must say, for 3.3 million, I expected a lot more. The game when I played it had glitchy animations, graphics and overall felt rushed and unfinished. I can't even remember the music, or the voices. The level of polish and attention to detail I expected from the creator(s) of Grim Fandango just wasn't there. I can still recall Manny Calavera's voice, Glottis, the festival theme, the little jingles, and the rest of the strong characters in that game. That game made an impact on me which lasts to this day. Somewhere along the line, something got lost.

Regarding the gameplay, the puzzles were a bit on the easy side, but at least they were a bit more straight forward and logical than some of the puzzles in Grim Fandango (The Petrified forest driving sequence almost broke the experience for me in comparison). Still, I was not pleased when I saw that this was it. I expected more.

So for the price you are seeing, I will not recommend this game, and since it is only half the game still, I don't think I will ever recommend the game based on the fact that I was promised a full game and the developers backed off from that.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Just finished Broken Age, and I have mixed feelings about it.

As a backer, and a game developer, I'm still a little miffed that Double Fine couldn't finish the game on the $3+million they got off kickstarter.  Contrary to what you hear, it IS actually possible to set a budget for a game and stick to it... even a creative, art-driven game like this one.

Part of me kept thinking while playing, what game were they planning on making if they had only gotten the $400k or whatever they originally set out to get?  And, is this game WORTH $3 million?

But as I played and got caught up in the story, I started asking different questions.   Is the game worth the $25 I pledged?  Is the world a happier place with this game in it, even unfinished?

I think the answer to both those questions is Yes.  It's a little bit simpler/easier than I remember the classic P&C adventures being.  But in every other way it's as good or suprerior.  The writing and voice acting are great.  The art is beautiful.  And the story is interesting.  I won't give anything away.. but I really liked the ending" to this Act.

Now I'm just keeping my fingers crossed that Double Fine can keep it together and manage their budget enough to actually finish the whole game."

date: how does the final product hold up?\n\nVery well.  Broken Age is a game of unrequited vision: a product designed by visionaries for a very specific audience.  The title of the game represents  adolescents
recommended: the titular "Broken Age" being the lives of the two protagonists who are caught in the pains of growing up. reviewText:
A beautiful point-and-click adventure game with imaginative locales, witty dialogue, and an engaging coming-of-age story of two youths whose paths collide in an astonishing cliffhanger for Act I of this game.

The game is a visual marvel, and is further brought to life with top-notch voice acting. The puzzles are relatively easy, but will still require some more tinkering than say The Walking Dead. If you find yourself stumped with one character's path, you have the freedom of switching to the other, but it is recommended to finish Shay's story first before Vella's. While the game it has it's humourous moments, there is dark undercurrent, coupled with a gender critique that gives it a depth beyond merely being cute.

All told, expect to complete Act I in roughly three hours, but with the richness of its atmosphere and detail, you may want to revisit the game to appreciate the interactions of its wonderful universe.

Bring me more games like this! I'm going to go replay the Monkey Island games now.

reviewText:
Short but sweet, and oh so pretty. Hardcore gamers look elsewhere.
+ IT'S SO PRETTY. I made so many screenshots!
+ Keeps you guessing as to the way the two stories are connected. I was wrong! Twice!
+ Good voice acting. No, really. I know its rare for indie games, but this isn't really indie, now is it?

+/- They don't tell you it's part one of a series until the end of the game. It's not even on the store page; false advertising much? If you're expecting a closed ending, you won't get one. (On the other hand: if you know that it's part of a series, the ending is fine. I really liked it. It ties everything up quite nicely.)
+/- Logical connections, so it's not very difficult. I'm not ashamed to use walkthroughs and I only had to use one twice, once in both storylines, but with a little bit more clicking around I should've been fine without. I'm fine with a lower difficulty level, but hardcore gamers might disagree.

- It's WAY too short for the €23 (+ Kickstarter funding!) they want you to pay for it. Took me 3,5 hours.

reviewText:
Just finished Broken Age, and I have mixed feelings about it.

As a backer, and a game developer, I'm still a little miffed that Double Fine couldn't finish the game on the $3+million they got off kickstarter.  Contrary to what you hear, it IS actually possible to set a budget for a game and stick to it... even a creative, art-driven game like this one.

Part of me kept thinking while playing, what game were they planning on making if they had only gotten the $400k or whatever they originally set out to get?  And, is this game WORTH $3 million?

But as I played and got caught up in the story, I started asking different questions.   Is the game worth the $25 I pledged?  Is the world a happier place with this game in it, even unfinished?

I think the answer to both those questions is Yes.  It's a little bit simpler/easier than I remember the classic P&C adventures being.  But in every other way it's as good or suprerior.  The writing and voice acting are great.  The art is beautiful.  And the story is interesting.  I won't give anything away.. but I really liked the ending" to this Act.

Now I'm just keeping my fingers crossed that Double Fine can keep it together and manage their budget enough to actually finish the whole game."

reviewText: Broken Age was a fun point and click that had an interesting story with a suprise plot twist ending that left me wanting more. You have the option to play between two story lines, one of a boy named Shay and the other of a girl named Vella, both living in two very different worlds. Vella lives a life where young girls are sacraficed to a monster in order to keep their villages safe and Shay lives a life of solitude trapped in a space station he's grown up in all his life. I've played Act One so far and I can't wait to play Act Two when it comes out. For sure a recommended game. If you're still unsure of whether or not to buy it, I did a let's play on the game. Go to my videos and check out the first few episodes, hopefully it'll help give you a better idea if this is the kind of game for you.

reviewText: Holy crap, what happened to this game? While Act 1 was a charming, excitingly drawn game with fantastic voice acting and a promise of an interesting story (albeit pretty light on puzzles), Act 2 retains almost none of this. The VA is still superb, and the art looks the same (it is 80% the same, actually) - but the story turns into something incredibly silly, and the puzzle design is easily the worst I've seen in a long, long time. I could stomach Act 1 taking almost 2 years, but I see absolutely no reason why Act 2 took 14 further months.\nI backed this game, and I'm fine with that as the journey itself was interesting, but the end product... oh no.
